site_title: Good corporate citizenship
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Good corporate citizenship

How can enterprises better match their corporate giving to social needs? Why is doing good ultimately good for business, and what CSR challenges do you face?

Published

Sun, Mar 23, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Adaire Fox-Martin

President

SAP Asia Pacific Japan

Find the ''sweet spot'' where your corporate resources meet social needs - that's how to maximise your unique impact. Listen to and work with your NGO partners, government, grassroots organisations and internal stakeholders to hone in on your organisation's unique contribution.

It's important for social investments to be sustainable, as programmes need to run for some time before results are achieved. Hence enterprises, when laying out CSR strategy, need to align social investments with social causes that generate value for both the enterprise and community. SAP's collaboration with IDA (Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore), for example, promotes technology among youths, while growing the long-term tech industry talent base.

Singapore civil society has an active community and high willingness to give - the challenge is identifying the right organisations to team up with for long-term, sustainable community programmes.

Terry O'Connor

Group CEO

Courts Asia

CORPORATE social responsibility (CSR) cannot be an afterthought but a key pillar of an organisation's business model and operations. Being a good corporate citizen is to be connected to the needs of the local community and to support them. We believe that part of the mandate as corporate citizens includes leveraging our core competencies to effectively support the causes we are passionate about.

Ultimately, a good CSR strategy should allow businesses to give back to the community in a sustainable manner. Courts is strongly committed to lending a helping hand to families and children in need. We are also avid supporters of football and champion the development of local football. Through close collaboration with grassroots and non-profit organisations, we are better able to use our business expertise, networks and resources to support these causes. We also actively engage our employees, customers and business partners to share in our CSR narrative and be part of the larger community spirit.

To us, CSR is not about doing good, but doing what's right.

Piyush Gupta

Chief Executive Officer

DBS

BANKS have an important role to play; we have the power to transform lives and livelihoods in the community. At DBS, we are of the view that we share a symbiotic relationship with the societies and communities which we operate in.

Apart from creating long-term economic value, we seek to positively benefit the communities we are present in and deliver social value. We believe in being a force for good and we champion social entrepreneurship across the region, recognising that social enterprises (SEs) provide innovative and sustainable solutions to challenges in Asia.

We have showcased more than 200 SEs and have given out close to S$2 million in grants to encourage the development of this sector. We are proud to be the only bank in Asia to offer virtually free banking services to social enterprises through the DBS Social Enterprise Package.

To address the region's evolving social needs, we recently set up a S$50 million foundation to strengthen our corporate social responsibility efforts and effectively scale up our support for communities in Singapore and Asia.

Geraint Hughes

Managing Partner - Singapore

Clifford Chance

EXPECTATIONS of corporate behaviour have broadened considerably in recent years and at Clifford Chance in Singapore, we have a cohesive approach to connecting with our community.

Our aim is to harness the ideas, energy and professionalism of our team and to match our efforts to local social needs. Staff at all levels of our business are encouraged to take part in a range of different ways that suit their skills and interest, with examples ranging from legal advice to charities, to fund raising through to participating in community schemes - in each case, employing the same professionalism and energy that we apply to advising our clients on a day-to-day basis.

Our CSR efforts are focused primarily on three key themes - widening access to education; justice; and finance. These three themes underpin the work of the Clifford Chance Foundation, our official channel for giving. Our aim each year is to make a meaningful difference to 100,000 people globally - including in Singapore and throughout South-east Asia.

Ingrid Sidiadinoto

Managing Director

UPS Singapore

AT UPS, we have long believed that we grow not only by investing in our business but also in our people and our communities. We believe the best way to give back is to draw upon our company's unique business assets: linking philanthropic dollars with our logistics expertise, transportation assets and the skills and passions of our global employees. Our UPSers are always in the forefront speaking to our clients, listening and understanding the community's needs. We believe that by living and working in the communities we serve, our employees are in touch with the needs and issues in the communities

Through various CSR activities, our UPSers are given opportunities to lead and take part in projects that are different from their daily responsibilities. This gives them a chance to try something new, expand their roles within the company and connect with colleagues from different departments. All these have proved to build stronger staff morale within UPS and enhance their sense of belonging to the company.

Janet Ang

Managing Director

IBM Singapore

IBM believes in giving back to the community in the best way we know how: by volunteering our skills, expertise and technology. From helping to build the smarter cities of our rapidly urbanising planet to deploying employees to developing markets to make communities more sustainable, we have taken a thoughtful, comprehensive approach to corporate responsibility that aligns with IBM's values and maximises the impact we can make as a global enterprise. As we continue to connect and engage with the community, we hope to inspire an active volunteering community that fosters social cohesion and promote the spirit of giving.

Lito Camacho

Vice-Chairman Asia Pacific and Singapore CEO

Credit Suisse

AT Credit Suisse, education is one of the primary focus areas among our corporate giving and volunteering initiatives. We have focused our support on numerous education projects around the region from infrastructure building to student scholarships and teachers' training. As an organisation with diverse talent and expertise, our employees also use their professional skills to help our partners in capacity building initiatives such as research, impact assessment, data collection and risk evaluation. Credit Suisse's philanthropic commitments demonstrate that companies are dependent on the existence of a stable environment both for themselves and their employees. We, therefore, support a variety of causes in the areas of education and social welfare through collaboration, strategic partnerships and community outreach efforts, to help improve the lives of disadvantaged people in locations where we do business. These initiatives can only be successful through the commitment of our senior management, employees and community partners.

Joshua Yim

CEO

Achieve Group

OFFERING employment to two groups in particular - the elderly and people with disabilities - is a much more holistic approach than just giving them handouts. Despite their challenges such as age and physical disabilities, many of them still have a capacity to contribute in certain roles so companies should look into offering them opportunities that will bring out their talents and abilities. Over the years, I've witnessed many companies offering employment to people with disabilities in areas such as call-centre work and back-end office administration. These are very good initiatives which I hope more companies can adopt. Another way that society can help these individuals as well as other groups such as ex-offenders is by giving them entrepreneurship opportunities. It could be a very simple franchise run as a one- or two-man show such as a hawker stall, for instance. I've come across groups, be it government agencies or non-governmental organisations, that help such individuals who have an entrepreneurial spirit to seek funds to start up their own small businesses or social enterprises. In this day and age, the more enlightened companies understand that doing business is no longer just about making profits. They know they have a social responsibility to give back to the society they operate in. There is also a lot of public recognition for companies that are strong in CSR these days. Besides being good for the company's reputation, CSR activities can help to cultivate a more caring culture within the company.

Teo Lay Lim

Senior Managing Director

Accenture, Asean

CORPORATE citizenship is fundamental to Accenture's character and the way we run our company. The goal of Accenture's global CSR programme, Skills to Succeed, is to equip 500,000 people around the world by 2015 with the skills to get a job or build a business. This initiative draws on one of Accenture's core competencies - training talent - to help address the need for skills that open doors to employment. At the same time, Skills to Succeed harnesses the powerful combination of our financial support, pro bono contributions of time and employee skills to make a difference in our local communities.

Today, the need is greater than ever to have the right skills to build confidence and capabilities that will open doors to employment for the young and underprivileged people. Additionally, Skills to Succeed engages and inspires our people, clients, recruits, strategic partners and the people whose lives we change. Together we have the opportunity to create an measurable impact that is greater than the sum of its parts.

Michael Zink

Head of Asean and Citi Country Officer

Singapore

WHEN corporate giving is aligned with our business expertise and the skills of our employees, we are able to generate greater impact in the meeting of social needs. At Citi, financial literacy is the cornerstone of our corporate citizenship efforts as it is a natural extension of the work we do as a global financial institution. Through financial literacy, we seek to enable progress in the communities that we serve and raise the quality of life for individuals and families as they make more informed and responsible financial decisions.

Over the past 11 years, we have committed more than S$10.8 million from Citi Foundation to financial literacy programmes serving various segments of Singaporeans including youths, young adults, teachers, mature women and the general public. There is also ownership among our employees as they serve as mentors in the programmes as a form of skills-based volunteerism. Thousands of our employees are also engaged in broader community service efforts throughout the year and around our annual Global Community Day. Corporate giving is a part of our corporate citizenship efforts. Under the unifying idea of Responsible Finance, we seek to ensure that our actions are in the interests of our clients, create economic value and are systemically responsible.

Tan Tong Hai

CEO

StarHub

TODAY, it is insufficient for a company to focus on providing excellent products and services. Consumers prefer to buy from a company that also does good. Doing good should hence be seen as part of a company's overall branding efforts.

When we run any business, we also think of how to grow and sustain it in the long run. Likewise, CSR efforts must be sustainable, firmly rooted into the corporate culture and transform the company's behaviour in the longer term. To do so, CSR must be driven by more than a few individuals.

StarHub is one of the few companies in the world which have one division taking care of CSR - Marketing, Corporate Communications and Investor Relations. This expands the budgetary and manpower support for our CSR initiatives. It also ensures that CSR is on top-of-the-mind recall among employees, and as much as possible, incorporated into our marketing efforts.

Dr Tan See Leng

Managing Director & CEO, IHH Healthcare

and Group CEO & MD, Parkway Pantai

AS a listed company, we have an obligation to deliver returns for shareholders. That said, we believe delivering social equity is also an important return, which can be achieved through a sustainable CSR. This has to be more than an initiative or a department - CSR has to be at the heart of the business. The most impactful way to make a real difference is to identify activities that are squarely at the nexus of what we do best as a means of fulfilling important social needs - our core assets being hospitals and our expertise being medical care.

Getting this right requires collaboration and commitment across many stakeholders. Since last year, IHH and our largest shareholder Khazanah collectively committed to delivering partial and fully sponsored medical treatment to needy patients in our home markets of Singapore, Malaysia and Turkey. Through the Khazanah IHH Healthcare Fund, we work with charitable and voluntary welfare organisations to identify patients who need assistance. They are cared for by our first-class doctors and medical staff at our hospitals. We're meeting a social need by doing what we do best - and in our view that can only be a good thing for our business.

Chris Mead

Regional Director

Hays in Singapore

AT Hays, we understand that the right person in the right role can transform an individual's life and transform a business. That is what makes us the ultimate people business and means that a responsibility for the world around us must be at the core of what we do every day.

We are currently applying our passion for people beyond recruitment to support the Singapore Cancer Society, which is dedicated to minimising the impact of cancer through public education, screening, patient services, financial assistance, research and advocacy.

During the past 18 months, Hays has raised about $8,000 through a variety of events and has fostered a strong understanding of the Singapore Cancer Society and its challenges. The people at Hays Singapore are proud of the relationship and will continue to work closely with the organisation.

While our business has a low environmental impact, we are committed to achieving continuous improvement in environmental performance and to preventing pollution. We now measure our global carbon footprint for the first time in accordance with the Greenhouse Gas Protocol. Hays is included in the FTSE4Good Global, Europe and UK Indices.

Lionel Lee

Group CEO and Managing Director

Ezra Holdings

AT Ezra Holdings, we believe that giving to social needs should be at the heart of a company's ethos and corporate culture. Engaging employees across various levels in altruistic activities have proved to inspire loyalty that importantly translates to talent retention. These activities form the DNA of empathy, patience and humility for every successful company amid the high-stress/high-pressure working environment that industries such as Ezra's offshore oil and gas operate in.

As companies invest in social capital, they need to build long-lasting relations with their CSR partners and local communities. For example, we have been involved in the ACE@Boon Lay Programme for many years and have been able to engage many kids who may otherwise be unsupervised at home after school.

Sustainable involvement brings about tangible outcomes which companies can then feel proud of.

Max Loh

Country Managing Partner

Ernst & Young

CORPORATE giving has a place in business. The benefits of corporate giving are multifold. Beyond the feel-good altruistic factor, the way in which companies conduct their corporate responsibility (CSR) programmes are reflective of the organisation's values, attracting stakeholders and investors who share similar beliefs. Additionally, CSR programmes provide opportunities for employee engagement. Yet often the challenge is in linking CSR to business imperatives and influencing stakeholders on its value. At EY, CSR is core to our purpose of building a better working world. We believe we have a role, at a broad level, in fostering a sustainable environment, developing entrepreneurship and talent, as well as contributing to more robust capital markets where capital flows and employment thrives, while at the same time helping underprivileged groups in our communities.

Allen Ang

Group Managing Director

Aldon Technologies Services

AN effective CSR practice can enhance a company's brand and image. These intangible assets are critical to strengthening the company's reputation as a trusted enterprise, a responsible corporate citizen and as an employer of choice.

Aldon Technologies has been giving donations to charitable causes on an ad hoc basis. We would like our staff to volunteer their time and skills for social causes but we do not know where and how to begin. As an SME, we have limited resources to develop a corporate CSR programme. It would be useful for SMEs like us if the National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) can broaden its scope by offering services to help SMEs develop effective CSR practices that match their resources to community needs.

Philip Yuen

Chief Executive Officer

Deloitte Singapore

DELOITTE empowers our employees to not only be leaders in business but also in the community. Our people are strongly encouraged to take part in CSR initiatives like our global Impact Day where we mobilise Deloitte people worldwide to give back to our communities.

We also support our people through our firm-sponsored Volunteer Club in Singapore or even smaller groups of employees who, on their own time, wish to band together to do their part for the community. This support can come in the form of funding, flexibility in taking time off work as well as encouragement through internal publicity of their efforts. In addition, we volunteer our professional expertise to charitable organisations that need them.

At Deloitte, our CSR efforts span the entire year, and· we believe that creating a strong business and building a better world are not conflicting goals - they are both essential ingredients for long-term success.

Kong Chee Min

Group Chief Executive Officer

Centurion Corporation

CORPORATIONS need to recognise their interdependence with society and local communities, and cultivate a corporate culture that upholds a sense of responsible citizenship. We need to remain aware of best practices in the market and ensure we fully understand how our business impacts society, whether directly or indirectly and whether positively or negatively.

We believe that corporate social responsibility extends beyond monetary contributions. At Centurion, our CSR begins with having a heart for our people. We understand that we have a responsibility beyond providing for the basic needs and well-being of worker residents who stay at our dormitories. We strive towards giving them a higher quality of life by providing good facilities and organising meaningful activities.

Doing good builds mutual trust and respect between the corporation and the community, which strengthens relationships with key stakeholders and the general public. At times, it is a balancing act for companies to meet the expectations of these various stakeholders but we trust that the creation of not just economic but social capital is needed for a business to prosper in the long-run.

Takeo Shimazu

Managing Director

Brother International Singapore

THE role of corporations has become more significant in achieving a sustainable society, and the demands and expectations of stakeholders have increased as well. We have a company principle at Brother which is based on the concept of ''Tomoiki'' or co-existence, which supports our longstanding belief in caring for the community.

For Brother, CSR is a fulfilment of our motto ''At Your Side'' and we see it as a mid- to long-term perspective in order to achieve further growth, establish a trusted global brand and build a company with a strong sense of pride among its employees.

We carefully identify our CSR activities by evaluating how we can best contribute to three specific areas - society, environment and our customers. This is important for us as the right CSR activities that will encourage participation among employees and, at the same time, provide value and add to the community.

Yeoh Oon Jin

Executive Chairman

PwC Singapore

WHY is doing good good for business? Businesses that positively impact the society are not only more relevant and sustainable, they are better perceived by both staff and customers.

Customers, especially the younger ones, are becoming more environmentally conscious and socially responsible. Some of them are prepared to forsake purchases and even job offers if the organisation does not support the social values they believe in. Organisations which are socially responsible drive both consumer behaviour and employment attractiveness.

The public is having a growing influence over businesses and is demanding higher standards of responsibility and accountability from them.

At PwC, we have always been giving time and money through donations, involvement in local and regional community projects and providing pro bono expert assistance to worthy causes. In recent years, we have also been focusing on raising awareness and empowering our staff to suggest ideas to find innovative new ways to reach out to and meet the needs of the local community. The outcome: practical ideas such as changing light bulbs, replacing mattresses, providing entertainment and organising excursions for elderly residents of lower-income neighbourhoods, etc. The list of innovative contributions goes on and we hope that through these initiatives, our staff will develop and embrace a sense of responsibility for the local community.

Julien Le Noble

Senior Managing Director, Head of Asia Pacific

CME Group

AT CME Group, not only do we value the critical role we play in financial markets, we also value being a productive and contributing member of the communities we serve. We take a strong, active role in global corporate social responsibility and community involvement. In 2012, nearly US$5.4 million was contributed through our charitable programmes, corporate foundation and independent foundations that we support.

The CME Group Community Foundation seeks to provide particular support to three areas of concern: children in need, education and health and human services. We are proud to be a socially responsible organisation that is making a positive and lasting difference in our communities. Locally, we have donated nearly US$40,000 to the Singapore Children's Society, and we have also supported the Truyen Tin Orphanage's fundraiser in Singapore, which helped the Vietnam-based orphanage purchase a school bus for its children.

We are privileged to partner non-profit organisations throughout the locations where we have a presence, to provide needed services and strengthen local communities. It is important for businesses to be actively involved in championing the causes that they have identified, and help these non-profit organisations fulfil their missions of creating a brighter future for those they serve. We hold the belief that, in order for businesses to thrive, the communities they operate in must also thrive. Organisations that adopt and embrace CSR will benefit from the creation of a more rounded business environment, greater employee engagement and increased customer loyalty.

Thomas Bon

Chief Executive

OKH Global Ltd

CSR goes beyond charity and philanthropy. And, to better match corporate giving to social needs, enterprises can frame CSR initiatives on a certain social cause/objectives. This will enable the enterprises to monitor and track the relevant outcomes while keeping a check on costs. And if necessary, enterprises can finetune these CSR initiatives without deviating from the objectives.

Why is doing good ultimately good for business?

The world has become increasingly interlinked where enterprises' actions will have multiple ripple effects across economies and communities. Doing good is second to our human nature and on this basis, we have made it part of our corporate mission. We strongly believe that, in the long run, we will enjoy enhanced brand reputation, increased customer preference and employee satisfaction, which contributes towards profitability. To co-exist on a long-term sustainable basis, the relationship between enterprises and the community must be mutually beneficial.

Two key challenges stand out in our CSR initiatives:

* Identifying suitable and relevant CSR initiatives - with the various social causes in the community, we need to carefully identify those that resonate with our objectives.

* Deployment of limited resources - while we are committed to our CSR initiatives, existing business operations would require a significant amount of resources to support. Hence there is always a tradeoff which has to be carefully planned.

Hugues Delcourt

Country Executive, ABN Amro Bank NV. Singapore and CEO of ABN Amro Private Banking Asia & Middle East

IN order for corporations to give back to society effectively, we must have a deep understanding of the wider community we operate in. The environment is continuously changing, and keeping abreast of prevalent societal gaps and current public issues allow MNCs like ours to sharpen our corporate social responsibility strategies to contribute more locally. Putting these insights into practice ensures that a company's resources are being used in the most effective way and this, in itself, contributes to sustainability. Whether a company's efforts involve monetary donations, employees' time, or implementing changes in business practices, a well thought-out and targeted approach is necessary.

Being one of the oldest banks in Singapore since 1858, ABN Amro has deep roots in Singapore, which is a key market for us. We take cues from ongoing and new national initiatives to understand how we can contribute as a bank, to further propel Singapore's status as an international city. In today's intensely competitive environment, corporations have to be aware of how their businesses impact society, and not just about the bottom line.

The challenge of ensuring that the needs of various stakeholders are met remains and doing good in society ultimately helps to boost our employee engagement and pride and further cements our strong ties with the community.

Julienne Loh

General Manager, Singapore

MasterCard Worldwide

I AM a strong believer that, to do well, a company must also do good. Having an acute awareness of the community we operate in and being socially responsible is key to the longevity of any business.

MasterCard's CSR efforts focus on two key areas, namely the empowerment of women and children. We continuously look for ways to help women and girls learn skills required to gain economic independence and support families. We established MasterCard MBA Scholarships for Women in 2011 together with SMU to further develop awardees into academically outstanding, business-savvy and socially responsible women. In addition, MasterCard was also the co-creator of Project Inspire: 5 Minutes to Change the World, with UN Women Singapore, which aims to highlight the importance of women's roles in society, and support initiatives that ultimately improve their socio-economic standing. Programmes such as these ensure we provide a hand-up, rather than just a hand-out, which is sometimes a challenge when doing good.

We also want to encourage responsible spending. MasterCard's survey on ethical spending in 2013 showed that, on average, one in three respondents in Singapore had purchased an item simply because a percentage of its sale was donated to a good cause. This finding supports MasterCard Purchase with Purpose initiatives, which sees MasterCard contributing to charitable causes each time a consumer uses his MasterCard card.

Martin Hayes

President

Bosch Southeast Asia

ENTERPRISES need to formulate CSR strategies tailored for the communities that they are present in to maximise impact and build local trust. Alongside the initiatives centrally coordinated from the Robert Bosch foundation in Stuttgart, Germany, we also adopt a local-for-local strategy. We collaborate with charitable organisations that operate at the grassroots level to better understand the inherent difficulties and challenges of our beneficiaries, and to ensure that our efforts benefit them directly. When we organised a food drive for World Environment Day in 2013, we also conducted an information session to communicate transparently who the beneficiaries will be and how they will be impacted through our efforts. This transparency provides trust and confidence, which amplifies the amount of support rendered.

Bosch supports the local communities where we are present in to advocate the moral, physical and intellectual development of the people. In the wake of events such as the 2004 tsunami and, more recently, Typhoon Haiyan, we focused our efforts on re-establishing schools and libraries. It is our firm belief that education is critical to the growth and development of any society.

Seah Kian Peng

CEO (Singapore)

NTUC Fairprice Co-operative Ltd

CUSTOMERS today are more aware of the various social and community causes and are more likely to engage with organisations that are aligned with their values. A socially responsible organisation resonates better with customers, increases brand loyalty, and is recognised as a responsible employer too. CSR is, therefore, about creating a positive impact on the triple bottom line - people, planet and profits. For most companies, the challenge of developing a CSR programme lies in identifying the right cause to support which aligns the company's belief against the needs of society. At FairPrice, we adopt a holistic approach that embraces corporate philanthropy, protecting the environment, responsible retailing and staff volunteerism as part of our CSR framework. One key focus of our CSR initiative that goes beyond our social mission to moderate the cost of living, is to help the poor and needy through both volunteerism and philanthropy. We have a robust volunteer programme that encourages and facilitates staff participation in over 70 volunteer activities, clocking more than 2,300 volunteer hours last year, while FairPrice Foundation has donated in excess of $49m to help the less fortunate since its inception in 2008. We are guided by our corporate philosophy to do well and to do good, and with the support of our customers, we aim to build a better life for all.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

PLAN-B ICAG Pte Ltd

TODAY, the playing field for beneficiaries of corporate giving can be levelled more. Many of the beneficiaries with well-known corporate donors behind them, and with more publicity, tend to receive more than they need. Enterprises can better match their corporate giving to social needs by spending more time to find out which are the charities with more compelling causes and who need the most funding and urgently. The essence and thrust of corporate giving must be to direct it to where it makes the most impact. In this regard, it makes sense to consult key stakeholders such as National Volunteerism and Philantrophy Centre in our giving eco-system, as part of the necessary homework needed for impactful and meaningful corporate giving. Regular corporate donors and sponsors continue to be victims of donor fatigue. To alleviate this, beneficiaries of corporate giving should widen their sources of funding and giving. Apart from expanding the reach in the private sector (businesses), charitable organisations and VWOs must also not hesitate to reach out more to the public sector (civil servants) and people sector (individuals). Corporate giving should not be undertaken only for the good of the business, but be driven more by the altruistic desire to help those who need it most. Giving is never enough to satisfy all the compelling needs out there, but when more businesses give, in line with their capabilities and capacities, the pressure on corporate giving can be lightened and it becomes more fulfilling, while ensuring a more equitable distribution of benefits to those who need it most. That said, giving in Singapore will take root when all 3Ps play their part.

Dora Hoan

Co-Chairman/Group CEO

Best World International Ltd

SOCIAL needs are best studied by voluntary welfare organisations. They have worked closely with the needy people and are in a better position to help. Therefore, enterprises can address social needs by working with these organisations. As there are various voluntary organisations working for numerous causes, enterprises would need to evaluate them and decide where to give. For whatever reasons, charitable deeds can help businesses build up positive images. With social media, the good reputation can be magnified. However, just as businesses want good reputation, VWOs are also mindful of their branding, i.e. they are selective of their corporate partners. Hence, there have been times when joint initiatives fell through because they were not in line with the VWOs' objectives. This could be resolved if businesses are conscientious of their branding and work with VWOs that are complementary to their industries.

Dumont Jean-Michel

Chairman

Ruder Finn Asia

IN today's globalised economy, companies' licences to operate come as much from the governments as from the communities where they operate in. We have helped businesses across the region develop their CSR strategies and the perceived lack of return on investments is often the main challenge that stops them from deploying CSR initiatives. However when done correctly, meaningful CSR generates immense reputational benefits for the company which translates to greater competitive advantage in a number of ways. Additionally to creating a goodwill shield in the event of a crisis, benefits include attraction and retention of better talent, especially among a younger generation who is more inclined to join socially responsible organisations. Involving employees and tapping their individual talents is also one of the best forms of corporate giving and ensures alignment with social needs. As importantly, good CSR has the ability to strengthen business partnerships and engagement among like-minded companies. Aligning the CSR strategy with the company's broader vision allows one to design cross-company measurements that actually show a positive return on investment as opposed to a cost impact.

Leong Yee May

Senior Vice-President, Asia Pacific

Orange Business Services

WHILE we all know CSR initiatives are integral to corporate identity, our efforts need to be effective, addressing genuine social needs. Strategic CSR initiatives may enhance an organisation's reputation, but in order for CSR to be effective for beneficiaries, enterprises need to engage in a social purpose that leverages a business' skills and operational competencies.

As part of the outreach efforts, Orange reaches out by supporting through our expertise in the field of communications apart from voluntary work and philanthropic activities. Being a communications integrator, our mission is to create links between individuals and make communication easier for those who are excluded for reasons such as health, handicap, and/or economic situations. We recognise the ubiquity of digital technology and its significance as an essential learning tool and leveller in education. Orange Foundation leads our philanthropic efforts globally, making digital technology accessible to everyone through workshops, healthcare, education, providing schools in developing countries with IT equipment and training. For example, Orange has provided downloadable tools for people with autism, and 730 workshops were held as part of our digital solidarity programme. We are also supporting philanthropic missions across Asia Pacific.

But well-intentioned projects can generate unintended operational consequences, such as failure to integrate CSR objectives into business priorities, inadequate staff education, among others. Enterprises must do the necessary groundwork to ensure full compliance of environment, health, safety and other regulations related to the target project, and to avoid being blindsided by unintended outcomes.

Enterprises may be tempted to identify social priorities and simply act on those, but by aligning corporate giving with the company's expertise, they can be more productive and demonstrate social responsibility through active engagement.

Roland Smith

Vice-President

Center for Creative Leadership (CCL), APAC

AT CCL, we believe that it should be about both a better bottom line AND making a positive societal and environmental impact - the Triple Bottom Line. We are driven by a mission to advance the understanding, practice and development of leadership for the benefit of society worldwide, and everything we do is in service to that mission.

Organisations often think that business and CSR initiatives are an ''either-or'' situation, when in fact, organisations should take an ''AND'' approach. A major challenge that most organisations face is recognising how polarities can be complimentary and interdependent, and figuring out how to implement a sustainable ''AND'' strategy. Because of its delicate nature, it requires innovative thinking, and can be time and energy consuming. If handled incorrectly, it can lead to organisations leaning on one aspect over the other, especially in the longrun. However, organisations should remain resolute and disciplined to reap the benefits, business or otherwise. The lessons of experience we learnt is - the more leaders lead responsibly, the more engaged and productive employees will be and the organisation, in turn, will earn other's respect.

Herbert Vongpusanachai

Managing Director

DHL Express (Singapore)

SOCIAL responsibility is an essential consideration for businesses today as it guides our actions as an organisation and ensures long-term success for the company by building trust with the community we live in and increasing employee engagement.

To create significant and lasting impact in our society, it is important for enterprises to build a corporate culture which infuses daily work with the commitment to better our society. This is a critical element that companies need to consider when creating CSR initiatives as it allows them to capitalise on their core competencies to achieve the greatest effect.

For DHL Express, we are leveraging our logistics expertise in our GoHelp initiative, which focuses on transporting humanitarian aid to disaster areas. As a global logistics provider, we are also committed to minimising our impact on the environment and reduce our carbon footprint through our GoGreen programme. In addition, our GoTeach initiative champions education for the less privileged, allowing us to cultivate long-term benefits in our community.

By intertwining social responsibility and business success, we ensure that DHL and our employees assume a more active and enduring role in the advancement of our society.

Cheng Heng Chew

Singapore Country Manager

American Express

ALIGN the CSR strategy with the values of the company, and assess what social needs there are to which the company and its employees can bring the biggest impact - that's key to executing a meaningful corporate giving programme. Giving back to the communities where our employees and customers live and work has been a corporate value at American Express since our founding. Today, serving our community is not only integral to running a business successfully, it also helps to enhance our reputation and engagement with employees, customers, business partners and other stakeholders.

Globally, American Express supports three giving platforms: leadership, historic preservation and community service. In Singapore, we engage our employees as volunteers and pro bono consultants to support these causes. Some of our recent activities include serving Lo Hei dinner for elderly residents to celebrate Chinese New Year, and conducting financial education classes for underprivileged children.

The challenge is how to develop a long-term CSR programme and yet continue to innovate, in order to engage both our beneficiaries and employees. After all, what matters most is the positive impact we can bring to the community in the long run.

John Keung

CEO

BCA

THE Building and Construction Authority (BCA) plays a key role in shaping a user-friendly and sustainable built environment. Making our built environment more accessible improves the mobility of people with diverse needs and promotes a more inclusive society, while green buildings help to reduce the impact on the environment and conserve energy. BCA has also been partnering the built environment sector on CSR and giving back to society. One example is our partnership with the industry to raise funds for the President's Challenge. The built environment sector is also in a unique position to help the less fortunate beyond time and money. For example, BCA and the Singapore Contractors Association, together with their members and material sponsors, helped the Singapore Association of the Visually Handicapped with an extensive renovation and makeover of their building. Within BCA, our CSR activities have even been extended to involve families of our employees as well as students at the BCA Academy. Ultimately, caring for and being responsible to our environment and community is a meaningful cause and I would like to encourage businesses and all our stakeholders from the built environment sector to join us in future CSR activities.

Koh Lian Hock

CEO

Lien AID

FROM an NGO perspective, there are tangible and intangible benefits for enterprises to practise corporate social responsibility (CSR) both financially and in terms of skilled volunteerism, to help the needy in Singapore and in the region. This not only benefits communities at the receiving end, enterprises also find themselves gaining value from the experiences.

Lien AID focuses on providing access to clean water and sanitation for rural communities in Asia and we have seen corporations support the work financially as well as send teams to the locations to help implement water projects according to their expertise. We have received positive feedback from enterprises that they found their employees more bonded as a result of working together for a good cause. Companies also help to build well-rounded employees in the CSR activities, which goes a long way in the staff's development.

Jessica Tan

Managing Director

Microsoft Singapore

AT Microsoft, we believe that corporate responsibility goes beyond fund-raising initiatives. It is a company-wide effort that is committed to making a difference. A challenge we face is finding the right opportunities where we can use our technology to make a positive difference. We believe that this effort cannot be achieved alone. Over the years, we have worked closely with our employees, business partners and stakeholders to explore ways to enable people from all walks of life to pick up skills and knowledge that would help them to improve their lives, bridge the digital divide and enhance their employability in the long run. These partnerships have enabled us to scale and sustain our efforts. In Singapore, with the world's third fastest ageing population, our seniors need to remain relevant and connected in this fast-changing world. Working closely with relevant NGOs and government agencies, we have introduced technology skills to more than 15,000 seniors. Along the way, this has helped nurture a community of digitally active and workforce-ready seniors. With the Society for the Physically Disabled (SPD), and with our partners through our efforts at the Infocomm Development Centre, nearly 2,000 persons with disabilities have been trained with basic technology skills, with 350 of them equipped with vocational skills. This has enabled 37 of them to find employment.

Chris Comer

CEO and Property Developer

Castlewood Group

IT'S 25 years since the first Corporate Social Responsibility report was published, and that was by ice-cream makers Ben & Jerry's; the first major corporation to follow was Shell some nine years later. Within Castlewood Group, we have embraced CSR since our inception. As a company, every member of our staff makes voluntary cash contributions monthly, deducted at source, and matched by the company. Our hotel projects follow a strict green eco-friendly carbon-neutral design and operations policy, and our Construction Code of Practice insists upon the use of local workforce and locally sourced and produced materials. Our social conscience initiatives for 2014 include a programme of ''Personnel Involvement'' as it was felt that the giving of time, gaining ''face to face'' exposure to social causes, would benefit the development of our staff, making them more socially responsible and aware, creating valuable members of society while making a valuable contribution and difference in the community. We welcome opportunities to increase our community involvement as it is all part of Castlewood Group's ''paying it forward''.

Christophe Duchatellier

CEO

Adecco Asia

COMPANIES can help by understanding the challenges that society is facing. This could vary from environmental changes to socio-economic reforms. Giving back to society within the communities we operate in has become the norm for many businesses. Some examples would be to partner local non-profit organisations as well as with government bodies to conduct focus groups and other outreach activities - these could be a purely financial contribution or other ways including volunteerism and community service. The benefits of a strong CSR culture have been intangible both in helping to attract and retain talent as an Employer of Choice but also serving to enhance brand value. We have seen several examples of companies ''doing good'' and the strong relationships they have created within their communities through regular engagement. However, organisations also face challenges which include apathy and indifference from their employees. Some ways in which management and HR can help bridge this gap include regular and transparent communication, as well as creating employee networks to help promote causes through employee-centric programmes.

Toby Fowlston

Managing Director, Singapore

Robert Walters (Singapore)

IN the keen competition for quality local talent, companies are increasingly looking at their employer branding in the market. A socially responsible organisation will not only benefit from a highly positive corporate reputation, the goodwill it builds with its robust corporate governance and activities can also attract, keep and develop people. Salaries and job responsibilities aside, professionals today are looking for more rewarding aspects of their career. By being increasingly active in this space, companies are likely to be more socially aware. This allows them to align their CSR efforts with their corporate philosophy and maximise contributions to the right causes. With most companies, the biggest challenge is in trying to make financial sense of the contributions as well as buy-in from senior management. Fortunately in Robert Walters, we have top-down initiatives such as the annual Global Charity Day which supports a local charity. While contributing to the local community it also creates a sense of focus and achievement for a specific day in the year amongst our employees.

Leon Leon Perera

Chief Executive Officer

Spire Research & Consulting Group

DOING good ultimately benefits companies by winning over customers, attracting and retaining employees as well as attracting the growing number of ethical investment funds. While all these advantages may not be decisive right now, they will become more important in the future as societal norms evolve. To avoid a mismatch between corporate giving and social needs, corporates need to better engage with non-profits to share goals and constraints, so as to align on areas where there is the closest fit. This conversation on goals should precede conversations about concrete activities. In Spire, most of our employees are involved in at least one CSR programme. We continue to strive to learn from past activities and to align employee preferences with company goals.

Dirk-Peter van Leeuwen

Senior Vice-President and General Manager

Red Hat Asia Pacific

CSR activities can help enterprises nurture leaders with a strong sense of commitment and responsibility in giving back to the communities. Red Hat believes that the community efforts we do go beyond helping those in need. It also creates a sense of fellowship among the employees at the same time, bringing us together to make a difference.

For donations, we look at areas of basic needs, education, technology and health, and we also have annual events that allow us to support a good cause while building brand awareness within the communities. We want to make sure that everyone at Red Hat can participate in our CSR programmes because, at the end of the day, we want to drive a long-term value to everything that we do.

Dhirendra Shantilal

Board Director & Head of Asia Pacific

Fircroft

TODAY, being a socially responsible enterprise is no longer optional; it's absolutely essential. With educated consumer communities demanding better from their brands, enterprises need to understand that corporate giving can no longer be an afterthought. This integration of corporate citizenship into the corporation has benefits beyond the immediate gratification of doing good - CSR policies that are aligned with the business objectives and strengths of the enterprise are good for the bottom-line. Socially responsibly companies are better placed to attract and retain talent - because the talented of this generation are drawn to enterprises that are making a positive difference to the world at large. As a recruitment firm in the oil, gas and energy industry, we operate in a sector that is closely scrutinised for its CSR policies. The companies we place talent with recognise the significant environmental and social challenges faced by society and are committed to ethical business practices. Anything short of this will lead to CSR policies that are more decorative than useful - for both our people and their profit.

Hari Krishnan

Managing Director - Asia Pacific and Japan

LinkedIn

MOST of us want to contribute to social causes, and this is underscored by a recent survey which shows that 82 per cent of LinkedIn members want to volunteer their time and skills. The gap between action and inaction is sometimes due to time constraints or lack of awareness of opportunities to make a difference.

At LinkedIn, we believe we can leverage what we do best as a business - connect talent with opportunity at massive scale - to positively impact the non-profit sector, by helping them find talent to drive their causes for example. Our ''LinkedIn for Good'' efforts aim to connect our employees and more than 277 million members globally with opportunities, from volunteering projects to more strategic board positions within non-profit organisations.

An impactful CSR programme is one that aligns the business' actions to its mission and values. This unlocks synergies which can result in immense social value, and in the process, benefit the business as it strengthens its connectivities within the communities it operates in.

Joshua Soh

Managing Director for Singapore and Brunei

Cisco

THE success of our nation is based on several factors, one of which is social investments. By creating value in our society, we can nurture strong relationships built on trust with customers, partners, stakeholders and the community we operate in. It is great to see many companies dedicated to improving lives and building thriving communities through initiatives, including the President's Challenge.

When investing in CSR efforts, our focus needs to be on areas where our expertise, resources and technology can have the most impact and self-sustaining effect. That is why the social investments by Cisco are in transforming education, connected healthcare, economic empowerment, preserving the environment and social support. We look for opportunities to help our partner organisations succeed far beyond what we have invested - by putting skills, confidence, and empowerment into the hands of people. And that is the philosophy behind the Cisco Networking Academy programme. We help build tomorrow's workforce by developing highly skilled network professionals to support local industries and have trained more than five million students in 9,000 academies operating in 170 countries.

We transform lives, communities and the planet working through the combined power of human collaboration and networked connections. That's impact multiplied.

Anne Tong

Chief Executive Officer

HSR International Realtors

IN order for corporate social responsibility to create impact, it should be consistent and sustainable. CSR is clearly outlined in our mission - ''As a responsible corporate citizen, we take pride in contributing towards the development of the community.'' We believe that as a successful business, it is our social obligation to help the less fortunate among us. Participating in CSR activities enables our salespersons and staff to build strong character, which translates into how they perform at work - with honesty, integrity and a genuine willingness to serve other people; key qualities that customers look for in a real-estate agent. This ultimately reinforces our brand-building efforts. With Singapore being an ageing nation with many citizens who require financial assistance, we have dedicated our CSR efforts to these groups of people. Two of our main programmes, Home Meal Service and Agape Ration Service, involve delivering fresh meals to needy families as well as giving out essential rations on a regular basis. We also offer support to the elderly by organising excursions, wellness checks and social activities. In implementing our programmes, the amount of resources and having sufficient volunteers are our main challenges. Nevertheless, we will continue to build and strengthen our charitable efforts, as we feel it is important as a corporate body to strike a balance between our CSR initiatives and overall business objectives.

Sam Yap

Group Executive Chairman and Co-Founder

Htwo Investment Holdings Pte Ltd

COMMUNITY involvement and community service has always been a value adopted by Htwo Investment Holdings in our business activities. This value is well-ingrained among our staff.

Htwo Holdings commits to integrate CSR into our decision-making process to achieve wider economic, community and environmental impact in which we operate. CSR will enhance our ability to pursue our business successfully in the long term.

As part of its CSR efforts, Htwo Holdings implements:

* Environmentally friendly practices in our business processes and activities;

* Fair labour-management and employment practices;

* Employee volunteerism and community service to the disadvantaged and needy; and

* Family-friendly practices.

This year, our employees organised a charity dinner for residents of a children's home. Senior citizens were invited to join in and have fun in a colourful event where they received gifts for the festive period. CSR programmes are not only useful to recipients but also for the staff as it deepens their awareness of the social and community landscape and encourage the spirit of sharing and caring among themselves.

David Low

CEO

Futuristic Store Fixtures

CSR is fast becoming a business unit of its own, especially for established corporations with a larger headcount as well as for industries with direct touch points with end-users. Futuristic Store Fixtures services a portfolio of fast-moving retail brands and many of our clients have strict protocols for CSR which further drives our CSR directives. We set aside an annual budget for CSR initiatives, which includes staff volunteering, events planning and execution with homes for the underprivileged and the medically needy, apart from upfront monetary contributions. Being socially responsible is part of our branding; we ensure that quality fixtures and services are delivered with a green conscience. Having CSR ingrained in our branding creates a culture of sharing and giving in the workforce. This encourages compassion within the workforce, not only towards the organisations we choose to adopt but also towards co-workers, which enhances social bonding, thus creating a more conducive working environment. Mobilisation of manpower for activities without disruption to employees' work and personal lives remains a challenge, along with the allocation of funds in tighter financial times.

Ronald Lee

Managing Director

PrimeStaff Management Services

IT is wonderful that more and more companies have been realising the importance of CSR and adopting such initiatives in recent years. Besides monetary donations, which are certainly crucial, staff volunteering is perhaps more meaningful as the volunteers get to relate on a personal level to the beneficiaries, be they underprivileged families, children, youth, the elderly and people with disabilities. To this end, companies could grant employees official time off for CSR activities, such as allowing them one working day off a month specifically to pursue volunteer work with a VWO of their choosing. Naturally, such an initiative is especially challenging for SMEs as they are already feeling the pressure of escalating business costs amid the economic restructuring that Singapore is undergoing. At PrimeStaff, CSR is a strong component of our company culture. Lending our support to children and youth, particularly those who have been neglected and abused, is something that is close to our hearts. Our appointed charities include the Singapore Children's Society and the Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, among others. On a company level, we often take part in CSR events such as charity runs/walks and strongly encourage our employees to join in. I personally believe that when individuals have more exposure to those less fortunate in the community, it helps to build character and makes them more well-rounded individuals who not only care about material wealth but about their fellow man too. It is thus my hope that through these growing CSR efforts, Singapore can start to transform into a more caring society.

Robin C Lee

Group COO

Bok Seng Group

AROUND the world, achieving Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is becoming a major goal for most companies. To do so, companies have to manage the social, environmental and economic impacts of their actions and be responsive to those who may be affected by their business operations. These responsibilities range from being more environmentally friendly to doing philanthropic work. In most large enterprises, there is often the challenge of pursuing profit-driven objectives while at the same time having to maintain the compassionate human aspect which improves a company's branding as well as reputation. As it stands, most large enterprises achieve this through big donations, usually accompanied by media glare, which thus confer branding returns. This does not typically incur too much time commitment on the company's part. There probably isn't as much take-up when it comes to CSR activities that involve the volunteering of one's time. I propose that a balance of these activities would be optimal, as it is vital to cultivate from top to the bottom the importance of having compassion and giving back to society with a genuine heart. I'm not criticising the philanthropic decisions of companies but, rather, I strongly feel that actions, helping out on the ground, are just as important as writing cheques. The power of human connection and interaction can never be doubted. Consequently, companies with caring, compassionate employees are often places where there is more teamwork, communication, fun and collective creativity, all keys to a successful business. That is what we in the corporate community should strive for and achieve.

Zaheer K Merchant

Regional Director (Singapore and Europe)

Qi Group of Companies

SOCIAL needs calls for understanding and compassion. Aside from achieving profits, which is important, companies should also focus on building a workforce that is gracious and selfless in society, and relevant to its needs. Organisations such as Singapore Compact (part of United Nations Global Compact) place strong emphasis on creating awareness and helping to build sustainable development for businesses and stakeholders in today's society. Having staff interested and involved in CSR programmes is beneficial to build resilience and an overall corporate image. Our group has several corporate volunteering programmes in place where employees work directly with non-profit and voluntary welfare organisations to better the lives of others. We have found that once employees see the positive difference they can make in others' lives, it makes them more understanding and respectful of the community they live in. It compels working towards bigger change. Ultimately, values such as generosity and the pursuit of social justice are what make a society proud of itself. We hope it will result in a society that gives, and not just takes.

David Leong

Managing Director

PeopleWorldwide Consulting

CORPORATE social responsibility is not about good business. It is about doing the right thing. When businesses do the right things and align their business bearings with certain principles - to have good CSR - the employees will also get the same sense of doing the right thing. Whether it is ethical, social, commercial or personal, doing the right thing is key. It is about setting an equilibrium in ethical standards and being accountable to all stakeholders. Correct CSR culture will rub off on employees as good ethical behavior and that will be the biggest benefit for companies - to have more employees doing the right thing.

Rob Bratby

Managing Partner

Olswang Asia

AT Olswang, we have a saying that ''law is what we do but CSR is who we are''. CSR is not something we do because we have to or just because others do it but because it is integral to our beliefs and approach to doing business. CSR brings many benefits to those we work with, our staff, our morale and focus on innovation and collaboration. Our projects have also helped us to build stronger partnerships with clients and in the sectors in which we work. There are many opportunities to engage in fantastic CSR opportunities in Singapore. We have chosen to work closely with the social enterprise sector which is aligned with the skills we can offer as a business. South-east Asia has a great scheme which we have helped develop which guides organisations by matching them with suitable social enterprises and helping them develop mutually beneficial relationships. I would urge companies to explore those opportunities in addition to the more obvious charity and volunteering options.

Eric Hoh

Vice President, Asia South & Korea Regions

Symantec

Symantec's core business objective is the protection of information, and we help people, businesses and governments safeguard against the growing cyber risks of the digital age. To meet the long-term needs of our stakeholders, we have invested to stay at the forefront of the security threat landscape.

We are also committed to educate the wider community against cyber security risks, and have partnered with Fei Yue Community Services to run a school-based online safety programme. This commitment to give back to the community extends beyond the online space, and we provide our employees with hands-on experiences -- such as by matching our corporate donations to the amount of time staff volunteer via our Dollars for Doers Programme, and sponsoring 32 trees for the Garden City Fund's Plant-A-Tree Programme.

By integrating corporate responsibility into our business strategy, we deliver value to our stakeholders, and it also allows us to remain committed to operating ethically and to practice sound environmental management to make a positive impact in the community.

Servcorp launches new serviced office at Metropolis Tower 2

Published Mon, Mar 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AUSTRALIA-LISTED Servcorp will launch its fifth serviced office in Singapore for sale today - a 14,000 sq ft space that occupies half the eighth floor of The Metropolis Tower 2 in Buona Vista.

The new serviced office will have 36 fully managed office suites and meeting rooms. It also comes with service facilities ranging from receptionist and secretarial support, to information and communication technology (ICT) infrastructure.

In an interview with The Business Times, Servcorp's chief operating officer, Marcus Moufarrige, said that serviced residences may be a more cost-efficient alternative for companies seeking premium office space amid rising rents for traditional prime offices.

site_title: A stroll through the shopping mall sector
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A stroll through the shopping mall sector

The profitability of retail malls depends on their tenant mix, use of space and population income growth, reports CAI HAOXIANG

Published

Sun, Mar 23, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DUBLIN has its pubs, London has Trafalgar Square and New York, Times Square. In humid and rainy Singapore, however, the top hang-out spot of choice for food, shopping or leisure is probably the ubiquitous air-conditioned shopping centre.

There are more than 80 malls in Singapore, scattered over all parts of the island, usually located near an MRT station. What investors might not know is that they can invest in at least a quarter of these and collect dividends through the rental income mall landlords receive. They can also invest in malls in other markets too, such as Hong Kong, China, and Indonesia.

Today, we introduce the drivers of the industry behind the retail real estate investment trust (Reit) sector, which is arguably one of the more stable and defensive sectors in Singapore. This week's piece is focused more on a general look at the industry, its opportunities and challenges. A future piece will describe and evaluate individual retail Reits.

Reits are financial vehicles where companies park property assets to enjoy tax advantages. Shopping malls are popular assets to be put into a Reit structure. Reit investors tend to look for stability and income, instead of explosive growth. This is especially true of retail malls, and a subset of retail malls located in Singapore's heartlands known as suburban malls.

After all, rents cannot be doubled overnight, and tenancy levels, usually near 100 per cent, have little upside. But shopping centres can still make money.

Performance drivers

Some factors that drive higher profits are within the control of a Reit manager. The top strategy is what is known in industry jargon as the asset enhancement initiative, or AEI for short.

AEIs are essentially renovation. People renovate their houses to make smarter use of space. They knock down walls to make a room bigger. They give the home a more comfortable and liveable look by laying new tiles, slapping a fresh coat of paint on the walls, and installing high-quality kitchen appliances as well as brighter lights.

Similarly, a smart mall manager will turn an awkward corner into a mobile accessory shop or bubble tea kiosk; escalators can be shifted to improve traffic flow; carpark space can be turned into shops to generate higher rental income; a more modern look will attract younger shoppers. With so many malls in Singapore, the older ones eventually lose their lustre and have to be renewed.

Another factor landlords think about is the tenant mix. What shops appear in malls are a two-way process: potential tenants apply for leases, and landlords try to bring in certain coveted brand names. A basement area that would otherwise stay quiet can be livened up by the right mix of popular restaurants and a supermarket. After dinner, people typically buy some groceries before heading home.

Controlling the tenant mix is an art as well as a science. The science is in analysing the industry the prospective tenant is in, and the tenant's own business operations. This ensures rent can be paid on time. If the tenant is profitable, rentals can be increased after leases, typically on three-year terms, are up.

The art is in figuring out what kind of shoppers the mall should focus on attracting, identifying the latest trends and designing the mall and tenant mix accordingly.

Having the right tenant mix is critical to a mall's performance. Barely one month after the former Iluma mall beside Bugis Junction opened its doors in 2009, some retailers began having discount sales. Perhaps their offerings were too niche. Perhaps Bugis Junction, located on top of Bugis MRT, offered strong competition. A bridge from Bugis Junction also did not link directly to the mall.

Iluma's fortunes seem to have turned around after CapitaMall Trust bought it in 2011 for $295 million and spent $38 million revamping it, reopening it in 2012. At end-2013, the mall, now renamed Bugis+, pulled in net property income of $21.3 million - a decent 6.5 per cent net property income yield on its new valuation of $330 million.

External factors

While mall managers can redesign the mall through AEIs and reshuffle the tenant mix, some factors will remain out of their control.

One key factor is the mall's location. This can only be controlled when the Reit manager is deciding whether to acquire the mall. Location will impose constraints on shopper flow. Those located right next to MRT stations will have the advantage, be it Bugis Junction and the former Iluma mall, or Somerset 313 versus neighbouring Orchard Central.

Related to location is who lives nearby. This is referred to as a mall's catchment area. Some malls attract a higher-spending crowd than others, and can thus charge their retailers higher rents.

Suburban malls with grocery chains and movie theatres will always have a captive audience. After a long day at work, it is far more convenient for a family to walk to the nearest shopping centre for dinner, entertainment, and a trip to NTUC FairPrice, than drive or take public transport to another part of town.

Another factor that is controlled upon purchase is size. Malls that are bigger will have more flexibility to customise their tenant mix and offerings. People are attracted towards and are more likely to spend time in a place where they can do multiple things.

Economic trends also affect mall performance. Rising median incomes are a boon to suburban malls. People are encouraged to spend more if they are getting promoted and receiving bonuses.

Higher tourist visits will be a positive for malls along the Orchard Road shopping belt. Job creation and economic growth also affect spending patterns.

How the economy affects a mall depends on the tenant mix. An economic downturn will hit malls with many high-end shops, such as SPH Reit's Paragon, harder than a place catering to the mass market, such as Fraser Centrepoint Trust's Causeway Point.

An epidemic outbreak, such as Sars, might cause people to stay indoors instead of going out to shop. A mall such as Vivocity, which is near a ferry terminal and transit points to Sentosa island, will be hit more when people do not travel.

A serious economic downturn will make everyone tighten their belts, spending less at expensive restaurants and boutiques.

Market watchers also examine statistics on the total amount of retail space in Singapore. According to the latest CapitaMall Trust presentation slides, Singapore's retail floor space supply growth is estimated to slow down in the next five years to hit 65.5 million sq ft by 2018 from 61.1 million sq ft in 2013, compared to growth from 54.5 million sq ft in 2009.

A final indicator can be the retail sales index, published by the Department of Statistics. Retail sales growth has been shrinking in the past few years, in line with a slowing economy.

After the latest release this year, observers pointed out that shrinking retail sales in the past year might indicate growing usage of e-commerce platforms.

Online threat

Is online shopping a threat to brick-and-mortar malls? Will retailers be doomed to have their shops become glorified showrooms while savvy consumers compare prices on their smartphones and ultimately make their purchases somewhere else?

In the US and other parts of the world, people shop online through Amazon and eBay. Estimated quarterly US retail e-commerce sales as a proportion of total quarterly retail sales have grown from 2 per cent in 2004 to 6 per cent today, according to the latest report from the US Census Bureau. Total e-commerce sales for last year were estimated at US$263 billion, up 17 per cent from 2012.

In China, the biggest player is Alibaba, which controls more than two fifths of the e-commerce market. It sells everything from apples and olive oil to motorcycles and used cars. Businesses around the world use it to run import-export operations. The company is preparing for an initial public offering in the US that values the company at about US$140 billion. Advertisers also use social media such as WeChat to market their products.

In Singapore, online shopping sites include Qoo10, Rakuten, Singsale, Zalora, mobile site Carousell, and online grocer Redmart. People also shop at British online store ASOS, vintage and handmade item store Etsy, supplement store iHerb, cosmetics supplier Luxola, just to name a few.

The advantage online shops have over their real-world counterparts is the lower set-up costs. For one thing, they do not have to worry about paying rent.

Consumers also like the convenience of browsing several sites at one go, instead of trudging from shop to shop looking for the best deal. Busy consumers with young children to take care of will find it more convenient to shop from home.

In addition, the disadvantages that dogged the early years of online shopping such as dodgy suppliers or credit card fraud are disappearing. Online shopping sites are becoming more reputable, consumers can buy from highly-rated suppliers who deliver on time and do not misrepresent their products, and e-payment systems are becoming more secure with payments authenticated through mobile phones and electronic passcode generators.

As online shopping takes off among a younger generation that grew up with the Internet, the composition of shops at Singapore's malls might change.

Certain items, such as electronics, books and nutritional supplements, can be easily compared online and purchased, with delivery to one's doorstep.

Other shops, notably clothes and shoes retailers, might still have a place in a shopping mall. This is because consumers can touch, see and try out these items on the spot, compared to wondering if digitally-enhanced pictures on the Internet can be trusted.

Restaurants, cinemas and supermarkets are unlikely to be replaced by the online threat.

To conclude, shopping malls in Singapore are here to stay in the foreseeable future. While they are not exciting investments, they can be reasonably profitable ones. A future piece will examine the 10 or so Reits listed here with exposure to the retail mall sector.
