site_title: MAS CEO's job has just gotten tougher
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

MAS CEO's job has just gotten tougher

Airline lost RM4.13b over past three financial years

Published

Sun, Mar 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[KUALA LUMPUR] Malaysian Airline System (MAS) chief executive officer Ahmad Jauhari Yahya was hired less than three years ago to steer the carrier into profitability. His mission has gotten harder as the national carrier hunts for a lost plane carrying 239 people.

The 59-year-old power industry veteran has presided over a 63 per cent slump in the stock since joining the state-controlled airline in September 2011, battered by unviable routes and competition from low-cost carriers including AirAsia. The airline lost a total RM4.13 billion (S$1.6 billion) over its past three financial years.

Rescuers have been searching for MAS Flight MH370 since it disappeared en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing early on Saturday. It is the second mishap in six months. In October, a Twin Otter DHC6 plane operated by its unit MASwings crash-landed in Sabah on Borneo island, killing two. That was the first fatal plane accident in Malaysia since August 2009, according to AviationSafetyNetwork, a Netherlands-based website that tracks safety statistics.

"When something like this happens, it does impact greatly on the reputation, their ability to turn around," said Shukor Yusof, an analyst at Standard & Poor's in Singapore. "Also, it casts a negative light on the management and shareholders of the company."

MAS has seen newer budget operators leapfrogging it with bigger fleets, with margins eroded on popular routes. Mr Ahmad Jauhari has also had to contend with some politicians calling on the Malaysian government to sell its stake in the airline which lost RM1.17 billion last year.

Mr Ahmad Jauhari spent about 16 years in the power generation industry, where he rose to the rank of managing director at Kuala Lumpur-based Malakoff, the nation's largest private sector power generation group before it was delisted.

When he left Malakoff in 2010, the power producer had more than doubled its earnings per share to 93 sen from 40 sen in 2008 following the global crisis, according to the company's annual reports. Mr Ahmad Jauhari was the CEO of privately held Premium Renewable Energy for about six months before joining MAS.

His career also included stints at Esso Malaysia, the then petroleum retailing unit of Exxon Mobil Corp, and newspaper publishing group New Straits Times Press.

Fourteen out of 16 analysts who cover the stocks have a "sell" rating, while two recommend "hold", according data compiled by Bloomberg.

Challenges ahead for Mr Ahmad Jauhari include boosting worker productivity, while trying to convince travellers to stick with the airline even after this incident.

MAS employees are less productive than their counterparts at neighbouring airlines. They each generate an average of US$222,000 in annual revenue, less than half the figure at Singapore Airlines Bloomberg data show. Workers at Thai Airways International and PT Garuda Indonesia Persero each bring in more revenue.

The national carrier, incorporated as Malayan Airways Ltd in October 1937, operates a fleet of 96 planes, according to its website. The company plans to order as many as 100 aircraft, and is seeking to start taking deliveries of the new ones from late 2016 or early 2017 as it works to upgrade its fleet over the next decade, a person familiar with the matter said in February.

The airline's worst crash was in 1977 when 100 people died after a reported hijacking, according to the Malay Mail.

The carrier needs new fuel-efficient jets to cut costs amid rising competition from discount airlines. Budget operators in South-east Asia have ordered at least 1,000 new aircraft in the past five years as economic expansion across the region enables more people to start flying in countries such as the Philippines and Vietnam.

Khazanah Nasional, a Malaysian sovereign investment company, has a 69.4 per cent stake in the carrier. In May 2012, the fund reversed a share swap that had handed 21 per cent of MAS to the parents of AirAsia, the budget carrier run by Tony Fernandes. The about-face followed complaints by MAS biggest union.

Among those who called for the government to sell out of MAS are former premier Mahathir Mohamad, who oversaw its initial public offering in 1985, and the executive who previously returned the carrier to profit. Former Malaysian Air managing director Idris Jala, now a minister in Prime Minister Najib Razak's Cabinet, said in August that the government should stay out of the airline business. Mr Idris returned the company to profit on a quarterly basis in 2006.

Dr Mahathir, Malaysia's longest-serving leader, told state news service Bernama last year that a private owner would work harder to avoid losses than the government. Mr Najib said in August that the government will not sell its stake, and the airline's turnaround "cannot happen overnight". - Bloomberg

Rare insider sale in Raffles Medical

Published

Sun, Mar 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE buying rebounded while the selling among directors was flat last week based on filings on Singapore Exchange in the first week of March. Buyers outnumbered sellers with 23 companies that recorded 49 purchases worth $5 million versus five firms with six disposals worth $310,000.

The buy figures were sharply up from the previous week's nine companies, 17 purchases and $2.29 million. The sales, on the other hand, were not far off from the previous week's four firms, 11 disposals, and $240,000. Meanwhile, buyback activity remained high with 12 companies posting 35 repurchases worth $6.6 million. The number of firms was up from the previous week's 10 companies, while the number of trades and value were down from the previous week's 41 transactions worth $11.3 million.

With buyers dominating trading, the bulk of the significant trades were purchases last week with insider buys in Sinjia Land, Hong Fok Corporation, Ley Choon Group, Zagro Asia, See Hup Seng and JB Foods.

On the negative side, there was a rare insider sale in Raffles Medical Group. The director trades in these seven companies were made, following the announcement of annual results.

Sinjia Land

CEO Cheong Weixiong recorded his first on-market trades in metallic, elastomeric and polymeric components manufacturer and distributor Sinjia Land (formerly HLN Technologies) since June 2011 with 331,000 shares purchased from March 3 to 7 at an average of 10.3 cents each. The trades, which accounted for 45 per cent of the stock's trading volume, increased his direct holdings by 22 per cent to 1.83 million shares or 1.22 per cent of the issued capital. These were made on the back of the 46 per cent drop in the share price since December 2013 from 18.9 cents.

The counter is also sharply down since February 2013 from 25 cents. Mr Cheong previously acquired one million shares in June 2011 at 28 cents each and an initial 500,000 shares in March 2011 at 31 cents each.

Sinjia Land announced on Feb 25 a year-end loss of $1.9 million versus a profit of $782,000 in the previous year. The counter closed at 10.5 cents on Friday.

Hong Fok Corp

Executive director Cheong Sim Eng picked up where he left off in property developer and investor Hong Fok Corp in January with 400,000 shares purchased on March 6 at 72.3 cents each. The trade increased his direct holdings to 92.924 million shares or 11.74 per cent. He also has deemed interest of 38.298 million shares or 4.83 per cent. The acquisition was made on the back of the 10 per cent rebound in the share price since February from 66 cents. He previously acquired 200,000 shares on Jan 9 at 70 cents each and 659,000 shares from April 22 to Dec 2, 2013, at an average of 69 cents each. Prior to his purchases since 2013, the director bought 170,000 shares from March to April 2012 at an average of 53.5 cents each and 2.6 million shares from March to April 2011 at an average of 57.5 cents each.

Investors should note that managing director Cheong Pin Chuan purchased 96,000 shares from Dec 20 to 31, 2013, at 69.5 cents each, which boosted his direct stake to 10.343 million shares or 1.31 per cent. He previously acquired 2.86 million shares from August to December 2008 at 49 cents to 16 cents each or an average of 19.5 cents each. The company announced on Feb 28 a 361 per cent gain year-end profit attributable to owners of the company to $356.952 million. The counter closed at 73.5 cents on Friday.

Ley Choon Group Holdings

Chairman and CEO Toh Choo Huat picked up where he left off in one-stop underground utilities infrastructure services provider Ley Choon Group in December 2013 with 830,000 shares purchased from March 4 to 5 at an average of 17.2 cents each. The trades increased his deemed holdings to 310.952 million shares or 52.49 per cent. He previously acquired 726,000 shares from Nov 21 to Dec 31, 2013, at an average of 17.9 cents each and 345,000 shares from March 4 to May 14, 2013, at an average of 20.6 cents each.

Prior to his purchases in March 2013, the chairman acquired 1.45 million shares in November 2012 at an average of 19.7 cents each and 4.026 million shares in September 2012 at an average of 22.2 cents each. Ley Choon Group announced on Feb 28 a fourth-quarter loss of $4.653 million, which was more than the loss of $287,000 in the same period in 2012. Earnings for the full year, however, were $14.322 million versus a loss of $3.157 million in the previous year. The counter last closed at 17.1 cents

Zagro Asia

Chairman and CEO Poh Beng Swee recorded his first on-market trades in agri-healthcare products manufacturer and distributor Zagro Asia since June 2013 with 315,000 shares purchased from March 4 to 5 at an average of 29.9 cents each. The trades increased his deemed holdings to 41.694 million shares or 16.1 per cent. He also has direct interest of 122.358 million shares or 47.28 per cent.

The purchases were made on the back of the 15 per cent rise in the share price since July 2013 from 26 cents. He previously acquired 812,000 shares in June 2013 at an average of 26.3 cents each. Prior to his purchases since 2013, the chairman acquired 4.4 million shares from August 2009 to November 2010 at an average of 20.7 cents each and 2.49 million shares in October 2008 at an average of 18.6 cents each. Zagro Asia announced on Feb 25 a 13 per cent rise in annual total comprehensive income to $9.003 million. Its shares closed at 31.5 cents on Friday.

See Hup Seng

Executive director and group CEO Henry Ng Han Kok resumed buying shares of grit blasting and tank cleaning firm See Hup Seng, after the stock fell by 13 per cent from his acquisition price on Jan 23, with 1.1 million shares purchased on March 5 at 30.5 cents each. The trade increased his direct holdings to 31.471 million shares or 5.17 per cent. He also has deemed interest of 42.769 million shares or 7.03 per cent. He previously acquired five million shares on Jan 23 at 35 cents each and an initial 25.37 million shares from Jan 6 to 22 at an average of 32.9 cents each. The purchases since January are Mr Ng's first on-market trades since his appointment as executive director on Jan 3 (Mr Ng was appointed group CEO on Feb 28). The acquisitions were made on the back of the drop in the share price since October 2013 from 39 cents. Despite the fall in the share price, the counter is still up since November 2011 from 14.2 cents

The corporate shareholder sentiment is not entirely positive this quarter as substantial shareholder Chew Hoe Soon unloaded 3.6 million shares on Feb 25 at 32 cents each, which lowered his stake (direct and deemed) by 9 per cent to 34.709 million shares or 5.7 per cent. He acquired a net 11.9 million shares from May 17 to July 1, 2013, at 29 cents each and had an initial filing on May 14, 2013, of 5.827 million shares at 29.9 cents each, which raised his interest to 6.28 per cent. The company announced on Feb 27 a 52 per cent gain in year-end profit to $7.96 million. The counter closed at 31 cents on Friday.

JB Foods

Executive director Goh Lee Beng recorded her first on-market trades in cocoa products manufacturer JB Foods since she joined the group in 2003 with an initial 400,000 shares purchased from March 4 to 6 at an average of 25.6 cents each. The shares bought represented 0.08 per cent of the issued capital. The purchases, which accounted for 30 per cent of the stock's trading volume, were made on the back of the 26 per cent drop in the share price since September 2013 from 34.5 cents.

The counter is also sharply down since February 2013 from 51.5 cents. The acquisitions were also made after JB Foods announced on Feb 28 a fourth quarter loss of RMB 23.095 million ($4.78 million) versus a profit of RMB 7.186 million in the same period in 2012. Loss for the full year was RMB 53.22 million versus a profit of RMB 39.161 million in the previous year. The counter closed at 27 cents on Friday.

Raffles Medical Group

Independent director Wee Beng Geok recorded her first on-market trade in private integrated healthcare provider Raffles Medical Group since June 2011 with 50,000 shares sold on March 6 at $3.28 each. The trade reduced her direct holdings by 5 per cent to 1.021 million shares or 0.18 per cent. The sale was made on the back of the 10 per cent rebound in the share price since February from $2.98.

Despite the rebound in the share price, the counter is still down since April 2013 from $3.52. The disposal was made at a profit based on the 120,000 shares that she acquired via exercise of options on Feb 4 at 78 cents each. The director previously sold 30,000 shares in June 2011 at $2.31 each. Prior to that sale, Ms Wee acquired an initial 30,000 shares in June 2002 at 34 cents each.

Also negative this quarter is Aberdeen Asset Management Asia with a disposal-related filing on Feb 7 of 240,000 shares at $3.05 each, which lowered its deemed stake to 38.722 million shares or 6.99 per cent. The group previously reported a purchase-related filing in April 2013 of 325,000 shares at $3.31 each, a purchase-related filing in February 2013 of 195,000 shares at $3.20 each and an initial filing in November 2012 of 159,000 shares at $2.42 each, which raised its interest to 5.0 per cent.

The company announced its annual results on Feb 24 with profit up by 49.1 per cent to $85.295 million. The stock closed at $3.32 on Friday.

site_title: BOS aims to double AUM growth
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

BOS aims to double AUM growth

Bank of Singapore did some spring cleaning and upgrading last year and growth is back on track, its CEO tells SIOW LI SEN

Published

Sun, Mar 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FOLLOWING three years of strong growth, Bank of Singapore (BOS) spent 2013 spring cleaning and upgrading its back-office operations - but, growth is now back in focus, says chief executive Renato de Guzman.

For 2014, BOS is aiming to grow assets under management (AUM) by 15 per cent, almost double that of last year, said Mr de Guzman.

Its AUM rose 8.0 per cent in 2013 - slower than the previous three years of double-digit gains, as the bank turned its attention to building up its infrastructure and weeding out clients whose AUMs fell below US$1 million.

"We have to go back to 15 per cent growth," its CEO said.

"Asia is still the sweet spot for private banks and that's where we're positioned," he added, seemingly unfazed by the challenges the industry faces.

Of late, as the pressures of cost show no signs of easing, more private bankers are warning of the difficulties of making a decent profit from serving Asia's rich.

Wealth creation in Asia will continue to expand at a more rapid clip than anywhere else, but expensive experienced client advisers and increasingly more complex regulatory demands make it a tough industry.

A McKinsey Private Banking Survey 2012 said Asia was growing fast but profit margins were at record lows due to high cost.

Last week, Singapore, the second largest wealth management centre after Switzerland was found to be the most expensive city to live in, said the Economist Intelligence Unit.

No surprises then that despite frequent headlines screaming Asian billionaires, some private banks are up for sale - the latest being Societe Generale's (SocGen's) Asian private bank. DBS Group Holdings is said to be the buyer for SocGen's private bank.

Wealth-X and UBS Billionaire Census 2013 last November said Asia saw the highest percentage rise in billionaire population (3.7 per cent from 2012 to 508 individuals). It also experienced the strongest surge in wealth - 13 per cent to US$1.18 trillion.

Singapore, with 27 billionaires, has the fifth largest billionaire population in Asia, and the 18th largest in the world.

Profits don't necessarily follow, unless one has scale; and, for BOS, it has another advantage - the "Asian alternative", says Mr de Guzman.

The Asian alternative is an option for clients looking to diversify their banker, he said.

Asian banks have much stronger balance sheets. BOS and parent OCBC Bank, both with an Aa1 credit rating from Moody's, are rated higher than the Swiss banks, he noted.

UBS, Credit Suisse and Julius Baer are rated A2 by Moody's.

"Singapore banks are much safer than European banks . . . We're only supervised by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS)," he said.

DBS Bank, OCBC Bank and United Overseas Banks (UOB) were named the three safest Asian banks in that order by finance magazine Global Finance last year. The three Singapore banks were ranked third to fifth among the world's safest commercial banks.

Being in Singapore, which has a AAA sovereign rating, is another plus, he said.

The Republic's "safe haven, safe place, stable government, consistency in rule of law and open to foreign investment" are a big draw for the rich when they think of where to park their money.

"We also have the OCBC banking facilities, products and services to complement our services," he said.

While AUM growth was slower last year, revenues and returns were better than the industry's, he said.

BOS registered revenue growth of 19 per cent in 2013, aided by an AUM gain of 8 per cent to US$46 billion. It also saw an increase in its earning assets base by 9 per cent to US$56.5 billion.

Its AUM are twice the US$22 billion recorded at the launch of BOS in January 2010 when it became part of OCBC. BOS was the former ING Asia Private Bank. The sale was a "good fit" as "private banking didn't come naturally to OCBC then", he said.

On last year's spring cleaning, he said it was necessary to weed out the smaller accounts, as providing private banking services is very expensive.

Investments went into back-room operations and IT. BOS spent US$34 million last year and will pump in another US$29 million this year into infrastructure, he said.

"We're rolling out straight through processing for trading of all asset classes," he said.

The bank added 23 new relationship managers last year, boosting the total to 303. Total staff strength is 1,100.

He is confident growth will go back to double digits over the next few years.

At that rate, could AUM almost double to US$80 billion by 2017? Mr de Guzman did not want to commit, but said he is excited by new opportunities. One area of focus going forward is Greater China, he said.

Parent OCBC has been ramping up its China operations, one of three areas of focus for the bank outside its main Singapore market.

It is currently negotiating to buy over Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank.

The Hong Kong lender has 43 branches in Hong Kong, 12 in Macau and 15 outlets in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Huizhou, Zhuhai and Foshan on the mainland. OCBC has one branch in Hong Kong, none in Macau and 16 in Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou.

OCBC chief executive Samuel Tsien last September said that "Greater China contributes more than 6 per cent to group earnings". Indonesia accounts for about 5 per cent and Malaysia, 22 per cent.

Greater China has the potential to increase its contribution to the mid-teens, Mr Tsien said. "Though it's not easy to do business in China, it's the driver of much of economic growth in Asia.

"Where OCBC does well, we'll do well," said Mr de Guzman.

Mr de Guzman, 63, is a career banker. His first job at 25 was with a Philippine bank. He then moved to French-owned BNP Paribas, where he spent 12 years, followed by a 20-year spell at ING.

"It was a good industry to get into; it suited my background of finance and accounting," he said.

He moved to Singapore in 2000, when he was tasked with consolidating all of ING's private banking Asian business into a regional platform. He says banking is a complex business and private banking is a discipline in itself.

As for the worst spell in his 38-year career, he points to the global financial crisis of 2008/2009. "It was the 'mother of all financial crises' and the worst period in my life and career. Everyone was running for the exit and there was no place to hide."

He said the bank had to extend some support to the clients since some markets had completely disappeared and there was no liquidity. "Generally, our clients were able to hold on to their positions and recovered fully two years after. It was a very good learning experience, in terms of dealing with the financial crisis," he said.

As for when he would eventually retire, he would only say, "My competition would love me to retire, they're the ones talking about my retirement".

site_title: MOM flags potential graduate-glut problem
content:
MOM flags potential graduate-glut problem

Chuan-Jin says S'pore must ensure that it continues to generate good jobs for its graduate job seekers

Published

Fri, Mar 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

ACTING Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin yesterday cautioned against Singapore producing too many graduates who can't find enough good jobs - a predicament South Korea and Taiwan find themselves in today.

"Their relentless pursuit of paper qualifications resulted in a glut of graduates," he told Parliament during the Committe of Supply debate on the manpower ministry. "The director-general of Taiwan's Ministry of Education stated that 'the abundance of (university) places had undermined the quality of degrees and created a skills mismatch in the job market. People became over-educated and underemployed."

Singapore should not take for granted that it would not face these problems in the future, he said. He noted that by 2020, Singapore would see 40 per cent cohort participation in its local universities. In addition, there would also be many pursuing private or overseas degrees.

"In theory, this can mean that we have an increasing pool of better educated and skilled workforce," he said. "We should be better able to move up the value chain."

But these jobs would only be created by good companies, he said. And these companies would only be here if there's a healthy economy and a business-friendly environment.

"If such companies are drawn elsewhere, those jobs will not be here," Mr Tan added. "Hence, we must ensure that our future economy will continue to generate good jobs for our graduate job seekers."

Pointing to the potential danger of producing too many graduates, he said: "We will need to watch this development carefully and help Singaporeans make informed educational choices."

The acting minister also reported that the foreign manpower tightening measures introduced over the past years are starting to "bite", with foreign employment growth at its lowest in five years. He noted that a number of the measures will kick in fully this year and in 2015

But he said there's still some way to go in reducing Singapore's overall dependence on foreign workers. Meanwhile, the government is doing more to raise the quality of the foreign workers in Singapore.

"The measures that we have announced in the Budget this year signal our move to raise the quality of our foreign workforce and by extension, productivity," he said.

The government has unveiled a new market-based skills recognition framework for the construction sector to encourage firms to retain experienced basic-skilled R2 Work Permit holders for a longer period and on higher pay. "With this, companies can upgrade their R2 workers to 'Higher Skilled', or R1 status, and will not have to bear the higher foreign worker levies that we announced in Budget 2014."

Ho Bee buys 2nd London realty for £171m

Subsidiary signs sale and purchase agreement to buy a prime Grade A office investment at 1 St Martin's Le Grand

Published

Fri, Mar 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

AT a time when the Singapore property market is languishing, property group Ho Bee Land continues its overseas foray, buying its second property in London for £171 million (S$362.5 million).

Yesterday, Ho Bee said that its subsidiary, HB Le Grand, has entered into a sale and purchase agreement with Nomura Properties to buy a prime Grade A office investment at 1 St Martin's Le Grand.

Originally constructed in the late 19th century, the property once served as the General Post Office of London. The building was redeveloped behind its original Portland stone facade in the late 1980s by Nomura. It now comprises 276,792 square feet of Grade A office arranged over basement, ground and nine upper floors.

At £171 million, the purchase price translates to about £618 per square foot and reflects a net yield of 5.5 per cent with total annual rentals of more than £9.9 million.

Its tenants comprise Mitsui & Co Europe, Pyramis Global Advisors, Julius Baer International, SS&C Technologies and Nomura International. The average lease before the break options and lease expires are 8 years and 12 years, respectively.

Chairman and chief executive officer of Ho Bee Land Chua Thian Poh said: "The acquisition is part and parcel of the group's continuing diversification overseas in times when the local market is facing very strong headwinds with limited investment opportunities."

Mr Chua said the acquisition, Ho Bee's second in less than a year, reflects the group's confidence in the London office market.

A 5 per cent cash deposit has been paid and the balance will be payable in cash on completion which is scheduled on March 28.

In May 2013, Ho Bee Land acquired Rose Court in London for £67.2 million. The 157,406 sq ft office block overlooking the Thames on the Southbank is expected to be redeveloped as a £250 million residential scheme.

Analysts like Ho Bee's move to increase exposure to investment properties given the slowdown in high-end residential development sales in Singapore which is reeling from the government's property cooling measures.

"The earnings contributions from its overseas developments including China and Australia should come through from FY15 onwards," said an analyst.

Last month, Ho Bee posted a net profit of $592 million for FY13, up from $187 million a year ago. Its bottom line got a major boost from the $490 million revaluation gains from the newly completed office development at The Metropolis at One-North. Turnover for FY2013 fell 70 per cent to about $139 million.

"Twin engines from rental income from The Metropolis and Rose Court, London, will underpin earnings in 2014/15 while development property income from Australia and China will drive earnings growth in 2015/16," UOB KayHian said after the results.

The local brokerage has a buy call on Ho Bee with a raised target price of $2.68 a share from $2.45 previously.

Compared to some of its peers, Ho Bee has a relatively low gearing of about 15 per cent.

"On a look-through basis, we estimate a net gearing of 20-30 per cent in FY14-16, leaving room for acquisitions. We hope to see more accretive acquisitions in the office space to strengthen Ho Bee's foothold as an office landlord," CIMB said.

Ho Bee ended three cents lower at $2.12 yesterday.

site_title: Luxola plays variety card in regional e-commerce game
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Luxola plays variety card in regional e-commerce game

Published

Sun, Mar 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE-BASED online cosmetics store Luxola has dramatically increased the number of items it carries, on its march to dominate the e-commerce game in South-east Asia.

The store, which is purely online and has no brick-and-mortar outlet, is slightly over a year old and is seeing revenue pick up at a much faster rate as a result of this strategy, said CEO and founder, Alexis Horowitz-Burdick.

Luxola ships to users in Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Brunei and the United Arab Emirates.

Ms Horowitz-Burdick told BT in an interview that it took Luxola 520 days to get to its first million in revenue, but the most recent million was made in just 42 days.

She is expecting to hit $100 million a year by end-2016.

She said online buying has finally risen above its image of being a cheap marketplace compared with physical stores.

"We are a full-priced player. Our value proposition hasn't been about offering discounts. We're not trying to be the cheapest," she said.

Instead, the increasingly savvy female buyer in the region is hungry for a wider variety of products, thanks to a growing middle class being exposed to foreign stores online.

"More women now know that the 12 prestige brands that they keep seeing on Orchard Road are not the only ones out there," she said.

Shoppers in Singapore, in particular, tend to conduct extensive research into the products they buy. This leads them to Western stores because shoppers are wary of counterfeit goods on some Asian sites, and Western stores are willing to ship to Singapore, she said. "That opportunity is leaving Singapore stores and going to US or UK-based sites because of availability."

With this, the company increased the spread of unique items in its inventory from 400 to 2,500 now, and this will hit 5,000 by the end of the year. It also acquired a fleet of delivery vans and built a logistics platform to run them, in order to provide same-day delivery in Singapore, giving it an edge over foreign sites, which have to rely on expensive third-party logistics providers here.

Luxola also has a feature that predicts what users might want, and pushes them subscription options to keep them coming back. If the system detects a repeat purchase at a regular interval, it will flag the item to the shopper and ask if they would like to be billed on a recurring basis for it.

Thanks to these strategies, the average basket size has grown from about $55 to $78 over the past year.

Luxola is running on the US$2 million in funding it won from Japanese investor Gree Ventures in March last year. It's in the middle of raising a much larger round.

The company has not broken even yet, but Ms Horowitz-Burdick intends to use its next round of funding to expand more aggressively in its primary markets of Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia.

The company has 30 people in Singapore and 12 in Jakarta, and this year will see it setting up and staffing new offices in Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines.

One costly portion of its overheads is logistics, an area of major investment for Luxola in order to beat its Western counterparts in the region.

She pointed out that even in a small market like Singapore, same-day delivery is too costly or unreliable when entrusted to third-party providers. Growing its own fleet and ensuring more robust deliveries in the region will provide a significant advantage for Luxola, she said.

"We're not trying to be a logistics company," she added. "If (third party players) beef up their services, I certainly hope we can offload the function eventually."

Till then, the company is pegging its expansion plans on projected growth. It has grown about 40 per cent month-on-month so far, and Ms Horowitz-Burdick said her plans are based on expectations of that momentum carrying on for "the next couple of years before we even come close to slowing down".

Luxola was initially launched on a seed round of $740,000 from Wavemaker Labs and the National Research Foundation (NRF). It had an initial angel round of $525,000 before that.

Ms Horowitz-Burdick came to Singapore from Washington, DC, about seven years ago, and set up a group buying site here called The Sweet Spot, which was later acquired by JigoCity in 2011.

site_title: Govt looking into extending re-employment age to 67
content:
Govt looking into extending re-employment age to 67

Published

Fri, Mar 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE government is looking into extending the re-employment age from the current 65 to 67, but is unlikely to act on it soon.

Senior Minister of State for Manpower Amy Khor told Parliament that the Tripartite Committee on Employability of Older Workers has said that, with the Re-Employment Act having been in effect only two years, the government should allow time for its impact to be monitored before making further moves.

The Retirement and Re-Employment Act, which took effect in 2012, requires employers - with certain exceptions - to offer re-employment to workers when they reach the retirement age of 62.

The Tripartite Committee on Employability of Older Workers will meanwhile review and iron out outstanding implementation issues and update the law and the guidelines on re-employment of older workers.

"We will announce the proposals, including the appropriate time frame for raising the re-employment age, when these are ready," Dr Khor said during the Committee of Supply debate on Manpower.

She said progress on re-employment has been smooth.

Preliminary findings indicate that 99 per cent of private-sector workers who turned 62 in the year ending June 2013 were offered re-employment; 67 per cent of them were re-hired on their existing contracts, with no change to their employment terms, she noted. "So far, the statistics have been encouraging. Among those re-employed in the same job in the private sector, 96 per cent did not experience a basic wage cut," she added.

IT is a true saying that the British love to talk about the weather. So, there are many sore throats here these days. For most of Britain, the weather for the last three months has been diabolical. Storm after storm and floods all over the place. Total rainfall has been the highest ever (well since they started measuring it, but then that is around 250 years ago).

Part of the country, not too far from here, has been under water since Christmas. Since we are having our roof rethatched, we have been looking for scaffolders and one of those we tried has all his scaffolding used in setting up walkways from village to village along roads that are up to six feet (1.8 metres) deep in water. The storms have been so intense that our region (Devon and Cornwall) no longer has main line train access to the rest of the country. One part of the line collapsed into the sea, another remains flooded and the last link was covered by a landslide.

Meanwhile, Singapore is suffering a drought, despite it being the monsoon season.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Big demand for 2.5b yuan China Eastern bond issue

Chaori default has no impact as offshore issuers have good credit profiles: DBS

Published

Fri, Mar 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singpore

DESPITE China's first bond default and yuan volatility, demand was strong for China Eastern Airlines' 2.5 billion yuan (S$516.6 million) bond sale yesterday.

The three-year bonds priced at 4.8 per cent received 4.3 billion yuan of orders, said DBS Bank, one of the book runners.

Asia accounted for 99 per cent of the deal with banks getting 51 per cent of the allocation. Fund managers, private banks, sovereign wealth funds and corporates accounted for 26 per cent, 12 per cent, 8 per cent and 3 per cent, respectively.

Singapore investors would have likely taken a good chunk of the bonds, said Clifford Lee, DBS Bank head of fixed income.

Hong Kong and Singapore would usually account for 60 per cent and 40 per cent of most offshore RMB bond issues, he said. In the past, it would have been a higher 70 per cent for Hong Kong, he said.

Demand for offshore RMB bonds remains strong despite this week's default, possibly the first in China's fixed income market, because the offshore yuan market is very different, said Mr Lee.

Offshore RMB bond issuance is growing at a blistering pace this year. For the first two months of 2014, issuance of offshore RMB bonds have totalled US$6.2 billion, almost three times the US$2.3 billion issued for the same period last year, according to Dealogic.

Chinese maker of solar cells Shanghai Chaori Solar Energy Science & Technology failed to pay the interest on its onshore yuan bonds, due yesterday.

Analysts are warning more Chinese companies will default on their bonds given the enormous amount of debt that has been issued over the past five years. But many say unless it's a default by a financial institution, they are not expecting a crisis.

Total debt of publicly traded non-financial companies in China and Hong Kong has surged to US$1.98 trillion from US$607 billion at the end of 2007, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

"The onshore and offshore markets are very different," said Mr Lee.

Companies which issued offshore yuan bonds generally have better credit profiles, he noted.

"And unless Chaori has truckloads of offshore bonds . . . that's why it hasn't impacted the offshore RMB market," he said.

As for yuan volatility, Mr Lee said the Chinese bond market has developed away from just being a pure currency appreciation play.

The yuan had its fastest monthly loss in 20 years in February as the Chinese authorities weakened the currency though its intentions were unclear.

During February, the yuan, via official intervention, weakened sharply with USD/CNY climbing from 6.0602 to 6.1446 in terms of London closing rates (USD/CNY also hit an intraday high of 6.1808 on Feb 28).

The 1.5 per cent monthly drop in the yuan's value is the largest since China unified its exchange rates in January 1994, noted Cliff Tan, East Asian head of global markets research at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ.

site_title: No plan to extend progressive wage model beyond three sectors
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

No plan to extend progressive wage model beyond three sectors

Published

Fri, Mar 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE Progressive Wage Model (PWM), which is backed by law and dictates a minimum wage, will be confined to the cleaning, security and landscaping sectors, the government said yesterday.

Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Manpower Hawazi Daipi, speaking during the Committee of Supply debate on the Manpower ministry, said: "Beyond cleaning, security and landscaping, there's no plan to legislate the PWM in other sectors.

"Mandating the PWM through government regulations is a very targeted intervention to support rank-and-file workers in sectors which suffer from cheap-sourcing. It is not appropriate for the government to do this for all sectors and for all occupations."

He said that for most other jobs, the government will let the market "determine the sustainable trajectory for wages, taking into account productivity changes over time".

"The government has not shifted from its fundamental position - that raising incomes has to be based, first and foremost, on productivity improvements, to be sustainable in the long-run."

Mr Hawazi's statement on the PWM follows the passing of a law last month which requires cleaning companies to follow it in order to obtain their operating licences.

Among other things, the PWM requires these employers to pay their cleaners a minimum basic wage.

Cleaning firms have up to September to comply with the PWM for all new cleaning contracts. The PWM requirement will apply to all existing contracts by September 2015.

A tripartite cluster has been set up to develop a PWM for the security sector. Mr Hawazi said that when this is ready, the government will apply the PWM requirement to the licensing regime that is already in place in the security sector. A tripartite cluster will also be formed for the landscaping industry.

Mr Hawazi said that eventually, the PWM will be extended to more than 80,000 local low-wage workers.

THE government will raise the income thresholds for student bursaries and raise the bursary amounts to make higher education more accessible to students from lower and middle-income households.

The move, which will cost the state up to $147 million more per year, will allow some 120,000 students - from about two-thirds of households - to benefit from bursaries, starting from academic year 2014. Speaking in parliament yesterday during the Committee of Supply debate on his ministry's budget, Education Minister Heng Swee Keat said that the bursaries come on top of the "very high level of subsidies" that all those enrolled in institutes of higher learning (IHLs) already enjoy.

site_title: Osaka to open Japan's tallest building
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Osaka to open Japan's tallest building

The 60-floor complex is part of the city's bid to lure tourists, stem businesses from moving to Tokyo

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] Japan's tallest building will open today in Osaka, as Asia's third-biggest metropolitan economy aims to lure tourists and stem businesses from moving to Tokyo.

Kintetsu Corp, one of the main rail operators in western Japan, spent 130 billion yen (S$1.6 billion) and four years constructing the 300-meter Abeno Harukas skyscraper, according to the Osaka-based company. It will surpass the 296-meter Landmark Tower in Yokohama, about 32km south of central Tokyo.

The new 60-floor complex, which includes a Marriott International Inc hotel, and a separate proposal for a 500 billion yen casino resort are the latest attempts to bolster the city's economy.

However, rather than tall towers, the metro area of 11 million people may need business zones with fewer regulations, according to Rakuten Securities Economic Research Institute. "The building will be a success, but total demand won't improve," said Masayuki Kubota, chief strategist at the institute. "Osaka should try special economic zones and create new businesses from those zones."

Japan wants to spur growth by easing restrictions in test zones under economic reforms pushed by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The government is considering measures from cutting corporate taxes to loosening building restrictions in the zones.

Osaka, once Japan's capital, is the birthplace of the country's biggest brokerage, Nomura Holdings Inc, and Nippon Life Insurance Co, the largest non-government life insurer.

The 634-meter Tokyo Skytree broadcasting tower is the world's tallest tower, defined as a structure where less than half the total height is usable floor space, according to Guinness World Records. The world's tallest building is the 828-meter Burj Khalifa in Dubai, according to the Chicago-based Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat.

Population growth in the Osaka area has stalled in recent years. The Osaka-Kobe metropolitan area's population is forecast to be 11.3 million next year, the same as in 2005, sliding four places to rank as the world's 19th largest megacity as it's overtaken by Beijing, Manila, Cairo and Lagos, in Nigeria, according to data compiled by the United Nations.

Tokyo's metropolitan population is predicted to rise to 35.5 million, retaining its spot as the world's largest megacity, according to the UN.

The Osaka-Kobe area is still Asia's third-biggest metropolitan economy, with a gross domestic product of US$655 billion, according to figures compiled by the Brookings Institution in 2012. That's larger than the GDP of Switzerland, according to World Bank statistics.

Tokyo is the biggest Asian metro economy at US$1.52 trillion and Seoul-Incheon is second at US$774 billion, according to Brookings.

Tokyo's dominance has contributed to office vacancies in Osaka as companies are drawn to the capital. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc, the nation's largest bank; No 2, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group Inc, and Resona Holdings Inc all moved banking unit headquarters to Tokyo in the past decade after mergers and reorganisations. Nomura relocated its head office to the capital in 1946.

Nippon Life is still based in Osaka, as are Panasonic Corp and Sharp Corp.

"Tokyo is the headquarters centre for an overwhelming number of companies," said Daita Obata, an Osaka- based assistant manager at real estate brokerage Miki Shoji Corp.

Office vacancies in Osaka's business districts were 9.45 per cent in February, the third-worst of seven major Japanese cities measured by Miki Shoji. Tokyo had the lowest rate at 7.01 per cent, according to the Tokyo-based company's latest report.

"Abeno Harukas has almost completely filled its offices," Mr Obata said. "However, most of the occupants are coming from the areas around Osaka. It's not having a big impact."

Sharp will move some of its sales staff to the new building, said Miyuki Nakayama, a spokeswoman for the electronics maker.

Japan's dependence on commuting by trains in major cities has ensured profits for rail operators, allowing them to finance large-scale infrastructure projects and enabling Kintetsu to build Abeno Harukas.

Tobu Railway Co completed the Tokyo Skytree in 2012, financing the project itself. Last year, a new shopping and office complex opened in the north of Osaka next to West Japan Railway Co's main station, featuring four towers ranging from 33 to 48 stories and 557,000 sq meters of space.

Osaka's newest tower takes its name from Abeno, the area where it's located, and Harukas, an old Japanese expression that means "to brighten or clear up", according to its website. The building's exterior design was overseen by Cesar Pelli of Pelli Clarke Pelli architects in New Haven, Connecticut, who also designed the Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur.

"It will be the first building in Osaka to be bathed each morning in the light of the rising sun," Kintetsu says on its website. "Visitors to the top floor will be treated to spectacular views seen nowhere else."

Osaka officials are in talks with Caesars Entertainment Corp, Genting Singapore and MGM Resorts International to build a gambling complex on reclaimed land in the city's bay, Osaka Prefecture governor Ichiro Matsui said in January.

The area is also lobbying to become one of the nation's designated special economic zones, Jiji reported, citing Shosuke Mori, chairman of the Kansai Economic Federation.

There will be a maximum of five zones in Japan, said Tatsuo Hatta, a member of the government council on the zones. Tokyo may make a decision on the locations this month, Mr Abe said earlier this year.

"Osaka used to be the commercial city and Tokyo used to be the government city," said Mr Kubota at the Rakuten Securities Economic Research Institute. "As Japan's original commercial city, Osaka should free lots of restrictions to spur growth." - Bloomberg

site_title: Behind the veil of stoicism
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Behind the veil of stoicism

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FOR all the rhetoric about the Middle East and its depiction as a volatile region, photographer Rania Matar is one who sees a different picture.

"I have a foot in the West and the other in the Middle East - I am a product of both," says Matar, who was born in Lebanon but is currently based in America. "This means I speak the language, understand the culture and love the people," she adds.

So in reaction to what she often observes in mainstream portrayals of the Middle East, Matar has put together a collection of her previous works to form an exhibition titled Ordinary Lives: Women of the Middle East. This solo photo exhibition will be on display at the Alliance Francaise Societe Generale Gallery this month in celebration of International Women's Day.

"We decided for this exhibition to only use images taken in the Middle East. The common thread is the focus on girls and women, and then the location in a different perspective," says Matar.

Her intention is to showcase these women in the same way as any others from anywhere else in the world - facing the same struggles whether as teenagers or as mothers.

She explains: "There's a universality of being a girl, a young woman, a mother, etc. It didn't matter in some ways where the images were shot, we are all similar in essence. For me, people are the same."

Matar herself is a mother to four kids, and reveals that it was the documentation of their daily lives which got her started in photography and led her away from her profession as an architect.

"I think I found photography at the right time in my life and it seemed that everything I did up to that point converged to make it (literally) click. The events of Sept 11 was when I started working as a photographer, and my being the product of two cultures made me want to tell the story the way I saw it," she elaborates.

One photo Matar highlights is of a wrecking ball knocking down some buildings in the background while a mother smiles at her toddler in the foreground. The artist's juxtaposition of the mother's smile against the ongoing destruction is her way of recognising "how people in Lebanon always end up picking up the pieces and moving forward," she says.

Ultimately, Matar also hopes her exhibition will be a testament to the strength she sees in these women who live in the Middle East, and how they get through everything that happens around them.

"I am humbled by the women who brought safety and stability to their homes and their children, and who just kept going every day with the simple tasks of their daily lives," she adds. "Women seem to bear the brunt of wars and yet are the ones keeping their homes and their children going."

Adding to this conversation is photographer Oh Soon-Hwa, an associate professor at Nanyang Technological University's School of Art, Design and Media. She is curating an upcoming group exhibition titled HER IMAGE, which will be held at The Private Museum later this month, and runs alongside a symposium - Women in Photographs from Asia and Middle East.

According to Dr Oh, the idea for the event first came about when she met a visiting anthropologist - professor Lilia Labidi from the National University of Singapore Middle East Institute (MEI-NUS), and the two discovered a shared interest in photography and women despite the difference in heritage.

HER IMAGE aims to explore three main themes - Women, memory and history; Women in daily life; and Women artists and photo-journalists - in a mixture of photography and videography works.

"Photography has traditionally been known for its capacity to capture the reality, the truth," says Dr Oh. "So we also wanted to cover different aspects of women in photography in Asia and the Middle East... and intrigue the audience regarding certain matters, without providing all the answers."

One of the artists for HER IMAGE is local photographer Jesvin Yeo, whose works are in line with the "Women in daily life" theme. She shot most of her displayed works while travelling in places such as Beijing, Tokyo and Malaysia while documenting the lives of women working "under the sun and on the street".

Yeo explains that her works intend to raise questions about the "discrepancies between the ideal role of women and the reality of the modern world". She adds: "I want to ask questions like "Can a woman actually accept this as her ideal role?" or "Can a normal woman really be who she wants to be?"

Ordinary Lives: Women of the Middle East runs from March 10 to March 29 at the Societe Generale Gallery at Alliance Francaise de Singapour. Opening hours are from 11am to 7pm on weekdays, and 11am to 5pm on Sat. Closed on Sun and public holidays. Admission is free. Log on to

www.alliancefrancaise.org.sg

for more information.

HER IMAGE runs at The Private Museum at 51 Waterloo Street from March 28 to May 25. Opening hours are from 10am to 7pm on weekdays and 11am to 5pm on weekends. Admission is free. Log on to

www.theprivatemuseum.org

for more information

TO understand thatthe foot has 33 joints to enable it to adapt to any kind of terrain and not just flat ground, is to realise that perhaps it shouldn't be bound in a stiff shoe.

Beauty in diversity

Heritage colonial cities, volcanoes you can walk up, pristine rainforest and the Galapagos - a trip to Ecuador is quite an adventure. By Geoffrey Eu

Listen to this article

Published Fri, Mar 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT sits in a small corner in northern South America, 20,000km and multiple time zones away on the other side of the world, but Ecuador has a few things in common with Singapore, not least of which are a tropical climate (at sea level, anyway) and yes, the Equator, that imaginary line at latitude 0 degrees running around the centre of the planet.

In theory, it would be possible to dig a hole from Singapore through the earth's core and end up in Ecuador - although flying there would be a lot faster. Singapore's location just north of the Equator also means that unlike Ecuador, it isn't able to build tourist sites featuring Equator museums and monuments with lines on the ground marking the centre of the world. Instead, we will have to make do with the Merlion.

A trip to South America requires commitment and ideally a sense of adventure on the part of the traveller. While Ecuador probably isn't going to be the first country on the continent you visit, perhaps it ought to be. For a country that is roughly the size of New Zealand and home to about 14 million people, the sheer diversity on offer is impressive (admittedly the food isn't world class yet but it's improving all the time).

site_title: Blend of farce and tragedy
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Blend of farce and tragedy

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

JAMES McAvoy's unbridled performance as a scheming, fast-spiralling out-of-control cop is what keeps us interested in Filth, a darkly humorous and deeply disquieting exploration of the descent of a man. That - coupled with copious amounts of over-the-top sex, drug use and violent behaviour that would normally be associated with someone from the dregs of society rather than a trusted officer of the law - makes Filth an intoxicating and yes, dirty blend of farce and tragedy.

McAvoy's character in the film is depraved, divisive and devoid of morals. It's also quite possible that he's completely insane.

Detective Sergeant Bruce Robertson (McAvoy) of the Edinburgh Constabulary is a man perpetually high on cocaine and alcohol and wrestling with inner demons. This nasty boy is in competition with his colleagues on the force for a promotion so when he's put in charge of a murder investigation, he goes all out to destroy their chances while enhancing his own.

When it comes to crooked cops of the cinema, Robertson is a blood brother to the likes of the characters played by Harvey Keitel in Bad Lieutenant (1992) and Denzel Washington in Training Day (2001).

Filth is difficult to watch at times - and not just because of the thick Scottish accents. The film, written and directed by Jon S Baird, is an adaptation of the 1998 book by Irvine Welsh, whose earlier novel Trainspotting was the source of a celebrated film about Scottish lowlives.

Robertson is a repulsive sort who somehow manages to appeal to weak-willed women who have suffered a loss of some sort, but roguish charm doesn't begin to describe him.

Instead, he offends colleagues and destroys friendships with misanthropic ardour, insinuating that one of his fellow officers is a closet gay while cruelly mocking another's unfortunate, um, shortcomings.

It's all a game to him, and he's the one who makes up the rules. Bearing the brunt of his bullying abuse is Clifford Blades (Eddie Marsan), a mild-mannered accountant and his bored wife Bunty (Shirley Henderson), who is the target of a series of crudely relentless prank calls.

The only person immune to Robertson's poisonous barbs is the primly efficient Amanda Drummond (Imogen Poots), another contender for the vacant detective inspector post. By way of explaining Robertson's sociopathic behaviour, we're fed intermittent scenes of his wife (Shauna Macdonald) prancing around in lacy underwear, along with dream-like sessions with his psychiatrist (Jim Broadbent), who dispenses plus-sized medication.

Robertson is also haunted by hallucinations of people in grotesque animal masks and images of a sad, soot-covered young boy.

The train wreck, when it finally comes, is a bit of a disappointment after the adrenaline-fuelled ride leading up to it.

There are moments when Filth is in danger of losing control but McAvoy's wildly exuberant performance pulls the movie through. His Bruce Robertson is by turns pathetic, manipulative and execrable - here's to him and other memorable movie creeps.

Rating:

C+

ANA bond sale raises higher-than-expected 30b yen

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] ANA Holdings Inc's victory over rival Japan Airlines Co in bidding for international flight slots from downtown Tokyo helped the nation's largest carrier triple the size of its first bond sale in two years.

Demand for the 10-year bond offering on Feb 28 exceeded expectations, helping the company raise 30 billion yen (S$367.5 million) at a record-low yield of 1.22 per cent, versus the originally planned issuance of 10 billion yen, ANA's spokesman Hideya Oishi said.

That compares with a 1.46 per cent average for similar-maturity debt sold by Japanese corporate borrowers, while companies worldwide pay 4.7 per cent, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch index data.

The carrier forecasts profit will double next fiscal year as it adds flights to London, Paris, Vancouver and other overseas destinations from Tokyo's Haneda airport this month.

ANA won more than double the number of new international slot pairs as JAL from Asia's second-largest air hub, helping make up for tax breaks for the rival which emerged from bankruptcy in March 2011.

Prime Minister Shinzo Abe earlier this week said that the government's aid for JAL won't damage industry competition.

"ANA is expanding international flights at Haneda, which is going to help profits," said Yusuke Ueda, a Tokyo-based credit analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lynch. "They have exceptionally good cash flow and are close with the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. That makes their bonds good to buy."

The Tokyo-based airline will get 11 new daytime take-off and landing slots from Haneda at the end of March, compared with five for Japan Airlines, the Transport Ministry said in October.

JAL protested against the decision but was unable to win more. ANA, seeking to ease its dependence on domestic operations, is also expanding its fleet of Boeing's more fuel-efficient 787 planes for international routes.

ANA cited the Haneda flights in targeting 60 billion yen of net income in the year to March 2017, from 30 billion yen next fiscal year and 15 billion yen in the current period, according to the company's mid-term business plan released on Feb 14.

It forecasts operating margin will increase to 7 per cent from 3.8 per cent as the airline reduces costs by 50 billion yen, adding to 86 billion yen in savings over the past four years.

"The company has entered a cycle where high level investments into business growth can be compatible with maintaining fiscal health," Kazuma Ogino, a credit analyst at Nomura Securities, wrote in a report dated Feb 20. "Concerns about its financial standing are on the decline."

Tokyo's Haneda airport restarted intercontinental flights three years ago after opening a new international terminal. The country moved overseas flights to Narita, 70 kilometres east of Japan's capital, more than three decades earlier to cut down on overcrowding.

The cost to insure the debt of ANA has retreated 22 basis points in the past month to 157 yesterday, according to data provider CMA. That compared with the 8.5 basis-point decline for the Markit iTraxx Japan index, while the gauge for North American companies slid 10.5 in the period.

Japan Airlines, the nation's second-largest carrier, emerged from bankruptcy after cutting about a third of its staff, grounding 103 planes and reducing its flight network.

Its monopoly on flights out of Japan ended in 1986, when a crash that claimed 520 lives prompted the government to grant ANA its international licence.

JAL received 35 billion yen of tax relief in its first full year after exiting bankruptcy and may not have to pay corporate levies until 2020, according to the Liberal Democratic Party.

The government is considering tightening restrictions on corporate-tax breaks on losses and shortening the number of years they apply, the Nikkei newspaper reported on Feb 4. - Bloomberg

site_title: BlackRock unmoved by China bond default
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

BlackRock unmoved by China bond default

It says things are reaching a point where reform has to happen in China

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AS China's first bond default happens today, Andrew Swan, a top-ranked BlackRock fund manager in Asia-Pacific, remains unperturbed.

"This year could be the bottom for Asian equity markets, with low ownership, expectations, valuations and risk appetite," he told The Business Times yesterday.

"Things are reaching a point where reform has to happen in China. This year is different because exports are picking up and global growth is better," said Mr Swan, BlackRock's head of Asian fundamental equity, who is in Singapore for client meetings.

In China and elsewhere, he is buying "value" stocks - notably stocks trading at low price-to-book values that have better management and a story of improving industry dynamics.

He likes "old economy" stocks, which are now seeing slowing supply growth and consolidation after suffering from excess leverage and overcapacity. They include stocks in the industrials, basic materials and energy sectors, he said. By contrast, he is reducing exposure to high-growth "new economy" stocks such as Internet, gaming and renewable energy companies, some of which might not meet lofty earnings expectations, he said.

In China, while its financial sector challenges are very real, "the fact that they are well known gives us some comfort, unlike the US situation when things were unknown and happened overnight".

Mr Swan cautioned that China is "not a one way trade" and there will be volatility in the short term. But he expects there to be a "pretty decent return" at this time next year.

Equity returns come from "changes at the margins" - such as moving from a negative outlook to a slightly less negative or neutral outlook, he said. "As the year progresses that's what we're going to see in Asia," he said.

Key to Asian growth is China, which accounts for a big chunk of demand.

Except for Japan, Asian stocks have underperformed developed market stocks in the past year.

Investors have been pulling money out of China, spooked by slowing gross domestic product (GDP) growth from over 10 per cent a few years ago to 7 plus per cent now.

Today, Chinese maker of solar cells Shanghai Chaori Solar Energy Science and Technology is expected to default on a bond interest payment. Bank of America analysts had called the Chaori default China's "Bear Stearns moment" that will cause a chain reaction and culminate in a Lehman Brothers bankruptcy-like event.

But Mr Swan said a default was to be expected - after all, the bond was rated CCC, or near the bottom of the "junk" range of bond ratings.

On the broader financial and economic system, he said Chinese authorities are very well aware of the issues, and are demonstrating a commitment to reform. This is seen in news from this week's National People's Congress conference, he said. Corporate reforms are happening, such as China allowing more private capital into the state-owned energy sector, for example.

Returns on capital typically improve when more decisions are taken by the private sector, he said. As long as reforms continue, new sources of growth will also emerge in consumption and the services sector, he said.

According to performance tracker Citywire, Mr Swan is ranked fourth in Asia-Pacific ex-Japan on a one-year and three-year basis, for funds registered in Singapore.

He told BT he overweighted value stocks in 2012 and growth stocks in 2013. "Having a flexible approach allowed us to navigate changing times," he said. "This year, growth is still doing well, value is underperforming, but we will get to an inflection point as you see stability due to reform and global growth."

site_title: Gritty clash of classes
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Gritty clash of classes

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AT ONE point, the characters, unable to contain their rage, start to scream and tear at each other with stunning vehemence. It is a sight made all the more nerve-racking because the actors are just metres away from you. That they would lose their balance at any point and crash into you is a real - and thrilling - possibility.

The Necessary Stage's highly charged production of Poor Thing wants to present and dissect that not-so-rare creature called the Ugly Singaporean. The performance space has been reconfigured by set designer Vincent Lim, so that the action takes place right in the centre, with the audience seated or standing around it, as if they were witnessing a circus show or a burning building.

What they're witnessing, in fact, is a car accident. Two cars, a BMW and a Ford, are involved in a fender-bender. The BMW driver is a well-off Chinese man Jevon (played by Joshua Lim) driving home from a party with his drunk Eurasian wife Alisha (Sharda Harrison). The Ford is driven by a working-class Malay woman Sharifah (Siti Khalijah Zainal) who's taking her gay and unemployed Chindian friend Jerome (Dwayne Lau) to his army reservist training.

When Sharifah refuses to pay for the damages to Jevon's car, even though she's clearly at fault for tailgating, the incident escalates into a long and nasty quarrel. Race, class, sexuality and religion become inexhaustible wellsprings of insults and abuse. The upper-crust Jevon and Alisha make derisive comments about Jerome and Sharifah's socio-economic status. Sharifah and Jerome think the system is always rigged in favour of rich people. Everyone, it seems, has a chip or two on the shoulder.

For director Alvin Tan and playwright Haresh Sharma, Poor Thing is another gutsy examination of the so-called fault-lines of Singapore society. Their previous plays like Model Citizens (2010), Gemuk Girls (2008) and Fundamentally Happy (2006) are some of the most sharply-observed and sometimes shocking social dramas ever written and produced in this country.

Poor Thing, however, doesn't belong in the same league. Unlike those of its predecessors, the characters here feel contrived, each standing for various opposing social forces designed to converge and brew the perfect storm. Jerome, for instance, is an unemployed homosexual Chindian, thus embodying three minority categories: economic, sexual and racial.

Sharifah is not just a foul-mouthed minah, she's also going through a bad break-up with her cheating mat boyfriend. Alisha is not just a rich, beautiful and privileged Eurasian, her condescending remarks towards Jerome and Sharifah sound distinctly neo-colonialistic.

I'm not saying that such people don't exist. They do. But I can't say I've ever seen a play by The Necessary Stage where the characterisations felt so unsubtle and the conflict so predetermined. These are moments when the characters look ready to give in and get out of argument, but something gets thrown in to draw out the conflict and repeat the cycle of hatred.

In spite of these quibbles, Poor Thing does triumph in being the first Singaporean play that ambitiously plugs itself into the realm of social media. The audience were told via email the day before to "befriend" Jerome on Facebook.

They were also asked to check their Facebook during the play to see pictures of the incident posted by Jerome in real-time. The audience could type in their comments, which Jerome might read and incorporate into the action of the play.

These added new thematic dimensions - voyeurism, trolling, cyber-bullying and the quickness of online commentators to judge events told from only one perspective - to the play's already bubbling cauldron of discord.

Poor Thing plays at The Necessary Stage's Black Box at Marine Parade Community Building till tomorrow. Tickets are sold out

site_title: Govt to step in if unfair Reit practices arise: Ser Luck
content:
Govt to step in if unfair Reit practices arise: Ser Luck

It's also looking into release of more comprehensive shop rental data later this year

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The government will intervene if it sees evidence of collusion or the abuse of market dominance by any landlord - including real estate investment trusts (Reits), said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Teo Ser Luck yesterday in Parliament.

Speaking during the Committee of Supply debate on the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI), Mr Teo also revealed that the government is looking into publishing more comprehensive shop rental data later this year, in a bid to make rental pricing more transparent.

This, he said, would help businesses make more informed decisions about the rental market.

MTI's statements yesterday came as calls for help with climbing business costs (and in particular, the affordability of business space) have grown louder both in and outside of Parliament in recent months.

Reits - some of which were formed after JTC and HDB divested space to private owners - have been blamed for shorter lease renewals and sharper spikes in rentals.

"We know that it has come up as an issue, many of you have raised it. We will monitor it," said Mr Teo.

At the same time, he noted that "Reits are not necessarily the leading players in the rental space market, because they currently only own about 13 per cent and 16 per cent of retail and industrial rental spaces respectively. Like any other landlord, they have to compete in the rental market to attract tenants and cannot charge excessive rents".

Mr Teo also said that rents for space are likely to moderate in the medium term, as the government has released a "significant amount of land".

Over the next three years, about 145,000 square metres of new shop space will be completed each year. Over the same period, an average of 500,000 square metres of multiple-user factory space will come on-stream each year.

For the former, that represents more than double the average annual demand for such space in the last three years; for the latter, it is just under double.

Entrepreneurship will also receive a boost, since by the end of this year, JTC will open two more blocks to incubate start-ups, as part of a cluster called JTC LaunchPad@one-north.

"It's our answer to Silicon Valley," said Mr Teo.

In response to Inderjit Singh's (Ang Mo Kio) concern that the government's restructuring efforts are taking place too quickly, Trade and Industry Minister Lim Hng Kiang said that the appropriate pace may differ at the macro, sectoral, and firm levels.

"I would argue that if you look at it at the macro level, we're not doing it as fast as we should ... If you look at the way the economy is still growing, and the jobs that are still generating, and the labour force (that is) still growing, one could argue that we're slightly behind the curve," said Mr Lim. He added that on the sectoral and firm levels, the ideal pace would vary among sectors and companies.

"So we prefer the middle path - consistent, steady restructuring," said Mr Lim, who said "we feel that this is the right pace".

Meanwhile, Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Lee Yi Shyan provided more details on the government's plans to assist companies in their internationalisation efforts.

For instance, $25 million has been set aside to enhance International Enterprise (IE) Singapore's programmes to better cater to companies at different stages of growth. This is expected to benefit 200 companies over the next two years.

To help rapidly expanding companies which tend to find securing financing challenging, the government will double the maximum loan quantum under the Internationalisation Finance Scheme from $15 million to $30 million.

In addition to an enhancement in the existing Global Company Partnership initiative, the government will also increase its support for pilot and test-bedding projects - which help companies test out the viability of their products and solutions in new markets - from 50 per cent to up to 70 per cent.

site_title: Winning ways with watercolour
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Winning ways with watercolour

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHILE the usual practice for an artist is to exhibit and sell works at private galleries, one artist has chosen to submit works to international competitions and win a clutch of awards and affirmations rather than ring up sales.

This was one way he could build up his portfolio, reckons Johor-born Lok Kerk Hwang, who isn't totally unrecognised in the local art market - as his work was once shortlisted in the UOB Painting of the Year competition, even though that was back in 1995.

He's finally holding his first solo show now, about 10 years after he first approached Utterly Art's managing partner Pwee Keng Hock about an exhibition.

The 41-year-old has a graphic design business in Singapore and is a graduate of the Nanyang Academy of Fine Art (Nafa). In this show, entitled the Magic of Light, viewers can appreciate his carefully controlled watercolour paintings featuring the texture of surfaces and light on objects such as locks, gates, and rusted metal machines.

The paintings draw your gaze into close up views, styled like photographs, of metal and wood objects, and everyday snapshots of street scenes.

There's that sense of contemporary photography that Lok evokes with his watercolour works. The tight angles pose quite a different approach from the usual expansive and wide-angled views of the streets awash in a mottled patches of colour.

The realistic approach is what he intended right from the start, he says, as he personally doesn't like the "smudge" effect of watercolour paintings. "It's just a style thing. For my works, I use thick Arches paper - 300 gms or 640 gms - so they can absorb the layers of wet, before I paint," he explains.

But he still manages to retain the transparent quality of watercolour, even if he strives for realism - most evident in his portrayal of rust and other temperamental effects of nature on man-made material.

Lok's formal art training was only in high school, as he studied graphic design and not fine arts at Nafa, he explains. While his works were noted as early as in the 1990s, he only painted in his spare time while he worked as a graphic designer.

The highest-priced painting in this exhibition - Symphony of Rust No 2, at $8,000 is a well-regarded one which he has submitted to competitions in 1995, 2000 and 2003. "I take part in competitions worldwide to see how my works are viewed by judges," he explains.

Lok's latest achievement includes being juried into The American Watercolour Society's 2014 exhibition - one of the most prestigious watercolour competitions in the world. He's only the third artist from Singapore to enter this competition after Ong Kim Seng and Ng Woon Lam. He was also one of the five winners in Singapore for the international Winsor & Newton Worldwide Millennium Painting Competition in 2000.

The Magic of Light is on at Utterly Art Exhibition Space, 20B Mosque Street (Level 3) today until Mar 16. View by appointment from Mon-Sat, 2pm - 8pm, and on Sunday from 12pm-5.30pm. Call Pwee Keng Hock at 94872006 for appointments

content:

Weak cargo sector weighs on Asia-Pacific airlines

Their shares drop in Feb while global carriers gain 6%, Iata data shows

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SHARES in Asia Pacific carriers remained weak in February, even as worldwide airline shares increased 6 per cent month-on-month boosted by robust financial performance.

According to data from the International Air Transport Association (Iata), the gain in global airline shares was generally in line with the broader market as the FTSE Global All Cap increased 5 per cent.

Singapore Airlines ended yesterday's trading at S$10.33, up nine cents. During February, the counter hit a low of S$9.44 and a high of S$10.25.

Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific closed yesterday at HK$15.82, up 14 Hong Kong cents, versus a high of HK$15.88 and a low of HK$15.06 in February. Meanwhile, Australia's Qantas was up one Australian cent at A$1.15 yesterday. During the month under review, it rose to A$1.27 and sank to a low of A$1.03.

Data in Iata's Airlines Financial Monitor showed that unlike the North American carriers, which are showing stronger operating profits and post-tax net profits, the performance of Asia Pacific carriers is being weighed down by weakness in the cargo markets.

A sample of 12 Asia Pacific airlines posted an operating profit of US$436 million in Q4 last year, versus US$1.358 billion in the year-ago period, while post-tax net loss was US$130 million, compared to a post-tax net profit of US$1.039 billion previously.

Jet fuel prices remained fairly flat month-on-month in February, averaging around US$125 per barrel, although Iata cautioned that recent developments in the Ukraine could end up impacting crude oil prices.

In an update on fares, Iata highlighted that global fares continue to remain weak, hurt by the Asian region as well as currency fluctuations.

Still, Asia Pacific carriers saw strong growth in passenger traffic (measured in revenue-passenger-kilometres) in January, up 11.2 per cent year-on-year. This outstripped a 10.3 per cent expansion in capacity (measured in available-seat-kilometres), resulting in a passenger load factor of 77.2 per cent.

Globally, passenger traffic rose 8 per cent while capacity expanded by 6.7 per cent, giving rise to a 78.1 per cent load factor.

Jardine Strategic net profit dips on weaker sales

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

JARDINE Strategic Holdings' full-year net profit has fallen 7 per cent on the back of weaker sales.

The conglomerate said that net profit attributable to shareholders of the company - including US$84 million from non-trading items - came to US$1.7 billion for the 12 months ended Dec 31, 2013. This compared with US$1.83 billion for FY2012, which included US$252 million from non-trading items.

The results translated to earnings per share of US$2.79, against FY2012's US$2.97 per share.

Including non-controlling interests, net profit totalled US$3.85 billion.

Revenue was down 1.3 per cent at US$32.7 billion, with mixed performances from its subsidiaries.

Within Jardine Matheson's directly held interests, Jardine Pacific's businesses produced a lower contribution, reflecting some mixed underlying performances. Earnings from Hong Kong Air Cargo Terminals fell following the planned move of a major customer to its own dedicated facility.

Performances by the KFC business in Taiwan and JardineOneSolution were also disappointing, said Jardine Strategic.

But Jardine Motors produced higher profit as its Mercedes-Benz sales activities in mainland China reversed from an earnings decline. Its dealerships in the United Kingdom and Hong Kong also did well.

Hongkong Land reported improved performance from both its commercial property interests and residential developments.
