site_title: No clear leader among cloud vendors
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

No clear leader among cloud vendors

Published

Sun, Mar 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE cloud distribution method for computing services is creating a new battleground for tech vendors, and is overturning the traditional IT vendor market, according to McKinsey & Company partner Abhijit Dubey.

Speaking at the Parallels Global Summit in New Orleans, Mr Dubey said the market is wide open right now, with no clear winner leading in the cloud vendor space.

A variety of company-types distribute cloud services. This ranges from IT vendors such as Microsoft or IBM, to telcos which bundle them with connectivity services, to a new breed of cloud companies which sell directly to end-users.

Traditionally, most companies bought their technology from channel distributors such as systems integrators (SIs). These tech vendors took care of the implementation of their customers' systems, bringing a spread of different tech products and services and promising to help with the cumbersome installation of it all.

However, the process of buying and using software on the cloud has become a lot simpler. Companies can pay with a credit card online and, often, there is no traditional "installation" to speak of, because the software is usable out of the box via a Web browser.

With the ease of buying on the cloud, it's small wonder that more than 50 per cent of cloud purchases for SMBs (small and medium-sized businesses) are made directly to the cloud vendor, said Mr Dubey, quoting findings of a recent McKinsey survey.

SMBs tend to be more "no frills" with their IT, because they have fewer users and customisation needs, so they are more comfortable buying direct from vendors without the need for an SI, he explained.

But IT firms need to re-angle their offerings for the SMB segment, because it represents 40 per cent of the total cloud opportunity, said the consultant. Around 60 per cent of US SMBs have adopted at least one cloud service, and a quarter have more than five services.

Mr Dubey said it is tough getting a return on SMBs because the deal sizes are often smaller than those with large firms, yet acquisition costs remain. "A lot of SMBs don't survive beyond three years either, so vendors can't recoup acquisition costs," he added.

In order to maximise the average revenue per customer, vendors should plot and predict what their customers want, so they can figure out how to graduate them to more services down the road.

He said that, typically, e-mail, backup services and customer relationship management (CRM) are the top three cloud services bought as a first purchase. Basic e-mail service tends to lead to more advanced e-mail features, then unified communications, then infrastructure-as-a-service, he said.

One of McKinsey's customers which sold e-mail services along this track had an average US$5 Arpu (average revenue per user) across 100 users for basic e-mail, and saw this grow to US$11 Arpu at the end of the value chain.

At a panel discussion at the summit, Simon Lee Smith, Telefonica's director of digital SMB, said the telco is focusing on the SMB segment because that is where the growth is.

He, too, acknowledged the challenge of approaching end-users, despite how large Telefonica's brand name is. "We have a lot of connectivity services, but people don't associate us with the cloud yet."

The plan is to take the company's bread-and-butter networking service and bundle it with cloud services when going to market, he said. "Sure, unified communications is a key area. It's a pretty safe first step for telcos to approach the market," he added.

Another telco has found a different angle to approaching the market. AT&T's assistant vice-president of cloud solutions, Jarrod Barnes, said the company is playing up its reputation for security when appealing to customers.

"Data breaches and keeping data secure. That's been important when approaching the medical segment, for example, so doctors know that, when they're sharing confidential information, they're safe. Security is a main hit point for us," he said.

And for Web hosting provider GoDaddy, simplicity is its secret sauce, said CEO Blake Irving.

"Don't underestimate the power of a single click," he said, referring to the company's decision to make hosting buyable within one page.

The company has also applied this to Microsoft Office 365.

Five weeks ago, GoDaddy inked a deal with Microsoft to distribute the latter's Office 365 service. He said that buying direct from Microsoft is an ordeal forcing the user to go through 20 pages of online forms.

"With one-click, we're up to 10,000 sign-ups a week," said Mr Irving.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Loyz buying Thai oil concessions for US$65m

It sees fast returns, positive cashflow from purchase

Published

Mon, Mar 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

UPSTREAM oil and gas group Loyz Energy will be acquiring a 20 per cent stake in three offshore oil-producing concessions in Thailand for US$65 million.

This marks Loyz's first foray into oil-producing concessions, which it reckons will deliver immediate returns and positive cashflows.

Loyz said yesterday that it will pay Carnavon Thailand, a subsidiary of Australia-listed exploration and production company Carnavon Petroleum, US$33 million. The remaining US$32 million will be funded through revenue from the producing wells at the three concessions.

The wells, located in Thailand's Phetchabun Basin, currently produce at a rate of 1,200-1,400 barrels of oil per day (bpd). Loyz said it expected the production rate to rise to 3,000- 5,000 bpd by December this year.

Operator ECO Orient Energy (Thailand) and ECO Orient Resources (Thailand) have also planned for a new drilling programme for 15 wells for the three Thai concessions. To date, three wells have been drilled, and Loyz expects the remaining 12 to be drilled in the next 12 months.

This will increase daily production, and cashflows from the production are expected to fund the entire drilling programme, it said.

"In line with our overall strategy for the group, we will continue to selectively acquire producing assets that will boost our earnings, while maintaining a balanced portfolio of exploration and producing concessions," said Adrian Lee, Loyz's managing director.

Last month, Loyz recorded a net profit of $1.567 million for the second quarter ended Dec 31, 2013, on recognition of deferred drilling revenue from the delivery of three wells in the United States.

Its shares closed 12 per cent lower at 32 cents yesterday.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Effectiveness of PIC scheme under scrutiny

Questions raised on gain sharing with workers, S'pore's value proposition as a high-cost country

Lee U-Wen

Published

Mon, Mar 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] While many MPs welcomed the move to enhance the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme and extend it for another three years, some wanted more insight into the effectiveness of the scheme so far.

Speaking on the first day of the Budget debate yesterday, Patrick Tay (Nee Soon) wondered how many employers have actually given their workers a raise after receiving the PIC from the government.

The scheme was introduced in 2010 and gives tax deductions or cash grants when they invest to boost their productivity.

In his Budget speech last month, Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said the three-year extension of PIC would cost the government $3.6 billion.

He also said that the scheme would be broadened for SMEs making substantial investments, in what he termed as PIC+. The $400,000 cap on the eligible expenditure that firms make will be raised to $600,000 from the 2015 year of assessment.

"I hope that gain sharing can be part of the criteria of PIC and PIC+. I would like to seriously urge employers to share the profits and gains from productivity with their workers," said Mr Tay.

The fact that the PIC scheme will be extended is proof of the government's recognition that restructuring takes time, said Jessica Tan (East Coast).

Some 80,400 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) tapped the PIC in 2011 and 2012, according to figures from the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS).

About three in five PIC claims were for the purchase of automation equipment, while 35 per cent were for the training of employees.

Non-constituency MP Yee Jenn Jong of the opposition Workers' Party pointed out that it is the larger firms that would primarily benefit from the PIC, given that many companies in Singapore are micro-enterprises that may not meet the scheme's qualifying criteria.

Mr Tharman had revealed in his Budget speech that two in three SMEs with turnover of more than $1 million had claimed PIC benefits to date.

Foo Mee Har (West Coast) described it as "disheartening" that productivity in Singapore was flat last year and shrank 2 per cent in 2012.

"We are now nearly five years into the economic restructuring programme with the government having rolled out one scheme after another," she said.

The economic restructuring efforts, she stressed, need to be "intensified urgently", with the government, businesses and workers all playing a role.

Liang Eng Hwa (Holland-Bukit Timah) noted that although productivity remained flat in the last four years, wage increases could be seen as an "early indicator" that things are on the right track.

"After all, the ultimate goal why we restructure our economy and enhance productivity is to seek better wages and better jobs for the low to middle income," he said.

Ms Tan (East Coast) cautioned that Singapore might be unable to justify its reputation as a "high-cost" country if companies here do not increase their productivity and value.

"Will Singapore, then, become uncompetitive? Is Singapore able to take advantage of the growth opportunities both locally and globally?" she asked.

Businesses should look at developing and acquiring intellectual property, design innovation, new ideas and investment in research and development to move up the value chain and to differentiate themselves.

"We need to look at how to simplify the various schemes in these qualifying categories to help SMEs acquire new capabilities and strengthen their operations," she said.

Financial survival for older parents

Saving for retirement should be more important than saving for children's college expenses, reports LEWIS BRAHAM

Listen to this article

Published Sun, Mar 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHEN Barrow Barre quit her job as a pathologist in New Orleans to raise her newborn twins, the 37-year-old told her husband Gregg he'd have to start saving more for their retirement. His response: "Retirement? I'm going to have to work till I'm dead!"

Barrow is part of a wave of parents having children into their mid-40s. In 2005, the year she gave birth, the mean age of mothers at first birth was about 25. In 2012, as birth rates fell to a new low among women in their early 20s, the birth rate for women between the ages of 35 and 39 rose 2 per cent, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The birth rate for women aged 40 to 44 has risen by 2 per cent annually since 2000.

The joy of having children is often accompanied by financial anxiety. The life insurance and estate planning challenges, not to mention competing savings needs, are particularly intense for older parents. Should saving for retirement remain the priority? How much of any wiggle room in the budget should be put towards future college costs, or go to increase life insurance coverage? There are no easy answers. But there are guidelines.

Opening a new Window into Android

Nokia unveils new range of smartphones which run on Google's OS

IT doesn't happen often nowadays but Nokia stole the spotlight from Samsung at last week's annual Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain. While the Korean giant used that global platform to announce its latest flagship phone, the Galaxy S5, the Finnish phone-maker caught the limelight and surprised everyone by unveiling a new family of smartphones which run on Google's Android OS (operating system).

Before trying to wrap one's head around this announcement - Nokia is, after all, the lone ranger keeping the Windows Mobile OS flag flying in the smartphone stakes and is soon to become a part of Microsoft - a couple of points need to be kept in mind.

One is that even though Microsoft's acquisition of Nokia's devices division for US$7.2 billion is a done deal, it has not yet been completed. This means the Finnish company is still an independent entity free to pursue whichever direction it chooses. The other point is that Nokia's X phone line-up uses a "forked" version of the Android OS, one in which Google's services have been booted out. This is very similar to how Amazon took a version of Android and "forked" it for its Kindle tablet line-up.

site_title: Qantas may recover from decline if Canberra relents
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Qantas may recover from decline if Canberra relents

Airline's nosedive offers its CEO best chance to steer it to long-term growth

Published

Sun, Mar 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] Whether through error or circumstance, Qantas Airways Ltd's spectacular fall from grace is giving chief executive Alan Joyce his best chance of steering the airline towards long-term salvation.

Mr Joyce has called on the Australian government to help the national flag carrier in its hour of need. If Canberra is convinced Qantas is in peril, it may have little option but to abandon decades of resistance and provide state aid.

The executive needs little help making a convincing case: Losses from a domestic price war and international competition are piling up; Qantas is now worth only half what it was when Mr Joyce took the helm in 2007; and its credit rating is now junk across the board.

The A$2 billion (S$2.26 billion) cost savings and 5,000 job cuts Mr Joyce announced last week represent the airline's most radical shake-up since it was privatised in 1995.

As yet, Prime Minister Tony Abbott appears unmoved by Mr Joyce's plea for the government to offer a debt guarantee that would lower Qantas's costs.

A change in laws to allow more foreign investment to flow into Qantas, as it has done to rival Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd, is a longer-term proposition.

Yet Qantas still has plenty of cash to keep it afloat pending changes, as well as inevitable disputes with trade unions over cutting 15 per cent of the carrier's workforce.

As Mr Joyce's calls for state support grow louder, so too does criticism of the way he has run the airline. The spotlight on his management has spurred some to call for his resignation.

"The only way for Qantas to get out of this nosedive is for Alan Joyce and the board to resign," said lawmaker Nick Xenophon.

There's no sign of that happening. The Irish-born executive, 47, promoted from Qantas's low-cost Jetstar unit seven years ago, likes to say that the struggling carrier is fighting lavishly funded competitors "with one hand tied behind our back", citing the unfettered foreign funds provided to Virgin Australia and others.

The law authorising Qantas's privatisation contains a provision that foreign investors may not hold more than 49 per cent of the company: Though officially a domestic airline, Virgin Australia is nearly two-thirds owned by non-Australian carriers - Etihad, Singapore Airlines and Air New Zealand - whose investments have provided funds for growth.

Others say Qantas's troubles rest squarely with the airline - and in part with Mr Joyce himself.

Analysts point to what they say are a number of key errors by Mr Joyce, notably the fight to retain Qantas's share of an already crowded domestic market and the failure to get proper lift-off for low-cost subsidiary Jetstar.

"Alan Joyce came from Jetstar, his performance in Jetstar was pretty good, but Jetstar is a cheap airline and the cheap airlines were quite popular during the global financial crisis," said Biyi Cheng, head of Asia Pacific dealing at City Index. "Since he took over the role at Qantas I haven't seen too much improvement for the company structure or commercial plans to improve the revenue."

Mr Joyce has dug in his heels in the Australian market, spending on planes and staff to keep Qantas's domestic market share at 65 per cent or above. That has locked the airline in to a deeply unprofitable price war with Virgin Australia.

Mr Joyce defended that strategy last Thursday after unveiling A$252 million for the six months ended Dec 31.

The domestic arm remained profitable but earnings of just A$57 million were a quarter of the A$218 million it made the previous year.

"We are very clearly protecting our position in the domestic market," he told reporters, noting Qantas's dominance of flight schedules gave it a significant advantage. "It would be remiss of us to weaken that product in any way," he added.

Mr Joyce does have supporters, who credit him with decent stewardship through competitive times in the Asian airline business, the most attractive in the world with passenger numbers growing faster than in any other region.

"I think Joyce has done a solid job," said Geoff Wilson at Wilson Asset Management. "It's a lot easier when you are running a company and things are going forward. I don't necessarily think he's the wrong man for the job."

Still, analysts say, the brand was weakened in an incident in 2011 when Mr Joyce grounded the entire airline in an attempt to win an industrial dispute, stranding passengers and creating headlines around the world.

The incident cost shareholders some A$70 million and allowed Virgin Australia, under the stewardship of Mr Joyce's former rival for the top Qantas job, John Borghetti, to ramp up its business, adding lounges and routes and building up an international alliance network. - Reuters

site_title: Ukraine prepares for war with Russia, mobilises reservists
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Ukraine prepares for war with Russia, mobilises reservists

Published

Sun, Mar 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[KIEV] Ukraine mobilised for war yesterday, after Russian President Vladimir Putin declared that he had the right to invade, creating the biggest confrontation between Moscow and the West since the Cold War. "This is not a threat: this is actually the declaration of war to my country," said Ukraine's Prime Minister Arseny Yatseniuk, head of a pro-Western government that took power when Russian ally Viktor Yanukovych fled last week.

Mr Putin obtained permission from his parliament on Saturday to use military force to protect Russian citizens in Ukraine, spurning Western pleas not intervene.

Russian forces have already bloodlessly seized Crimea - an isolated Black Sea peninsula where Moscow has a naval base. Yesterday, they surrounded several small Ukrainian military outposts there and demanded the Ukrainian troops disarm. Some refused, although no shots were fired.

Ukraine's security council ordered the general staff to immediately put all armed forces on highest alert, the council's secretary Andriy Parubiy announced. The Defence Ministry was ordered to conduct a call-up of reserves - theoretically all men up to 40 in a country with universal male conscription, though Ukraine would struggle to find extra guns or uniforms for significant numbers of them. "If President Putin wants to be the president who started the war between two neighbouring and friendly countries, between Ukraine and Russia, he has reached this target within a few inches. We are on the brink of disaster," Mr Yatseniuk said in televised remarks in English, appealing for Western support.

Ukraine has appealed for help from Nato (North Atlantic Treaty Organization), and directly to Britain and the US, as co-signatories with Moscow to a 1994 accord guaranteeing Ukraine's security after the breakup of the Soviet Union. Nato Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen accused Russia of threatening peace and security in Europe before Nato ambassadors met in Brussels to discuss their next steps. Washington has proposed sending monitors to Ukraine under the flags of the United Nations or Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, bodies where Moscow would have a veto.

US Secretary of State John Kerry bluntly warned Russia yesterday that it risked losing its seat among the prestigious Group of Eight (G-8) nations, as well as economic turmoil, if it fails to pull its forces out of Crimea. Moscow could also face sanctions from its G-8 allies and see American businesses pull out of the country if Mr Putin failed to de-escalate tensions in Ukraine, Mr Kerry said. So far, the Western response has been largely symbolic. Mr Obama and other leaders suspended plans to attend a G-8 summit in Sochi. Some countries recalled ambassadors.

Ukraine's tiny armed forces would be no match against the might of its superpower neighbour. Britain's International Institute of Strategic Studies estimates Kiev has fewer than 130,000 troops under arms, with planes barely ready to fly and few spare parts for a single submarine.

Russia, by contrast, has spent billions under Mr Putin to upgrade and modernise the capabilities of forces that were dilapidated after the breakup of the Soviet Union. Moscow's special units are now seen as equals of the best in the world.

Russia has launched an all-out propaganda campaign yesterday to whip up support for possible military action in Ukraine, as state media and ruling party officials claimed armed marauders were terrorising the ex-Soviet nation. Kremlin-controlled media launched a full-scale operation with footage aimed at discrediting the new Kiev authorities and rousing anger at alleged outrages perpetrated against the Russian-speaking population. - Reuters, AFP

site_title: Bank lending in Feb grows at slower pace for the third month
content:
Bank lending in Feb grows at slower pace for the third month

Construction loans contracted over the month for first time since Jan 2011

Published

Mon, Mar 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Bank lending in Singapore in February grew at a slower clip for the third straight month, with the loan business involving two key industries - construction and finance - registering particular weakness.

Preliminary figures released by the Monetary Authority of Singapore yesterday showed that domestic banking unit (DBU) loans stood at $584 billion in February, up 0.4 per cent from January. This was weaker than the 1.4 per cent month-on-month growth posted in January.

On a year-on-year basis, loan growth stood at 14.6 per cent, which is also poorer than the 16.5 per cent growth seen in January - and is the slowest gain since November 2010, data compiled by The Business Times showed.

The DBU gains refer to net growth, that is, new loans which have been granted after deducting loans which have been paid off. The DBU figures refer to loans denominated in Singapore dollars.

On a month-on-month basis, business loans in February grew 0.5 per cent to $358 billion. This is a much smaller expansion compared with the 2.1 per cent growth in January.

Loans to the building and construction segment - which is the largest component of all business loans - contracted in February over the month for the first time since January 2011, BT data showed.

The 0.2 per cent contraction to $92.4 billion in this segment is in contrast to the 1.4 per cent expansion in January. This also follows two months of expansion since December.

Loans to financial institutions - the next largest loan segment after construction - gained 0.6 per cent to $80.9 billion in February over the month. This is a marked weakness from the 5.8 per cent growth over the month in January.

There was, however, some strength seen in the manufacturing segment, on a loan-growth basis. Loans to manufacturers grew 2.4 per cent over the month to $32.6 billion, a significant lift from the 0.5 per cent growth posted in January.

As for consumer loans, the month-on-month growth was 0.3 per cent to $226 billion. This is a touch lower than the 0.4 per cent growth in January.

Growth in consumer loans is mainly driven by that in property loans, which grew 0.5 per cent to $168 billion. That is the same growth rate posted in January over the month.

The share of housing loans of total bank loans has risen further to 28.8 per cent in February, said Selena Ling, head of treasury research & strategy at OCBC Bank. "Hence, it may be premature to expect any early unwinding of property curbs before we see further stabilisation."

Growth in car loans, on a month-on-month basis, has been in negative territory since September 2012, and contraction in this segment has deepened, following car-loan curbs that were implemented in February last year.

In February, car loans contracted further by 1.9 per cent over the month to $10.3 billion. This compares with a 1.8 per cent contraction in January.

Broadly, the loan to deposit ratio, at 108 per cent in February, "is still on the uptrend and the highest since May 1998", said Ms Ling. Still, this is some distance from the record high in October 1997 of 115.6 per cent, she added.

Published

Mon, Mar 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE value of the Singapore stock market rose month-on-month to close the first quarter at $915.9 billion, with large-caps and the commerce sector leading the way.

The total market capitalisation of Singapore-listed stocks gained 2.3 per cent against February, but was down 3.5 per cent year-on-year. Month-on-month, gainers outnumbered losers 358 to 318. But there were 395 losers to 287 gainers on a year-on-year basis.

The quarter began on a sour note, with January falling in value against December 2013. But the market grew steadily over the next two months, and on a quarter-on-quarter basis total market cap was up 1.8 per cent.

Still, the modest quarterly fortunes were not widely shared, with losers dominating gainers 381 to 317 during the period.

The quarter got some help from four initial public offerings that added about $1.1 billion of market cap at listing.

The commerce sector was the best performer during the quarter, rising 13.8 per cent in value versus December, to $168 billion.

One key mover in that sector was commodities trader Olam International, which is in the middle of a takeover bid by a unit of Singapore investment company Temasek Holdings. Olam's market value is up 44.6 per cent quarter-on-quarter at $5.4 billion.

The worst performing sector is mining and quarries, which is down 17 per cent quarter-on-quarter at $3.4 billion. Upstream oil and gas production and exploration outfit KrisEnergy was the big mover in the sector, shedding 40.6 per cent of its value since December to close at a market cap of $779.4 million as at end-March.

UOB Kay Hian head of research Andrew Chow said the quarter has seen "thematic" rotational flows into laggards rather than fresh flows of funds into the market.

"The banks did see a bit of a selldown ... Jardine was down because of a slowdown in Indonesia but then had a big rebound," Mr Chow said.

"It's mainly rotational plays. The latest is the switch from Olam to Noble ... and we're now seeing some bargain hunting in oversold developers."

The rotational effect could persist for a while as investors digest corporate earnings.

"Earnings visibility is not there yet," Mr Chow said. "People are still trying to get a grip on whether earnings consensus numbers are going to start tracking up or go sideways."

Mr Chow expects plantations to continue to do well, with telcos and some oil services companies appearing attractive. The banks could benefit from any upward revisions to Singapore's economic outlook.

Overall, larger companies performed better than smaller ones during the quarter, with the largest 10 per cent of companies gaining 2.4 per cent in value compared to a 12.7 drop in value for the smallest 10 per cent.

site_title: Will the stock market resume its 2013 run?
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Will the stock market resume its 2013 run?

Despite possible shocks, it helps that profits-expectations gap is narrowing

Published

Sun, Mar 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

US STOCKS went nowhere, fast - for the week, month, the first quarter - but they may not flounder around the flat line for much longer.

After the volcanic rally in the fourth quarter, many traders had braced for a cooling-off period in the market. After all, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had risen more than 12 per cent from its low of 14,776 in early October to its high around 16,588 in December.

That's considerably more than the average annual move in the blue-chip index. Barring a major leap higher today, the Dow may confirm those suspicions. It closed on Friday at 16,323, 1.5 per cent lower than where it finished 2013.

"The market may have been ahead of itself in December," said Oliver Pursche, president of Gary Goldberg Financial Services. Still, Mr Pursche argues that the gap between those high expectations and the improvement in corporate earnings is now narrowing.

Now that bullish traders have had a quarter to "digest gains", they've likely built up an appetite for more stock buying in the second quarter, says Mr Pursche and others.

There are still shocks to absorb: This week, Janet Yellen will speak again, possibly revealing whether she has intentionally or unintentionally changed the central bank's public outlook on interest rates.

There could be more evidence of China's unexpectedly severe slowdown. Indeed, Chinese industrial and economic-growth data has been so weak lately that rumours have spread about a new stimulus package from the government there.

Similarly, a decline in European consumer prices forced the European Central Bank to consider interest rate cuts to stave off the spectre of deflation.

And, of course, the 20th century-style military standoff between great powers continues in and around Ukraine. The US has expressed concern at the preparation of what looks like another invasion force on Ukrainian borders north of the Crimea.

On the bright side, US data should add to the sense of an economy emerging from a barren winter to a fruitful spring. Economists expect a survey of the manufacturing sector to show an increase in activity during March. And Friday's monthly jobs report from the Department of Labor has inspired some of the rosiest forecasts from Wall Street economists in months.

Most anticipate that at least 200,000 new jobs were created during the month, consistent with a healthy labour market. Relatively strong weekly jobless claims reports during March suggested reversals in January and February were temporary and weather-related, said economists at brokerage Nomura Securities in a research note.

Some measures of unemployment, such as the "U6" index - a statistic that Ms Yellen reportedly tracks because it includes part-time workers invisible in the other surveys - remain high.

And some jobs, particularly in manufacturing, will never come back. Traditionally, technological advances start economic booms and provide the impetus for growth in the labour market. Think of inventions such as the steam engine in the 19th century, or of the personal computer in the late 20th century.

One thing that has complicated this recovery is that the great technological advances have been in the field of automation. Robots are learning to make cars, and computers are learning to make advertising. While US corporations are more productive and profitable than ever, they are increasing productivity using machines and algorithms rather than new workers.

For the market to resume its 2013 run, first- quarter earnings reports, which will start to trickle out this week, will have to exceed Wall Street targets. In the sceptical atmosphere of the last three months, many analysts lowered those targets, making it easier for corporations to impress the market now.

"A lot of people are expecting poor earnings and so that's setting us up for positive surprises," said Mr Pursche of Gary Goldberg Financial Services.

Over the last several years, corporate America has learned to eke earnings growth out of cost cuts but that will not be enough to impress investors this time around, according to one strategist.

"We need to see revenue growth," said Quincy Krosby, investment strategist at Prudential Financial.

"The most salient argument (from those who say) 'this market needs to burn off more froth' is that revenue growth is not commensurate with the market valuation," said Ms Krosby.

The long-bubbling debate on high-frequency trading may come to a boiling point this week. Today, Michael Lewis, one of the most respected authors on the subject of finance, will release a new book entitled Flash Boys: A Wall Street Revolt.

Mr Lewis argues that high-frequency traders have essentially rigged the US stock market for their own profit. The expose follows a recent pledge by New York Attorney-General Eric Schneiderman to crack down on the high- speed traders.

Some analysts on Wall Street claim the stock market could be disrupted if high-frequency traders were kicked out. Others blame the near light-speed computer trading for causing the "flash crash" of 2010, the biggest one-day sell-off in recent years.

Bullish traders hope that the return of 2013 ebullience will dominate market talk this week, rather than calls for stockmarket reform in the age of automation.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China Rongsheng suffers another year of losses

Published

Mon, Mar 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[HONG KONG] China Rongsheng Heavy Industries Group, the country's largest private shipbuilder, posted a second straight annual loss yesterday due to shrinking orders and said that it was in talks with 10 Chinese banks about the repayment of loans.

Analysts have said that Rongsheng could be the biggest casualty of a local shipping industry suffering from overcapacity during a global shipping downturn, amid mounting concerns of defaults in China as a credit crunch takes a toll.

Rongsheng said that the group's borrowings included 127 million yuan (S$25.7 million) that was overdue and had not been renewed or repaid. Its total borrowings and finance lease liabilities stood at 22.41 billion yuan, of which 13.71 billion yuan is due within 12 months. "We have signed a framework agreement with over 10 principal banks to establish a debt optimisation syndicate, for the purpose of ensuring our stability of operations and improving our state of liquidity," Rongsheng said in a statement.

The banks include Bank of China, The Export-Import Bank of China and China Minsheng Bank.

China Rongsheng logged a net loss of 8.68 billion yuan for the fiscal year ending December 2013, much bigger than its net loss of 572.6 million yuan a year earlier.

A builder of Vale's large ore carriers, the company asked the government for financial help last July and warned in December that it faced a substantial full-year loss.

China Rongsheng said yesterday that it believed the recession in the shipbuilding market had come to an end, and it planned to focus more on large liquified natural gas carriers thanks to increasing demand for new energy sources.

It also cut the remuneration package of senior and middle management by 30 to 50 per cent from a year earlier. As at the end of December 2013, the company had 4,738 employees, down 28 per cent from the previous year.

Rongsheng said that it had won orders to build 23 vessels worth US$726 million last year, well below its target of US$1.8 billion worth of contracts. - Reuters

site_title: Myanmar opening spurs shipping
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Myanmar opening spurs shipping

Nation is importing basic materials to grow infrastructure

Published

Mon, Mar 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] Coca-Cola Co and Suzuki Motor Corp are among companies pushing demand for transportation of machinery to Myanmar to bottle drinks and make trucks, after the country's five decades of isolation during military rule.

Coca-Cola, which opened a bottling plant in Myanmar last year, plans to invest US$200 million over five years while Suzuki restarted production of trucks last year after leaving the market in 2010. Asahi Group Holdings Ltd, Japan's biggest beermaker, said this month it's forming a venture to start operations there this year.

Because much of the machinery is too big to fit in regular containers, Japan's Mitsui OSK Lines Ltd and other shippers are increasingly using vessels that can handle oversized cargo. Myanmar is importing basic materials to improve infrastructure after the US, Europe and Japan eased sanctions following elections in 2012 in which the country's leading dissident, Aung San Suu Kyi, a political prisoner for 15 years, was elected to Parliament.

Companies are building manufacturing facilities in Myanmar, to take advantage of cheaper labour than in China. The country exports gas, rice and wood and is now importing steel, building materials, machinery and other parts to build factories and infrastructure.

Myanmar is also planning to more than double rice shipments as the country that used to be the world's largest exporter of the grain embraces trade and opens its economy, challenging Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia.

Shipments may increase to 2.5 million metric tonnes in 2014-2015 from an estimated 1.8 million tonnes in the year that started April 1, according to Toe Aung Myint, director general of the department of trade promotion at the Ministry of Commerce. Exports are targeted to increase to 4.8 million tonnes in 2019-2020, he added.

The country, the leading rice exporter from 1961 to 1963, saw exports tumble to as low as 15,000 tonnes in 1997, before bouncing back to be the world's ninth-largest shipper with 690,000 tonnes in 2012.

Mitsui OSK, operator of the world's biggest fleet, predicts transportation of oversized equipment, which it calls Liner Dry Special (LDS), will double this year, after tripling in 2013. The shipping line uses equipment called flat racks, similar to the bottom part of a container, to transport equipment too big to fit inside regular boxes.

"LDS shipment volume for Myanmar is growing rapidly," the shipping line said. The company predicts more demand for infrastructure and building materials and said the "outcome is pretty good so far".

The company is also boosting its cargo service between Myanmar and Singapore this month to a regular weekly service to improve connections in Singapore, it said on March 13.

Myanmar is planning to improve ports and roads to help movement of goods after the Asian Development Bank said transport networks are insufficient to support growing activity. - Bloomberg

US Navy's helicopters cancellation would cost US$250m

Published

[WASHINGTON] The US Navy's plan to cancel an order for 29 MH-60 Sikorsky helicopters under a current five-year agreement would trigger termination fees of at least US$250 million and raise the cost of Army helicopters covered by the same contract, a top US senator said.

Senate Armed Services Committee chairman Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat, criticised the Navy's plan to "break" the multi-year purchase agreement during a hearing on the Navy and Marine Corps budget requests.

The cut in MH-60 helicopters is one of a number of controversial proposals sent by the Navy and other US military services to US lawmakers, who have the ultimate control over the Pentagon budget. Navy officials said deep budget cuts agreed by Congress had forced them to make difficult choices across various portfolios in shaping the fiscal 2015 budget.

Mr Levin dismissed the Navy's claim that scrapping the fiscal 2016 order of helicopters was related to the planned retirement of the USS George Washington aircraft carrier, noting that each carrier had only five MH-60 helicopters on board.

Sikorsky signed an US$8.5 billion contract with the Army and Navy in July 2012 for 653 Black Hawk and Seahawk helicopters through December 2017, a deal that generated significant discounts given the larger order quantities. - Reuters

Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical's earnings drop 12% to 352.3m yuan

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

TRADITIONAL Chinese medicine group Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group Corporation Ltd registered a 12 per cent year-on-year fall in net profit, from 399.9 million yuan (S$69.1 million) to 352.3 million yuan for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2013.

The decrease came mainly from the disposal of a subsidiary, Tianjin Central, and a decrease in share of profits from an associated company, Tianjin Smithkline & French Lab Ltd, compared to the corresponding period in FY2012. Excluding the impact of Tianjin Central and Tianjin Cinorch, operating profit of the group (excluding investment income) increased by 88 million yuan, or 41 per cent compared to the corresponding period in FY2012.

Revenue for FY2013 came in 17 per cent higher at 6.01 billion yuan, as compared to 5.13 billion yuan in the preceding year. Tianjin Zhong Xin said the increase was due to "appropriate allocation of marketing resources, consolidating the sales and sourcing channels and optimising the services to end customers".

The group did not provide a breakdown of its fourth-quarter results.

Earnings per share for FY2013 were 0.48 yuan per share, down from 0.54 yuan per share in FY2012. A final dividend of 0.5 yuan for every 10 shares was declared.

Tianjin Zhong Xin said it expects to face challenges from the increase in costs of raw materials, energy and human resources; it also cited controls over the price of pharmaceutical products by the Chinese government and relatively high financing costs as other challenges.

"The board believes that with the strengthening of its marketing efforts, the company's operating profits will be improved in 2014," said the group in its statement yesterday.

Globally, firms opting for cloud services past 50%

Virtualisation firm Parallels sees pace of change rising as firms 'let go' of the IT backroom, reports VICTORIA HO

Listen to this article

Published Sun, Mar 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SLIGHTLY more than half of businesses globally outsource their IT services to cloud providers, choosing that over the traditional model of building those services in-house, said Parallels CEO Birger Steen.

Speaking to BizIT at the Parallels Summit in New Orleans, Mr Steen said that the industry has finally crossed the halfway mark in terms of users opting for cloud services.

Network software company, Spiceworks, said that over the last 12 months, it saw a 10 per cent shrinkage of companies using on-premise IT, pushing the base of cloud users to 55 per cent.

Deal reached on delayed Panama Canal project

Listen to this article

Published Sun, Mar 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[PANAMA CITY] The Panama Canal and a Spanish-led consortium expanding the major maritime artery have reached a preliminary deal to complete work on a project that has been delayed in a dispute over US$1.6 billion in cost overruns, the canal's administrator said late last week.

The deal foresees the consortium, which is led by Spanish builder Sacyr alongside Italy's Salini Impregilo, finishing work by December 2015.

Limited work on the project resumed last Thursday after a two-week stoppage. The dispute has fanned fears that Panama could lose millions of dollars in shipping tolls.

Charting S'pore's 10-yr infocomm blueprint

Being planned are underground data centres and a nationwide heterogeneous network

Listen to this article

Published Sun, Mar 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] In 2025, Singapore could be largely unrecognisable if plans for the infocomm media (ICM) sector take off. By then, the country could have underground data centres, a revolutionary nationwide heterogeneous network (HetNet) and a thriving equity crowdfunding scene.

These preliminary ideas are outlined in a consultation document released today for public perusal. It will form the basis for a 10-year ICM masterplan that will be published in mid-2015.

Already, some of the proposals are being set in motion, such as HetNet - which allows users to switch seamlessly between different networks and latch onto the best available one.

Tata Chem pulls out of Olam's Gabon project

They end 2011 plan for Indian firm to take 25.1% stake

Listen to this article

Published Sun, Mar 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

OLAM International said on Friday night that Tata Chemicals will no longer be taking a 25.1 per cent equity stake in its fertiliser project in Gabon.

This follows doubt over Olam's ability to divest part of its stake in the capital-intensive project in Western Africa - including doubts cast by Muddy Waters in a report last year.

In its statement to the Singapore Exchange, Olam said that the decision was made because Tata Chemicals has shifted its investment focus away from overseas fertiliser manufacturing, and because of Olam's intention to move to a minority and non-consolidated position in the project. They thus agreed on Friday to terminate a plan announced in 2011 for Tata Chemicals to invest US$290 million for a 25.1 per cent stake.

site_title: BonAppetour's hosts with the mostest
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

BonAppetour's hosts with the mostest

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BonAppetour

www.bonappetour.com

WHO knew that the simple desire for a home-cooked meal could spark a business idea?

For Inez Wihardjo, a final-year engineering student, and fourth-year chemical engineering student, Rinita Vanjre Ravi, that was how BonAppetour, a startup that lets tourists visit the homes of local hosts for a home-cooked meal, came about.

The two NUS undergraduates were in Paris for a holiday two years ago and were in search of a good Christmas dinner. "Thanks to our naivety, we didn't realise that most restaurants were closed on Christmas Day," says Ms Wihardjo, 22. They met with little success and it didn't help that they could hear families enjoying fun-filled Christmas dinners.

It was a light-bulb moment for them when the idea of how tourists such as themselves could visit local families for a meal popped into their heads.

They pitched their idea during Startup Weekend in Milan last February, where startup ideas are thrown up. The idea for BonAppetour was well-received, and the duo decided to make it a reality. Giovanni Casinelli, an Italian computer engineer, is also on the team.

BonAppetour currently has hosts in over 50 cities, from Singapore, to Milan, and even in exotic places such as Sao Paulo and Johannesburg.

Travellers search for hosts in cities that they are visiting and decide on whose home they'd like to visit.

Sometimes, it is more than just sitting down for a meal in the dining room with a local family. Depending on the host, a BonAppetour experience can include a DIY onigiri-making session in Tokyo, a rooftop dining in Rome, or even a seafood-themed dinner coupled with freshwater fishing in Reykjavik, Iceland.

The BonAppetour experience for visitors to Singapore feature dining on pen cai, attending a vegetarian cooking class or tucking into some homemade nasi lemak.

Ms Wihardjo believes that BonAppetour has been well-received because "there is a change in the way people travel. More travellers are going off the beaten path, and BonAppetour allows them to do that", she says.

For hosts, not only do they get to make some money with their culinary skills but they also get to meet and interact with people from all over the world right in their own homes. The host sets a price on the experience.

While there are other similar concepts, Ms Wihardjo says they aim to stand out from the competition "with the quality of the community that we are building".

She explains that hosts are vetted before they are officially part of the BonAppetour community.

Hosts are free to decide on the menu they wish to offer.

"All we want from our home chefs is to be able to offer an authentic home dining experience - be it a signature local delicacy, or a fused creation," says Ms Wihardjo. "Some even go to the extent of engaging the diners by getting them involved in the cooking or they take them grocery shopping so these diners can go back and replicate the dish."

Ms Wihardjo has big plans for BonAppetour, even though there are already hosts in many cities across the world. "We aim to make it big, and to do so, we are currently in the midst of recruiting country managers or ambassadors especially in America and Europe. Hopefully with these extra helping hands, we can invite more home cooks to join our community, build stronger relationships with our existing hosts, and conduct local events to knit the whole community closer together."

site_title: Nadella signals new course with Office for iPad
content:
Nadella signals new course with Office for iPad

Microsoft's new CEO indicates plans to make mobile apps top priority

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

San Francisco

MICROSOFT Corp's new chief executive officer, Satya Nadella, finally unveiled Office for Apple Inc's iPad in a polished debut that set him apart from his energetic predecessor while signalling his plans to make mobile apps the top priority at the world's largest software company.

At a news conference on Thursday, executives demonstrated a new "touch-first" version of Office crafted for the iPad, available for download as a free app, though a subscription is needed to let users create or edit documents rather than just read them. Significantly, they did not demonstrate any software on Windows machines, telegraphing a departure from former chief executive Steve Ballmer's focus on the personal computer operating software and its own devices.

"Their absence speaks volumes," said Daniel Ives, an analyst at FBR Capital Markets. "Nadella's a cloud-centric guy; he's going to focus on what's been successful, and where the future's going. Windows 8 thus far has been extremely underwhelming."

Mr Nadella kicked off the presentation with a fluid, low-key introduction to Microsoft's approach to the new mobile, cloud-centric world of computing, in his first public appearance since taking the helm 52 days ago.

Dressed in a black polo shirt and dark jeans, the 46-year-old computer scientist threw in some geek humour and lines of poetry from TS Eliot, marking a change in style from his energetic predecessor Steve Ballmer. His lack of references to Windows indicated a deeper strategic shift.

Mr Nadella gave no indication of when Microsoft would release "touch-first" versions of Office apps for Windows 8, the latest version of the operating software, which he acknowledged had fallen behind in the mobile era. "The Windows strategy, there's no change, except we want to be known as the innovative company that's coming from behind in some categories," Mr Nadella told reporters in an ad hoc question-and-answer session after the presentation, another sign of new openness at the company.

"If you look at the story of Windows, we lead in some, we have fallen behind in some. We're grounded in that reality," he added. "What we need to be is a challenger there and be able to show what we're capable of doing in these new form factors."

Apart from the absence of any Windows devices, the Surface, one of Mr Ballmer's prized concepts, was conspicuously missing from a show floor at the event that included Google Inc Android tablets from Samsung and Acer as well as the iPad. Mr Nadella did not mention the poor-selling tablet at all in conversations with reporters.

The Office apps are free to download from Apple's app store, but to create new documents, users will need a subscription to Microsoft's existing cloud-based service called Office 365. Microsoft's Office 365 Home Premium, designed for home consumers, costs US$100 a year. For businesses it costs US$60 or more per year, depending on features.

Apple gets its standard 30 per cent cut of new Office 365 Home subscriptions sold through its app store, but no share of existing Office 365 revenue or multiple subscriptions bought by companies. That is analogous to the way Apple treats magazine subscriptions. "Welcome to the #iPad and @AppStore!" Apple chief executive officer Tim Cook tweeted after the announcement. "Thanks #tim-cook, excited to bring the magic of @Office to iPad customers," Mr Nadella tweeted back.

Analysts have estimated that Microsoft could rake in anywhere from US$840 million to US$6.7 billion a year in revenue from iPad-native Office, although some fear it may have moved too late to grab the attention of many.

Easy to use, touch-friendly work apps like Haiku Deck, Quip, Smartsheet and Evernote, not to mention Google Apps, have quickly gained a following among younger users who have never worked with Office applications, or relish the change.

Sources have said an iPad-friendly version of Office - which encompasses such popular applications as Word, Excel and PowerPoint - had been ready for years, but the Redmond, Washington-based company had been reluctant to compromise its signature PC operating system.

However, Microsoft's own efforts to produce a touch-friendly operating system capable of challenging the iPad have floundered, with poor sales of its Surface tablet, and a general lack of interest from third party hardware makers in making tablets running Windows 8. Reuters

site_title: It's Samsung vs Apple in court - again
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

It's Samsung vs Apple in court - again

Published

Sun, Mar 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SAN FRANCISCO] Apple and Samsung are slated to return to federal court in the heart of Silicon Valley today for a new round in their seemingly perpetual patent war.

The case concerns smartphone and tablet patents and is just the latest in a long-running feud between the two tech giants, who are battling for supremacy in a multi-billion-dollar market.

"The parties tried hard to accuse each other's latest and greatest products, but US patent litigation is slow, which is why this 2014 trial will be about 2012 and pre-2012 products," intellectual property analyst Florian Mueller said in a post at website fosspatents.com.

The rivals will face off once again before District Court Judge Lucy Koh in the California city of San Jose. Judge Koh presided over a trial last year that ended with a jury declaring Samsung owed Apple more that a billion dollars in damages for infringing patents with some older model Android-powered devices. The damages award was later trimmed to US$929 million and is being appealed.

If this new trial goes in Apple's favour, it could result in an even bigger award since it involves better-selling Samsung devices built with Google-backed Android software. This time, California-based Apple is taking aim at Samsung's flagship Galaxy line, crafted to challenge the iPhone in the high-performance end of the market. "Both in the United States and globally, Apple and Samsung have established themselves as fierce competitors in the smartphone market and fierce adversaries in the courtroom," Judge Koh said. - AFP

site_title: Asia Fashion comes under pressure
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asia Fashion comes under pressure

Shares fall 15% on subsidiary's involvement in compensation claims; chairman of audit board quits; PwC to review China units

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE share price of Asia Fashion Holdings, a maker of functional knitted fabrics, fell about 15 per cent to 5.3 cents yesterday on news that a subsidiary was the subject of arbitration proceedings for alleged non-fulfilment of obligations in an 86.5 million yuan (S$17.8 million) compensation settlement.

The fall was despite Asia Fashion saying that the settlement amount payable was already provided for in its financial statements.

Year to date, the shares have fallen 34 per cent.

Spooking the stock is the compensation related to a dispute involving the China subsidiary, Fujian Qianfeng Textile Technology Co.

The company also said that it has hired PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP (PwC) to review the cash and bank balances of its key China subsidiaries to enhance corporate governance.

The news came in the wake of the immediate resignation of an independent director who was the chairman of its audit committee for eight months on "differing views with management" and a warning to shareholders by the company's chief executive officer, Lin Daoqin, to trade its shares with caution.

Independent director Ong Kian Guan, 46, resigned the day before, on Thursday. Mr Ong, who joined the board on July 31, 2013, resigned because of "differing views with management as to the handling of matters relating to and resulting from legal claims from customers".

Fujian Qianfeng Textile Technology Co (formerly known as Fuzhou Jimei Dyeing and Weaving Co) has been embroiled in claims - amounting to 461.5 million yuan in settlement agreements - from customers. The eight claimants alleged that the subsidiary delivered faulty textile products with "abnormal colour fading contamination problem", which affected the quality of finished sneakers. Last August, the company entered into the settlement agreements with the claimants, which have since received 300 million yuan in cash compensation last September. The remaining amount (after a 36.9 million yuan discount for early payment) would be deducted from fabric sales over the next five years till July 31, 2018.

But in March this year, Asia Fashion's China subsidiary was served with notices of arbitration by several claimants. The arbitration proceedings were carried out by three arbitrators in the Fuzhou Arbitration Commission. They alleged that Fujian Qianfeng had breached the terms of the settlement agreements by not fulfilling the obligations in the provisions of products, which was intended to set off against 86.50 million yuan otherwise payable to them. On March 13, the arbitrators confirmed that the terms of the settlement agreements were valid and enforceable, and Fujian Qianfeng was required to provide the compensation by providing the products over a period of 60 months.

Asia Fashion said that Mr Ong felt that the company should have hired a reputable Singapore lawyer, with experience in mainland China, to advise on the arbitration notices and related settlement agreements, legality of the arbitration proceeding and implications of the arbitration judgement. Mr Ong also felt that the company should call on Mr Lin's undertakings to provide 100 million yuan financial support.

"The board had since requested its Singapore lawyer to engage a Chinese law firm to review the arbitration proceedings and provide its advice to the board," said an announcement submitted to the SGX by Mr Lin.

"The board had engaged a Chinese lawyer to prepare a deed to incorporate assets of Mr Lin, so that the company can draw on his assets to fulfil his undertaking to the company up to 100 million yuan," the release added.

Asia Fashion has appointed Kwok Wei Woon, 41, to replace Mr Ong.

It said that the settlement amount payable will not result in any material impact on its financial position, and the amount of arbitration fees payable by Fujian Qianfeng is not considered material.

Meanwhile, Asia Fashion has engaged PwC to "perform certain agreed upon procedures with respect to the cash and bank balances" of its key China subsidiaries - Fujian Jiamen Textile Co and Fujian Qianfeng Textile Technology Co - for the nine-month period ended Sept 30, 2013. PwC has not issued its report.

Mr Lin also cautioned: "Pending the reports from PwC and the finalisation of the statutory audit by Foo Kon Tan Grant Thornton LLP, shareholders should exercise caution in trading in the company's shares."

Earlier this month, the company has requested more time to report its financial results for the year ended Dec 31, 2013. It said that the extension was needed as its board would like its auditors to have more time to work with its management to complete and reconcile certain outstanding works, including the compensation to customers which may have a material impact on its financial statements. It also changed its chief financial officer in January after its CFO of 15 months resigned to pursue other career opportunities.

The company had warned in February that it might report a net loss for FY2013 due to the compensation.

For the nine months ended Sept 30, 2013, the company sank deeper into the red with a net loss of 420.07 million yuan from a net loss of 28.72 million yuan a year ago after making a 424.58 million yuan provision for the compensation to customers. As at end-September, its cash and cash equivalents fell to 51.96 million yuan from 375.46 million yuan a year ago.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

More properties up for auction but few sold

Only six of the 132 units in Q1, up from 120 in Q4, snapped up for $17.87m

Published

Thu, Mar 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE number of properties put up for sale via auction is increasing as more sellers are turning to the auction market when they find it hard to move sales in the secondary market.

But selling units in the auction market isn't always quicker as there are cautious buyers staying on the sidelines.

Data from Colliers International showed that a total of 132 properties were put up for sale via auction in the first three months of this year, up from 120 properties in Q4.

Despite the increased supply, only six properties were sold in Q1 for a total of $17.87 million. This is a 76.5 per cent decline from the $76.08 million a year ago, which was bolstered by the sale of four high-value properties.

"The low level of transactions this quarter reiterated the persistent stalemate between buyers and sellers," noted Grace Ng, deputy managing director of Colliers International. "Although sellers are now more willing to negotiate in light of the softer market sentiments, it is a buyers' market now - with many adopting a wait-and-see approach in anticipation of price declines on the back of supply pressures in the near future."

Among the 132 properties put up for auction in the first quarter, 110 were put up by owners who sought to use auctions to indicate their serious intention to sell.

The number of properties put up for mortgagee sale at auctions also rose to 22 - the highest quarterly number since Q4 2010. There was an average of only eight mortgagee listings per quarter last year and an average of six per quarter in 2012.

Colliers is expecting the number of properties put up for mortgagee sales to increase, particularly in the high-end residential and retail segments.

Ms Ng noted that the pool of potential buyers in the resale market has shrunk, making it challenging for owners to dispose of their properties in the secondary market when they default on their mortgage payments.

"This is a different situation from the period between 2011 and 2012, when the buoyant property market was further boosted by a low interest rate and high liquidity environment," she added. "Borrowers who were in default of their loan payments could easily sell their properties in the open market on their own."

Mok Sze Sze, head of auctions and sales at Jones Lang LaSalle (JLL), reckoned that the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) framework, which caps the loan limit at 60 per cent of gross monthly income, has also shrunk the pool of potential buyers for units with higher price tags in the auction market.

This could likely explain why there was no flying of hands or shouting of bids for properties at recent auctions.

Yesterday, only one property went under the hammer at an auction held by JLL - a four-bedroom apartment in Draycott 8 located in the prime District 10 after receiving only one bid at $5 million, or $1,746 per square foot (psf). This represented a $2 million loss for the seller who bought the unit for $7 million in December 2009. The buyer for the 2,863-sq-ft unit was a Chinese national, who declined to be identified but said he was buying the unit to reside in it.

Sales of industrial units are also taking a longer time to be sold. Two factory units at WCEGA Tower at Bukit Batok Cresent, owned by TPPL Pte Ltd, were put up for mortgagee sale yesterday but received no bids.

"Even for non-residential units, we are seeing more end-users rather than investors or those who may consider a dual purpose," Ms Mok said.

Overall, sellers may have to accept more haircuts going forward in order to move their units more quickly, she added.

At the auction held by Colliers on Wednesday, the properties' list was long but only two properties changed hands. One was a 883-sq-ft freehold apartment at The Anchorage along Alexandra Road, which was sold for $1.1 million or $1,246 psf, while the other was a 366-sq-ft shop unit at Peninsula Shopping Centre that was sold for more than $1 million.

Earlier, a strata-titled factory unit at Enterprise Hub in Jurong went under the hammer for $1.21 million, while four adjoining office units at Orchard Shopping Centre in Somerset were collectively sold for $8.55 million.

Ms Ng said she expected the total sale value for the auction property market here to come in at $70-80 million for the whole year, a 13-24 per cent decline from last year.

site_title: A higher Class
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A higher Class

With its styling and safety features, the new Mercedes-Benz C-Class could pass for a mini S-Class. By Samuel Ee

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE good news about the new Mercedes-Benz C-Class is how radically improved it is. The bad news, especially for current owners of this compact sedan, is how ancient their cars now look. The fourth generation of what was once called the baby Benz now looks less utilitarian and more upmarket. Earlier generations have always mirrored the latest S-Class look but this one is the closest rendition, both in terms of styling and innovations.

The new C-Class looks like a downsized version of the flagship limousine. The exterior styling is curvaceous with harmonious proportions but it is the interior that is groundbreaking. Where the old C-Class had a basic cabin, the new car has the same design language as the S-Class. The flowing lines and moulded forms feature more high-end materials with equally high build quality. Witness the fine panel gaps.

Two new features in the cabin stand out. The first is the touchpad in the controller knob's handrest that recognises input using finger gestures. The second is the head-up display, a first not only for the C-Class but for Mercedes-Benz. The reason the brand with the three-pointed star took so long to embrace HUD is that it was waiting for LED technology to evolve in order to produce the perfect virtual image. The result is crystal clear symbols in vibrant colours with superb contrast.

For the new C-Class, Mercedes-Benz focused on three areas - light weight, safety and aerodynamics. The new car is longer and wider with its wheelbase extended by 80 mm to a whopping 2,840 mm. Yet the new entry-level C200 is actually 100 kg lighter at 1,310 kg because the body shell is almost 50 per cent aluminium.

In terms of safety, the new C-Class also benefits from the new S-Class' technological innovations. One of them is Collision Prevention Assist Plus, which is a standard feature that employs autonomous braking at speeds of up to 200 kmh to avoid contact with pedestrians and other cars. But it is in the area of aerodynamics that the new C-Class impresses. Its drag coefficient of 0.24 is the best in its class and greatly helps the C250's coasting ability. Lift off the accelerator pedal and the car continues cruising effortlessly. The C250's two-litre four-cylinder turbocharged petrol engine is mated to the familiar seven-speed 7G-Tronic automatic transmission which has been optimised for faster and smoother gear shifts. The turbo unit sends good low-end torque to the rear wheels but it isn't the quietest power plant around.

Airmatic is optional, making the C-Class the first in its segment to be fitted with air suspension. The continuously variable damping allows for Comfort, Sport or Sport + settings, while the steering feel and engine response can also be separately tweaked. At the media launch in Marseille this week, the C250 was sublime in full Comfort mode. The steering is well-weighted and accurate with very good feedback, while body control is excellent even with the high level of ride comfort. Sport mode actually robs it of sensitivity.

The C250 with a newly developed four-link front suspension (from three links previously) is particularly composed in sweeping curves. Its blend of comfort and handling is admirable, especially for what is essentially an entry-level Merc.

Thanks to its design, quality and efficiency, this new Mercedes-Benz C-Class has moved up to a higher class.

site_title: Japan consumer prices in 9th straight rise
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Japan consumer prices in 9th straight rise

February increase of 1.3% lifts hopes that the economy is keeping deflation away

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Tokyo

CONSUMER prices in Japan maintained their upward trend in February for a ninth consecutive month, buoying hopes that the world's third-largest economy is defying 15 years of deflation, though price increases were driven partly by a rush to buy goods in anticipation of a rise in consumption tax.

Data released yesterday by the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications showed that core consumer prices (excluding volatile food prices) rose 1.3 per cent in February from a year earlier, the same rate as in January.

Next Tuesday is the critical date when the national sales tax is due to rise to 8 per cent from 5 per cent, before being hiked again probably to 10 per cent in 2015. If consumer spending survives that event after a brief interruption, the economy will be on the way to sustainable recovery, analysts say. But some fear that consumption will suffer a more lasting downturn and that progress on ridding the economy of deflation will slow or even reverse as the impact of a pre-tax hike rush to buy and the impact of a weaker yen on energy and other import prices fades away.

In that case, the Bank of Japan (BOJ) could be forced to apply even more monetary stimulus on top of its already implemented massive easing if the central bank is to hit its 2 per cent annual inflation target and if economic recovery is not to go into reverse again.

Much of the rise in consumer prices over the past year has been driven by the higher yen costs of soaring imports of fossil fuels in the wake of the Fukushima nuclear disaster and the subsequent shutdown of nuclear reactors. Lately, however, rising prices of consumer durables have added to inflation pressures.

A last-minute surge in demand in February for electronics items, such as computers, televisions and air-conditioning equipment, in advance of the April 1 tax hike helped push up consumer prices overall, both in January and February.

While contributions of higher energy prices to consumer price inflation lessened in February, "the trend of rising prices in a wide range of items such as durable goods has continued", an Internal Affairs Ministry official was quoted by Kyodo news service as saying yesterday.

Meanwhile, the "core-core" inflation index, which excludes energy and food prices, rose 0.8 per cent in the year to the end of February, the strongest rise in 15 years. Core consumer prices in Tokyo, available a month before the nationwide data, rose one per cent in March from a year earlier.

"We judge that inflation expectations have generally been rising," BOJ governor Haruhiko Kuroda said in a speech last week.

The economy "has been following a path towards achieving the 2 per cent price stability target as expected, and we are halfway there", he noted, adding that "inflation should reach the 2 per cent goal" in fiscal 2015.

Retail sales rose 3.6 per cent year on year in February, figures released yesterday showed.

Household incomes fell in February, however, and data showed that average monthly household spending in that month declined 2.5 per cent in inflation-adjusted terms from a year earlier to 266,610 yen (S$3,300), marking the first decline in six months.

While household demand has been on a rising trend of late, it temporarily declined in February due to the heavy snow, a ministry official told Kyodo.

"We are not seeing any factor which changes the basic trend of spending," the official added, while maintaining the basic official assessment that household spending is "picking up".

The unemployment rate fell to 3.6 per cent in February, the lowest level in more than six years, while the jobs-to-applicants ratio rose slightly to 1.05, indicating that the overall number of available jobs exceeded the total number of job-seekers.
