site_title: Inflation target can be reached: BOJ chief
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Inflation target can be reached: BOJ chief

Published

Wed, Mar 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BANK of Japan (BOJ) governor Haruhiko Kuroda yesterday voiced fresh confidence that the central bank can achieve its 2 per cent annual inflation target, and that a raft of "supply side" reforms planned this year by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government will also nudge the Japanese economy towards its official growth targets.

Mr Kuroda hinted during a Tokyo seminar that in his view, there may be room for the yen to fall further against the dollar, with the BOJ set to maintain super-easy monetary conditions even as the US Federal Reserve continues to "taper" its massive Treasury bond purchases.

Raising inflation expectations in Japan has been an uphill battle requiring shock tactics by the BOJ in order to overcome an entrenched deflationary psychology in the world's third largest economy, he told the seminar organised by Japan's Institute of International Monetary Affairs.

The economy was at the midpoint of the two years specified for achieving the inflation target, said Mr Kuroda, who has just completed his first year in office after a long stint as president of the Asian Development Bank.

"So far, Japan's economy has been following a path toward achieving the 2 per cent price stability target as expected," he said, as he pledged to continue large-scale monetary easing in order for the economy to climb out of longstanding deflation.

He expressed confidence that the Japanese economy could withstand the possible negative impact of a hike in Japan's national consumption tax, which is due to take effect on April 1.

The "virtuous economic cycle" of production, income and spending will not be interrupted by the hike, he declared.

Reversing deflation will not be enough in itself, however, to produce sustainable economic recovery in Japan, he suggested, pointing to the need for the series of supply-side reforms envisaged under the "third arrow" of Mr Abe's "Abenomics" policies.

The Abe government plans to submit 30 Bills to Parliament this year, mandating a series of deregulatory economic policies, which Mr Kuroda suggested should serve to raise Japan's potential growth rate so that expansion can continue even after monetary and fiscal stimuli are eased.

He avoided direct reference to the yen exchange rate, which has tumbled by nearly 20 per cent against the dollar since the BOJ announced its dramatic monetary easing measures a year ago.

Mr Kuroda referred to the yen's movement over the past year not as depreciation, but as a process which has helped reverse previous "excessive appreciation of the yen, if not yet completely".

His comments on the divergence between US and Japan monetary policies also implied possible weakening of the yen.

Japan's economic recovery over the past year has been driven very much by domestic demand, he said; exports showed a weakening trend in the second half of 2013.

But overseas demand, from Asia especially, is expected to pick up in the first half of this year, adding impetus to Japan's recovery, he noted.

Another speaker at the Tokyo seminar, Gao Haihong, a director and professor at the Chinese Academy of Social Science, argued that China's renminbi was now near its "equilibrium" exchange rate against major currencies, as shown by the recent convergence of onshore and offshore exchange rates for the Chinese currency.

site_title: DBS's buy useful but hardly earthshaking
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

DBS's buy useful but hardly earthshaking

Published

Wed, Mar 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DBS Group Holdings' agreement to buy the Asian private banking business of Societe Generale for US$220 million has met with muted responses from the investment community.

The price represents about 1.75 per cent of assets under management (AUM), based on the AUM of Societe Generale Private Banking Asia (SGPB Asia) of US$12.6 billion as at last Dec 31.

Comments from eight analysts were on the whole underwhelming, with expressions such as "small positive", "neutral" and "a useful bolt on". You get the picture.

All were relieved that DBS paid a reasonable price as the deal is not expected to strain the group's capital position or net asset value; neither will it have a significant impact on earnings in the short term.

The contribution to earnings - $50 million profit before tax in year three, according to DBS's chief financial officer - represents chump change or one per cent based on the group's 2013 $5 billion pre-tax profit before allowances.

Gone are the days when acquisitions were meant to ring some bells. For sure, the acquisition, which would boost the private bank AUM of DBS by 23 per cent to $85 billion from the current $69 billion, is a big number, moving the bank further up the league table.

The other point is that it widens the gap with closest rival Bank of Singapore, a unit of OCBC Bank. Back in 2009, when OCBC Bank paid US$1.4 billion for ING Asia Private Bank (with US$16 billion AUM), a substantial premium of 5.8 per cent, its then chief executive was not at all embarrassed that he had overpaid. David Conner defended the premium by calling it a transformational deal as it more than trebled OCBC's private clients AUM to US$23 billion.

Instead of building from scratch, the move gave it a full fledged private bank - extensive products, IT platform, 150 relationship managers (RMs) and more than 5,000 clients - boosting OCBC's vision of making wealth management one of the central planks of its business.

Later renamed Bank of Singapore, AUM has since doubled to US$46 billion last year.

"DBS is already a significant private bank player, so it is much less game-changing; for OCBC, it was a fundamental entry into the business," said Henri Guedeney, partner at AT Kearney Pte Ltd.

It would seem the strategy has delivered for OCBC. Its wealth management income, which includes a big chunk from its insurance unit, has nearly doubled to $1.9 billion last year from $1 billion in 2009. Wealth management in 2013 contributed 29 per cent to group revenue, up from 21 per cent in 2009.

DBS chief executive Piyush Gupta said the SGPB Asia deal will help raise wealth management contribution to 15 per cent of the group's business in three years. Last year, wealth management income of $924 million made up 10.4 per cent of the group's $8.9 billion.

Another reason why it is hard to be impressed with DBS's acquisition is that making money from the wealthy in Asia can be illusionary at times.

Sure, wealth is growing at a faster clip in Asia than anywhere else in the world. But the Asian rich, many of whom are first generation, are demanding. As savvy business people, they are smarter than many of the RMs selling financial products.

An entrepreneur knows that if you lose money, it could lead to bankruptcy, and so has little patience when the fund recommended by the RM is said to be outperforming the benchmark, losing, say, "only" 2 per cent against a 5 per cent fall in the benchmark.

According to a private banking report done by AT Kearney based on interviews with top private bankers and regulators between late 2011 and early 2012, it's a penalising environment.

A high degree of correlation of volatility in markets, low interest rates, the paradigm "risk on, risk off" - it all adds up to a formidable operating environment, making it very difficult for banks to generate sustainable returns, it said.

The industry is further hamstrung by a decline in the number of transactions, an increase in cash holdings and a squeeze on margins.

The impact of the current penalising environment is most evident in Asia, where the private banking industry's cost-income ratio hovers at about 80 per cent, it said. It hasn't become any easier two years on (from when the interviews were done), said Mr Guedeney.

Scale is one of the factors for survival and having another US$12 billion AUM or so is "very useful", he said.

site_title: Toyota distributor Borneo quits motor traders' body
content:
Toyota distributor Borneo quits motor traders' body

Exit raises question of body's relevance since it'll represent just 1/3 of the market

Published

Tue, Mar 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Motor Traders Association could soon be the Minor Traders Association if the number of members keeps falling.

The Motor Traders Association of Singapore (MTA) is a grouping of new car distributors and some commercial vehicle dealers.

Its membership has been sliding over the years and the latest to leave its fold is Borneo Motors Singapore (BMS) - the distributor of Toyota, Lexus and Hino - leaving it with 26 members.

With BMS's exit at the end of this month, Singapore's top three brands - Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Toyota, in that order - will not be part of the MTA. Critics now question how MTA can continue to be relevant.

"MTA is supposed to be the voice of new car sellers. What is the point if it does not represent the majority of the industry," asked the director of a brand who left MTA a few years ago.

Based on last year's total vehicle sales of 34,090 units, MTA members accounted for 46 per cent of total market share (this number is made up of 22,472 new cars, 8,128 commercial vehicles and 3,490 taxis).

If BMS sales are excluded, this proportion drops to 32 per cent, or barely a third of the market. Volkswagen will then be the biggest brand left in MTA. Last year, VW was Singapore's No 4 make.

BMS declined to comment when contacted. But there is speculation that its departure is largely symbolic, one that signals its displeasure with the association.

"The annual membership fee is only $1,500, so it's definitely not about the money," said the head of a luxury dealership. "It is probably to make it clear that they do not see the value of MTA membership."

In recent months, some complaints about the MTA included how it appears to champion the causes of only its committee members, and the inability to present members' views and appeals to the government, especially after the recent radical changes to the motor trade, such as the loan curbs and certificate of entitlement tweaks.

The luxury dealership head recalled that when the vehicle financing restrictions were introduced last year in February, the Singapore Vehicles Traders Association, or SVTA, whose members are mainly used car dealers, immediately met to craft an appeal to the government. The result was the lifting of loan curbs for 60 days to allow members to clear their stocks of second-hand vehicles.

But, according to the luxury dealership head, the MTA was reluctant to intercede when approached by some members for help to lobby the government to soften the impact of the loan curbs.

Senior MTA committee members could not be contacted for their views. But one industry veteran defended the MTA.

"To be fair, it does not have an easy time," he said, explaining that this is because MTA members have conflicting interests.

"It is difficult to function as a cohesive organisation because not every brand is impacted by the same issues, such as engine output or emissions," he added. "So there is no unified voice, unlike used car dealers who do not have brand loyalty and can talk about common problems such as policy and financing as a group."

site_title: SGX's new rule: clarity needed
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SGX's new rule: clarity needed

Published

Mon, Mar 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Singapore Exchange's (SGX) recent attempt to enhance its regulatory might was put to its first major test this past week, when Temasek Holdings made an offer for Olam International. The jury is still out on how effective SGX's new rule is, but the incident has definitely highlighted its practical issues.

The rule in question requires listed companies to notify SGX on a confidential basis if they are in discussions that could lead to a takeover. It was one of several new rules that came into effect on March 3, as part of SGX's attempt to "enhance its regulatory tools in line with international standards".

SGX brandished the new rule on Sunday, in its response to criticisms in the media as to why it, as regulator, failed to query the unusual leap in Olam's share price in the lead-up to the offer announcement.

In what might be seen by some as an attempt to diffuse the attention on SGX, the regulator started off its response by reminding the market that parties to a takeover shared some responsibility, too. It stressed "the responsibilities placed on potential offerors and/or listed companies when they are in confidential discussions that may lead to a potential takeover offer".

It brought up its new March 3 rule, which states that companies are "required to notify SGX where its board is, either aware of discussions or negotiations of a potential proposal, or in discussion or negotiation on an agreement or document which may lead to a takeover, reverse takeover or a very substantial acquisition by the company".

"SGX will keep such notifications confidential", the rule added.

SGX's decision to bring up the rule, as the starting point of its response, is a curious one. For one, it has the undesirable effect of suggesting that such a rule was not followed, and can be considered to be a rather unfair remark to make at this point, given that Temasek and Olam - bound by takeover rules - cannot confirm or deny that they have informed SGX. Market participants are left none the wiser as to what actually happened.

For another, it highlights the practical difficulties of enforcing and of complying with this rule - concerns that surfaced among listed companies when the rule was first announced.

From the listed companies' point of view, there is great uncertainty as to how exactly they are expected to comply; SGX's Practice Note 7.2 (on this matter) gives little guidance beyond what the rule states. Questions which many have - that remain unanswered - include:

Practice Note 7.2 says this is "when the board of an issuer is:

i) made aware of discussions or negotiations on a potential proposal; or (ii) in discussion or negotiation on an agreement or document, whether binding or non-binding".

This encompasses a whole range of stages: when an expression of interest is first made; when a preliminary offer is put on the table; or when an irrevocable agreement has been entered into. A deal can also fall apart at any point, with the greater possibility occurring when discussions are at a very preliminary stage. So, would it be relevant, timely and useful for SGX to be informed at the first instance that the board is, if this occurs at the most preliminary stage, or only when discussions are more definite?

If takeover talks are amicable, should all parties involved inform SGX at the same time, so that one party isn't left looking like it shirked its duty?

What if the takeover attempt is a hostile one? Should the acquirer announce its intentions to SGX before making its move? It is commonly accepted that the element of surprise is a critical one in hostile takeovers, so one wonders how SGX's rule can be practically adhered to in this case - for example, how much in advance should such a notification be made?

SGX's Practice Note - which states that, "where the discussions or negotiations are carried out by a controlling shareholder of the issuer and without the knowledge of the issuer, that controlling shareholder shall (through their advisers or otherwise) notify the Exchange directly if the discussions or negotiations are likely to result in the above transactions (takeover or reverse takeover of issuer, or very substantial acquisition by issuer)" - doesn't quite answer the question.

SGX's Practice Note sets out a simple template of information that needs to be provided in such notifications, including name of issuer, type of transaction, etc. It says notifications should be emailed to

privylist@sgx.com

. It does not, however, say who mans this email account. So, an issuer does not know if it is a junior or senior officer, a small group of people or an entire department, who will have access to this sensitive information or how secure this email account is.

And, should a deal break in the middle of the night, mere hours before an issuer intends to publicly announce it, would sending off an email to this account - when one doesn't know if it is manned at all hours of the day and night - suffice as a proper notification?

The assumed answer to this question is, "very" - as in, every single person who could possibly have knowledge of this deal, including the tea lady who might happen to walk in on discussions in the conference room. If so, it would mean very detailed record-keeping for the entities involved.

These are some of the practical issues listed companies have to wrangle with. What of SGX's enforcement of the rule?

It is unclear, at this stage, how SGX intends to deal with the companies that do not comply with the rule; for example, what are the punitive actions it can/will bring against companies that fail to notify the Exchange?

It is also unclear - based on the aforementioned challenges faced by companies - what exactly constitutes non-compliance. Would non-compliance be notifying a day late, or at the wrong stage, or leaving a name out of the privy list?

It is also unclear how SGX intends to use the information given to it, to improve its monitoring of trading activities. For example, in the event of a seeming information leak, one assumes the Exchange would use the privy list to question everyone who might have knowledge of the deal. Or it might use the notification email to try to determine when such information became known to which set of people.

Its effectiveness, however, would depend very much on the accuracy of the information provided - which SGX might not have a way of verifying.

This is not to say that SGX has been remiss in its duty as a regulator; as with every new rule or legislation, greater clarity and understanding always comes with time - seeing how it is implemented, and through observing test cases.

In this case, the Temasek-Olam deal has served as a reminder of the need for greater clarity on this rule, to enable the market and its regulator to benefit from it.

TTI query, trade caution a regulatory overkill?

Listen to this article

Published Tue, Mar 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT APPEARS that in the wake of last October's penny stock crash and the measures to strengthen the market that have been proposed since, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) may be going into misplaced regulatory overkill. One case that stands out is TT International (TTI) - the company having been queried on Monday about a surge in volume traded of its shares, which was then followed by a "Trade With Caution" warning.

Before going into details, note that when the exchange explained why it did not query Olam International during Olam's six-week-long, 40 per cent share price surge, it said over the weekend that it takes into account several factors when deciding whether price movements are unusual.

"These include macroeconomic factors, market sentiment, specific industry outlook and trends, company financials and company developments and analyst reports. SGX will issue a public query when trading activities cannot be explained by these factors," said the exchange.

site_title: Olam suitor knocks on Temasek's door
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Olam suitor knocks on Temasek's door

Sime Darby said to have sought a place in the consortium

Published

Wed, Mar 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The largest public palm oil producer in the world might still be keen to dip its finger in the Olam pie.

Sime Darby has approached Temasek Holdings for a place in the consortium that made an offer for the shares of Olam International that it does not yet own, sources said.

The group had been holding internal discussions to make an offer for Olam shares prior to Temasek's surprise announcement last Friday, they said.

The Business Times understands that the proposal is unlikely to progress further. Temasek declined to comment.

Sime Darby's head of communications said: "We are open to all opportunities for growth and expansion. I am, however, unaware of any specific interest in Olam."

Analysts had said that they did not expect a competing offer for Olam, given that the offer involves existing shareholders with a large stake, and the complex nature of its business.

The consortium that Temasek leads, which includes Olam's founding firm Kewalram Chanrai and management, already owns 52.5 per cent of the agri-commodities trader.

Sime Darby, a motoring-to-plantation conglomerate, has in recent years looked to grow its land bank, as well as diversify into other crops. The group in 2009 secured a 220,000-hectare concession in Liberia, and has said that it is also evaluating expansion opportunities in other parts of Africa.

Olam is developing a 300,000-hectare palm plantation in Gabon in partnership with the government, and also has a 50:50 joint venture with Wilmar International that holds a 27-per cent stake in Sifca, the largest integrated palm player in West Africa.

While the Sifca investment is already fully contributing, Olam's plantation in Gabon is still gestating, and will require further investments, the firm said during its results briefing last month.

It expects the first yields from the first plantation in Gabon to come next year.

Planting in Gabon is expected to be completed in 2016, Olam had previously said.

Meanwhile, the probability of Olam defaulting on its debt has fallen to an all-time low, according to an analysis by the National University of Singapore Risk Management Institute (RMI).

The RMI's probability of default measure for Olam fell from nearly 50 basis points in December 2012 to 2.76 basis points this month, said analyst Siddharth Batra.

The measures takes into account factors such as the current liabilities and long-term liabilities, among others.

"The probability of default has declined steadily since December 2012, reflecting receding fears on Olam's ability to tide through big acquisitions and its stretched balance sheet," said Mr Batra.

Temasek's offer to buy Olam shares that it does not already own at $2.23 a share, valuing the firm at $5.33 billion, is seen by some to help the agri-commodities trader shore up shareholder support ahead of its bonds which will mature in the coming years.

According to Bloomberg data, Olam has US$2 billion of bonds due between 2016 and 2018.

US short-selling firm Muddy Waters had criticised Olam for its overly high leverage and negative cash flow in November 2012.

Since then, Olam has moderated the pace of its capital expenditure and also undertaken initiatives such as sale and leaseback transactions to release cash from its balance sheet.

The counter closed unchanged at $2.22 yesterday.

With additional reporting by S Jayasankaran

Australia takes lead role in search for missing jet

Malaysia focuses on role of pilots, denies it refused to cooperate with FBI

Published

Mon, Mar 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[KUALA LUMPUR] Australia took a leading role in the search for a passenger jet in the southern Indian Ocean that vanished 10 days ago as Malaysian authorities focused on what role the pilots may have played in the diversion of the aircraft.

Initial investigations indicated that it was the co-pilot who last made contact with air traffic controllers before the plane vanished from radars, Malaysia Airlines chief executive officer Ahmad Jauhari Yahya said yesterday. Malaysian officials also refuted criticism that they had refused to cooperate with the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott discussed the search plan with his Malaysian counterpart Najib Razak, who asked Australia to take responsibility for the southern part of the search zone.

There's no trace of the Boeing 777-200 plane, which vanished on March 8 with 239 people on board, and the area now being searched stretches from Kazakhstan in the north to the two-mile deep waters off Australia in the south.

Malaysia has cooperated with the FBI and the Interpol from the start of the investigation, Acting Transport Minister Hishammuddin Hussein said at the same press conference.

While there have been few breakthroughs, authorities established that the plane operated for almost seven hours after its last contact with air traffic controllers. That led to closer scrutiny of the crew.

Police searched the homes of the pilot and co-pilot on Saturday to help answer why the jet was deliberately flown off its course, racing against time as the trail of isolated signals caught during the journey risks going cold.

The police have been investigating since March 8 all crew members, including the pilot and the co-pilot, as well as all ground staff handling the aircraft. The police also seized a flight simulator from the pilot's house and are studying it.

Malaysian investigators are treating both the northern and southern search zones with equal importance. Yet, US investigators are growing more convinced the most likely last position of MH370 was in a zone about 1,609 kilometres west of Perth, said two people in the US government who are familiar with the data. Mr Najib was told that is the most promising lead, one of the people said.

MAS can't determine when the plane's Aircraft Communications Addressing and Reporting System, which transmits text messages and data to and from planes, was disabled, CEO Ahmad Jauhari said yesterday. The Acars system was disabled just before the jet left Malaysia's east coast and its transponder was switched off near the border between Malaysian and Vietnamese air traffic control, Mr Najib had said at a Saturday briefing.

Data that is available indicated the plane was last spotted in an arc that reached as far as Kazakhstan in the north to an area in the Indian Ocean off Australia in the south. Malaysia is now enlisting the help of 26 nations, Mr Hishammuddin said.

The jet made its last satellite contact at 8:11 am on March 8, according to Mr Najib. Malaysian officials previously said the plane was last tracked by its transponder, a device that helps radar find its location more precisely, at 1:30 am.

Beyond an expanding search area, the investigation has turned toward the pilot Zaharie Ahmad Shah and Fariq Abdul Hamid, the first officer. Mr Fariq, 27, joined the airline in 2007, while Mr Zaharie had worked at the carrier since 1981 and logged 18,365 flying hours.

The deeper probe of the two men by police included interviewing family members.

The longest period in modern aviation history between an airliner's disappearance and initial findings of debris took place seven years ago, when Adam Air Flight 574 disappeared off the coast of Indonesia's South Sulawesi. - Bloomberg

content:
Moody's: Olam bid by Temasek credit negative

Market talk has it that share surge could partly be due to rival suitors

Published

Mon, Mar 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE offer to buy the remaining shares in Olam International is credit negative for Temasek Holdings, though it will have "minimal" financial effect on the investment firm, rating agency Moody's said yesterday.

Meanwhile, there were market murmurs that the surge in Olam's share price prior to the announcement on Friday could have been partly due to interest by other firms in acquiring the agri-commodities trader.

Bringing another company under the Singapore umbrella "negatively pressures portfolio liquidity", said Moody's vice-president Alan Greene in a report. "The high concentration of investment in Singapore-listed companies and the large size of each shareholding reduce portfolio liquidity."

This is in marked contrast to typical sovereign wealth funds that have more broadly spread holdings, which can adjust them quickly without moving markets, he added.

Olam's dividend yield of 2 per cent in 2013 is also "well below" Temasek's overall dividend income yield of about 3 per cent in the year to March 2013, Mr Greene noted.

Temasek Holdings on Friday launched a cash offer for all Olam shares that it does not already own, in a deal that would value the agri-commodities firm at $5.33 billion. The offer price of $2.23 represented a premium of 11.8 per cent over the last traded price before the announcement.

The consortium that a Temasek unit is leading includes Olam's management and its founding firm, and already owns a combined stake of 52.5 per cent.

Temasek said that it intended to keep Olam listed, but kept the option to reassess its position if the minimum public float requirement of 10 per cent was not met.

Mr Greene said that Olam's credit profile is "relatively weak", with gross debt of $9.1 billion and an Ebitda (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation) of $1.2 billion in the 2013 calendar year.

Like other analysts who believed that the deal would benefit Olam in obtaining funding, he said: "Now with Temasek firmly in the picture, Olam will benefit from the financing halo effect, although Temasek does not guarantee the debts of its operating subsidiaries."

The 34.8 per cent surge in Olam's share price in the six weeks after Feb 3 has also led many to question whether there had been a leak in information prior to the announcement. The Singapore Exchange, in a statement on Sunday, noted that there had been a general re-rating of commodities firms Noble Group, Olam and Wilmar International, and that trading in these stocks were within the price ranges set out in research reports.

Besides these, and a good set of results that Olam announced on Feb 14, market talk revealed that there have been at least three separate parties interested in acquiring Olam during the same period, potentially pushing up its share price as well.

Sime Darby, one of the largest palm oil producers in the world, is said to be one of them. Two Japanese trading companies are also said to be interested in Olam due to its exposure to African markets.

This comes as investor interest in agriculture picks up, with more agribusiness companies looking at vertical integration in the area of production to tie up supply, The Business Times earlier reported.

Analysts had said that they did not expect a competing offer for Olam, given that the offer involves existing shareholders with a large stake, and the complex nature of its business.

Olam's shares ended two cents lower at $2.21 yesterday.

site_title: Trade With Caution not intended as a black mark against companies: SGX
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Trade With Caution not intended as a black mark against companies: SGX

Published

Wed, Mar 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Singapore Exchange (SGX) said its new "Trade With Caution" notification is not intended as a black mark against the company on whose shares the notice is issued, but merely an enhancement to the exchange's ongoing public queries.

"Trade With Caution" is a new regulatory tool that the exchange introduced from March 3 after consultation with the Monetary Authority of Singapore to augment its routine queries into odd price or volume movements," said an SGX spokeswoman when contacted by BT yesterday.

"It is a signal to investors to be cautious when trading in that company's stock and serves as a warning that the trading activities in that company's stock could be caused by market forces other than the corporate developments of the company," she said.

"It is also important to note that it is not a black mark against the company but an enhancement to the public query," added the SGX spokeswoman.

She was responding to queries by BT into SGX's handling of a spike up in the shares of Jardine Cycle & Carriage (JC&C).

On Tuesday, when JC&C's shares rose $1.70 or 4 per cent to $43.84, SGX sent a query asking if the company knew of reasons for the rise in the share price.

In its reply yesterday, JC&C's group company secretary Ho Yeng Tat said although it did not know of any information not previously announced which if known might explain the rise, trading "may possibly have been impacted by recent developments in Indonesia" through JC&C's significant investment in PT Astra International.

"It should be noted that the recent news from Indonesia regarding the nomination of Mr Joko Widodo, a popular Indonesian presidential candidate on 14 March 2014, had coincided with a spike in the share price of the company (up 9 per cent compared to the previous day)," said JC&C's Mr Ho.

"An increase in the Jakarta Composite and a similar run-up in the share price can be observed for Astra (up 7 per cent compared to the previous day) on the same day." He also said a stronger rupiah could be a factor.

After JC&C's reply, SGX yesterday issued a Trade With Caution announcement in which it acknowledged JC&C's response, noted that the shares had risen 12.2 per cent between March 14 and 18 and recommended shareholders and potential investors to exercise caution when dealing in JC&C's shares.

"The notice may not be a black mark but it certainly is a red flag," said NUS Associate Professor Mak Yuen Teen. "I think trade with caution alerts can be useful particularly to get more companies to think more carefully about issuing 'no explanation' responses. Just to give you an idea, my student found that 75 per cent of responses to price queries are 'no explanation' responses. If companies know that they will be slapped with a Trade With Caution if they provide no explanation, we may see such 'no explanation' responses reducing."

Other observers welcomed the query as being long overdue. "JC&C is a heavyweight in the Straits Times Index and regularly displays large price movements - up and down - so trading in its shares should be subject to greater scrutiny," said a dealer with a local brokerage.

Another noted that JC&C's shares often move with only very small volume done. "The trades are typically done with metronomic regularity - one lot done, followed by two lots, followed by one lot and so on," he said. "It is a very odd trading pattern."

David Gerald, president of the Securities Investors Association of Singapore, described the JC&C case and the new notification as encouraging developments.

"For too long, investors have been kept in the dark when companies provide boilerplate replies to SGX queries," he said. "Trade With Caution should be taken seriously and sometimes investors need to be told to exercise care. This is a good move."

Veteran market activist Denis Distant also welcomed the move. "It's good that SGX queried JC&C because it shows that it's not just penny stocks that they will go after."

JC&C's shares yesterday fell 63 cents to $43.21 with 217 lots done.

site_title: SGX reiterates regulatory stance in response to Olam
content:
SGX reiterates regulatory stance in response to Olam

Trading was within price ranges set by analysts, it says

Published

Sun, Mar 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Singapore Exchange (SGX) said that it takes a serious view of all market misconduct in breach of the Securities and Futures Act, including potential insider trading and manipulation activities.

The regulator was responding yesterday to news reports highlighting Olam's escalating share price ahead of Temasek Holdings' offer for the company last Friday. In the six weeks since Feb 3, Olam's counter had jumped 34.8 per cent, leading market watchers to ask if some had gotten wind of the deal. Others questioned why Olam did not request for a trading halt earlier, and was not queried by SGX.

"We will spare no effort in conducting investigations on possible transgressions and will cooperate with regulatory agencies to enforce the law against offenders," SGX said in its statement.

Under new rules which came into effect on March 3, listed companies are required to inform the bourse if their board is aware of discussions of a potential proposal, or in talks on an agreement which may lead to a takeover of the company.

SGX did not indicate whether it had been notified by Olam but said: "We do not discuss our dealings with regards to individual companies, including notifications as required under the listing rules. If there are possible breaches of rules or requirements, we will investigate and take appropriate action."

Olam declined to comment. Said a spokesman: "The offer made by Breedens Investments is subject to the Takeover Code, and we have been advised that we should not make any comment on the offer except by way of a board-approved announcement."

Temasek unit Breedens Investments Pte Ltd is leading a consortium to put up $2.53 billion to buy the rest of Olam that the group does not own. As at last Friday, the group owned a combined stake of 52.5 per cent.

Asked if it had notified SGX of the intended offer, Temasek declined comment and said: "All our discussions with the regulators are on a strictly confidential basis."

Besides requiring companies to keep material information confidential, the new rules which kicked in this month also require them to keep a list of names of persons privy to the transaction, requestable by SGX as and when necessary.

In its response, SGX also sought to put Olam's share price jump into context. Olam's 34.8 per cent price jump in the six weeks leading up to the takeover announcement had surpassed those of its peers, Wilmar International which rose 11.2 per cent, and Noble Group which rose 12.6 per cent over the same period.

SGX said that trading in these three stocks were within the price ranges set out in analysts' research reports, suggesting that they were trading within the general market view, with Olam shares reflecting a more positive market view.

It noted that of the 13 analysts who issued reports on Olam in February, seven had raised their target price by an average of 10.4 per cent, with the highest increase being 21.4 per cent. Target prices for the stock ranged from $1.50 to $2. Olam ended Friday at $2.23, which was the offer price.

In Wilmar's case, eight analysts raised their target price by an average of 2.6 per cent, with the highest increase being 4.8 per cent. For Noble, one analyst raised its target price in February.

"(Hence,) such comparisons should be conducted with care as the financials and outlook of individual companies may differ even if they are within the same industry," SGX noted.

Over the weekend, Carson Block, founder of US shortselling firm Muddy Waters which in November 2012 betted against Olam and said that the commodities trader faced insolvency risks, observed that the timing of Temasek's offer for Olam was "interesting".

In an e-mail to media, Mr Block said: "The Singapore sovereign wealth fund's timing is interesting given that Olam has $1.2 billion of debt maturing this year and is still burning cash, and that the stock has inexplicably outperformed in the past month."

site_title: MH370 mystery may spur redesign of switches
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

MH370 mystery may spur redesign of switches

Satellite technology for real-time tracking of jets may become priority too

Published

Sun, Mar 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[CHICAGO] In a world where Google Inc knows your shopping habits and police use mobile phones to pinpoint locations of emergency calls, how can a wide-body Boeing 777 fall off the grid?

The silencing of most communications from Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 exposes how easily the voice, radar and satellite links in a modern plane can be disabled. A beacon to help controllers track the jet was shut off. So was the text-and-data system to help the airline stay in touch with the crew.

The mystery may spur a redesign of switches that let pilots sever the connections, and speed adoption of satellite technology for real-time tracking of planes and crucial systems, said George Hamlin, a former Airbus SAS executive.

"The book of rules is written in blood," Mr Hamlin said, citing the catchphrase used among aviation professionals. "Many of the rules were written because people discovered how things could go wrong that were unknown before."

Even a cockpit voice recorder that is part of the so-called black box may not provide tell-tale clues if the 777-200 operated for four hours after controllers lost contact, as satellite data suggests. The unit keeps only two hours of audio as it overwrites older material in a continuous loop, said Todd Curtis, president of Seattle-based consultant

AirSafe.com

.

Flight MH370 last appeared on air controllers' screens as it approached Vietnamese airspace at a cruising altitude over the Gulf of Thailand on March 8. The last voice communication was normal, according to Malaysia Airlines.

Before contact was lost, the jet's radar signature was enhanced by its transponder, which gives air traffic managers details about the target they're tracking. Pilots can code them to emit distress signals for an emergency or hijacking, said Hans Weber, president of San Diego-based Tecop International, a consultant focusing on aviation safety and security issues.

The jet concerned was also outfitted with the Aircraft Communications Addressing and Reporting System, dubbed Acars, which lets pilots send text message-like communiques to flight operations staff.

The technology allows the jet itself to send reports via satellite or radio to ground handlers of any abnormal performance or mechanical breakdowns. Transmissions to Malaysia Airlines and engine-maker Rolls-Royce ceased shortly into flight, the companies said in statements.

Malaysia Airlines didn't subscribe to a popular Boeing add-on: a maintenance program to beam real-time information to the Chicago-based planemaker, said a person familiar with the jetliner, who wasn't authoriaed to speak on the record. Boeing compiles the data and sends maintenance alerts to participants in its Airplane Health Management programme.

Anyone intent on ending aircraft data communications would need to turn a switch to silence the transponder or disable a cockpit circuit-breaker to cut off Acars, said Bill Waldock, professor of safety science who teaches accident investigations at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in Prescott, Arizona.

Flight MH370's interrupted Acars data feed indicates intervention by "someone who knows the system on the airplane", Mr Waldock said. "That has to be the crew or someone who's intimately familiar with how a 777 operates."

Even without the flow of Acars reports to the ground, the jet's position was tracked to near Australia by analysing pings from a transmitter that signalled a satellite about once an hour after the transponder went dead and the plane veered off its northerly course, said the person familiar with the analysis.

Investigators narrowed the jetliner's possible routes by mapping the satellite contacts that continued after Acars and other systems were shut down, according to three people familiar with the work.

The pulses provide no data about the plane's speed, location or altitude. Still, they allow calculations of an arc along the earth's surface where the plane was each time it communicated with the satellite.

As the industry assesses how to forestall communication gaps in the future, Airbus Group and Chicago-based Boeing will have to balance design changes against a host of considerations, from the costs for airlines to the risk of saddling air crews with technology they can't control.

Requiring more satellite-based flight monitoring may spur objections from airlines about the expense, said Mr Curtis, who worked on the 777's development as a Boeing employee in the 1990s. Pilots also want to be able to prevent a cockpit fire or short-circuit by pulling the plug on any electronic device, like a transponder or the Acars system.

"Under normal circumstances, in flight you would never shut them off unless you wanted to hide," said Denny Kelly, a former airline pilot who runs an accident-investigation consultancy in Dallas.

Mr Hamlin, the former Airbus executive, said one easy fix would be making switches for transponders, cockpit voice recorders and data tracking more cumbersome to turn off.

Wilson Chow, a Boeing spokesman, declined to comment on how MH370 might affect aircraft design, as did Mary Anne Greczyn, a US spokeswoman for Toulouse-based Airbus Group.

Data communications as basic as the aircraft-performance signals sent via Acars were pivotal in unravelling the 2009 Air France jet crash in South Atlantic.

For MH370, the cutoff of that data for an unknown period leaves a hole in investigators' understanding of what happened during its final moments.

On-board voice recorders can be disabled by a circuit- breaker in the cockpit, Mr Hamlin said. Mr Curtis said recovering the flight's recorders also may prove little if the two hours of recording capacity weren't enough to capture any course change.

"Passengers' electronics could be absolutely essential to determine what happened and when it happened," he said.

Flight MH 370 is already sparking renewed talk about implementing satellite-based tracking, to span areas beyond radar coverage and provide airlines and controllers more information about what's occurring in the air.

With technology that's more advanced than after the Air France crash - and with the expense of dozens of ships and planes hunting for debris - closer monitoring of planes may be an idea whose time is at hand, Mr Weber said.

Compiling that data would eliminate the need for data and voice recorders on planes. - Bloomberg

content:

Companies should also focus on the 'I' in PIC

Innovation, not just productivity, needs more attention, say business leaders

Listen to this article

Published Sun, Mar 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Rather than focusing on just automation and training, companies should use more of the other qualifying activities in the productivity and innovation credit (PIC) scheme, said participants at a post-budget roundtable organised by Canon Singapore in collaboration with The Business Times.

The other four activities - which include the acquisition and registration of intellectual property, research and development, and approved design projects - will help businesses to innovate and be different, instead of having incremental productivity advances from the first two activities, they said. PIC has a total of six qualifying activities.

Said Abhijit Ghosh, corporate tax partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers Singapore: "There is really high value-added stuff out there in the last four buckets. We don't see much action there, and the question we should be asking is: Why not?"

Boeing 787 Dreamliner safe to fly: FAA review

Published Thu, Mar 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] The Boeing 787 Dreamliner, grounded for months last year after battery overheating problems, is soundly designed and safe to fly, a joint review by the planemaker and the Federal Aviation Administration said on Wednesday.

The review, which was initiated by the FAA after a battery fire aboard a 787 in Boston in January 2013, encompassed the entire plane, not specifically the battery issue.

"They found that the 787 met its intended level of safety. The plane's fundamentally sound design and the processes the FAA and Boeing had in place to detect and correct issues that emerged were the underpinnings for that conclusion," FAA administrator Michael Huerta told a telephone news briefing.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Buybacks maintain momentum

Published

Sun, Mar 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BUYING fell while selling among directors rose last week, according to filings on Singapore Exchange, with 15 companies recording 32 purchases worth $2.47 million versus sixwith 15 disposals worth $2.42 million. The buy figures were sharply down from the previous week's 23 companies, 49 purchases and $5 million. Sales were up from the previous week's five firms, six disposals and $310,000.

Buyback activity remained high with 12 companies that posted 37 repurchases worth $39.3 million - consistent with the previous week's 12 firms and 35 trades while the value was sharply up from that week's turnover of $6.6 million. The huge value was due to buybacks by DBS Group Holdings with 2.1 million shares purchased (March 10-14) for $33.4 million at an average of $15.92 each.

The buybacks, accounting for 6 per cent of the stock's trading volume, were made on the back of the 9 per cent drop in the share price since January from $17.41. The group acquired 1.8 million shares (June to July 2013) at an average of $15.59 each, 8.6 million shares (August to December 2011) at an average of $13.31 each and 4.579 million shares (November 2007 to October 2008) at an average of $17.41 each. The stock closed at $15.73 on Friday.

There were several significant director trades with purchases in Banyan Tree Holdings, Mewah International and Uni-Asia Holdings and sales in Tee Land, Halcyon Agri Corp, Lion Teck Chiang and GP Batteries.

Banyan Tree Holdings

Founder and executive chairman Ho Kwon Ping recorded his first on-market trades in premium resorts, hotels and spas manager and developer Banyan Tree Holdings since August 2009 with 200,000 shares purchased (March 11-12) at an average of 64.1 cents each. This increased his deemed holdings to 286.433 million shares or 37.71 per cent of the issued capital. The purchases were made on the back of the 18 per cent drop in the share price since May 2013 from 78.5 cents. Despite the fall, the counter is still up since June 2012 from 50 cents. Mr Ho previously acquired 9.77 million shares (August 2007 to August 2009) at $2.03 to $0.37 each or an average of $0.70 each. Banyan Tree announced on Feb 27 a 44 per cent drop in fourth-quarter profit after tax to $3.941 million. Earnings for the full year, however, rose by 18 per cent to $18.155 million. The counter closed at 65 cents on Friday.

Mewah International

CEO Michelle Cheo Hui Ning picked up where she left off in edible oils and fats producer Mewah International in October 2013 with an initial two million shares (direct interest) purchased on March 12 at 49 cents each. The shares bought represented 0.13 per cent of the issued capital. She also has deemed interest of 573.508 million shares or 38.05 per cent. She previously acquired 3.88 million shares from August to October 2013 at an average of 46.1 cents each, 11.78 million shares from January to June 2013 at an average of 51.2 cents each and 2.74 million shares from January to November 2012 at an average of 44 cents each. Mewah International announced on Feb 27 a 7.7 per cent gain in fourth-quarter profit after tax to US$9.123 million. Full-year earnings, however, fell by 15 per cent to US$20.005 million. The counter closed at 49 cents on Friday.

Uni-Asia Holdings

COO Michio Tanamoto and executive director Masaki Fukumori acquired shares of structured finance arrangement and alternative assets direct investment firm Uni-Asia Holdings with a combined 530,000 shares purchased (Feb 28-March 12) at an average of 19.1 cents each. The purchases, accounting for 37 per cent of the stock's trading volume, were made after Uni-Asia Holdings announced on Feb 27 a fourth-quarter profit of $37,000 versus a loss of $240,000 in the same 2012 period. Full-year earnings rose by 57 per cent to $5.641 million. Mr Tanamoto recorded his first on-market trades since the stock was listed in August 2007 with 330,000 shares purchased (March 7-12) at 19 cents each. The trades increased his direct holdings to 9.283 million shares or 2.0 per cent.

The share price dropped 24 per cent since May 2013 from 25 cents. Despite the fall, the counter is still up since August 2012 from 16.1 cents. Executive director Masaki Fukumoripurchased 200,000 shares on Feb 28 at 19.2 cents each, boosting his direct stake to 8.093 million shares or 1.7 per cent. He acquired 337,000 shares (Nov 20-Dec 20, 2013) at an average of 19 cents and 500,000 shares in May 2013 at 23 cents each. The counter closed at 19.5 cents on Friday.

Tee Land

Non-executive chairman Lee Bee Wah and independent director Chin Sek Peng acquired shares of property developer Tee Land after the stock fell by 12 per cent from 33 cents in January with a combined 285,000 shares purchased on March 14 at an average of 29 cents each. Dr Lee purchased 135,000 shares on March 14 at 29.5 cents each, which increased her direct holdings by 77 per cent to 310,000 shares or 0.07 per cent. She previously acquired 85,000 shares in October 2013 at 36 cents each.

The purchases by Dr Lee since October 2013 are her first on-market trades since the stock was listed in June 2013. Her purchase prices were lower than the IPO's 54 cents.

Mr Chin acquired 150,000 shares on March 14 at 28.5 cents each, boosting his direct stake by 136 per cent to 260,000 shares or 0.06 per cent. He previously acquired 50,000 shares in December 2013 at 32.5 cents each and an initial 60,000 shares in August 2013 at 34 cents each. The counter closed at 28 cents on Friday.

Halcyon Agri Corp

Executive chairman and CEO Robert Gunther Meyer recorded his first on-market trades in midstream natural rubber producer Halcyon Agri Corp since the stock was listed in February 2013 with 2.6 million shares sold from March 10 to 13 at an average of 77.5 cents each. The trades, which accounted for 43 per cent of the stock's trading volume, reduced his deemed holdings to 102.750 million shares or 25.95 per cent (registered holder is Halcyon Investment Corporation Pte Ltd). He also has direct interest of 4.55 million shares or 1.15 per cent. The disposals were made on the back of the 9 per cent rebound in the share price since February from 71 cents. Despite the rebound, the counter is still down since June 2013 from $1.07.

Mr Meyer's sale price was sharply higher than the IPO's 36 cents. Halcyon Agri Corp announced on Feb 27 a 75.7 per cent gain in fourth-quarter profit to US$1.426 million. Full-year earnings, however, fell by 9.3 per cent to US$9.1 million. The counter closed at 75.5 cents on Friday.

Lion Teck Chiang

Director Cheng Heng Jem unloaded more shares of property investor and developer and steel trader Lion Teck Chiang with 169,000 shares sold from March 5 to 12 at an average of 72.8 cents each. The trades, which accounted for 71 per cent of the stock's trading volume, reduced his deemed holdings to 28.622 million shares or 18.29 per cent. He previously sold 407,000 shares from Feb 19 to 20 at 74 cents each and 72,000 shares on Nov 20, 2013, at 81 cents each. Prior to his disposals since November 2013, the director unloaded 815,000 shares from May to July 2013 at an average of 73.9 cents each, 2.185 million shares from February to March 2013 at an average of 75.2 cents each and 150,000 shares in July 2012 at 46 cents each. The counter closed at 72.5 cents on Friday.

GP Batteries International

Vice-chairman Richard Ku Yuk Hing recorded his first on-market trade in battery manufacturer GP Batteries International since December 2010 with 31,000 shares sold on March 12 at 58.5 cents each. The trade reduced his direct holdings by 11 per cent to 259,000 shares or 0.16 per cent. The sale was made on the back of the 26 per cent drop in the share price since December 2013 from 78.5 cents. The counter is also sharply down since March 2011 from $1.30. He previously sold 29,000 shares in December 2010 at an average of $1.71 each. Prior to his disposals since December 2010, the vice-chairman acquired 81,000 shares in April 2009 at an average of 56.1 cents each. Prior to those purchases, Mr Ku unloaded 549,000 shares from September 2003 to September 2004, some of which were options-related sales, at an average of $3.54 each.

Note that the stock fell by an average of 30 per cent six months after Mr Ku sold shares, based on 13 disposals since 2003. The stock recorded a price fall six months after on 92 per cent of those disposals. GP Batteries announced on Jan 27 a third-quarter loss of $24.153 million versus a profit of $4.785 million in the same quarter in 2012. Loss in the first nine months was $20.291 million versus a profit of $10.881 million in the same period in 2012. The counter closed at 55.5 cents on Friday.

site_title: China money market funds expose cracks in banking
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China money market funds expose cracks in banking

Banks, faced with credit crunch, rely on these funds for short-term liquidity

Published

Tue, Mar 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE explosive growth of an online money market fund launched by the Alibaba Group last summer has exposed the cracks in China's banking system as regulators attempt to wean the country's banks off cheap money.

The Yu E Bao fund, now the country's largest with more than 500 billion yuan (S$102.4 billion) under management, has caused a stir in China - both for the threat it has posed to the country's banks and its rewards to its investors, who number 81 million and have exceeded the number of equity investors.

With the success of Yu E Bao, China's money market fund industry has grown from a bit player to a 953.2 billion yuan one as at January. Money market funds are not new in China, but Yu E Bao was the first to create economies of scale by pooling together small investors who park idle money in their accounts with Alibaba's online payment system.

Along the way, Yu E Bao, meaning "leftover treasure", has revolutionised how funds are raised in China. Its existence, as well as its high profitability, ironically, owes much to the funding needs of the banks themselves.

Alibaba commissions the money it has raised through the Yu E Bao programme to a fund manager, Tianhong Asset Management, which it acquired last year. Tianhong, in turn, lends the money, via private placements, to banks in need of short-term liquidity but which are having trouble getting it directly from the interbank market.

Wang Dengfeng, the fund manager of Yu E Bao, disclosed a week ago that it lends primarily to a dozen big and mid-sized banks, which are among the 29 major banks on the regulator's white list.

He said it shuns away from dealing with small and regional banks, and that most of its investors are small depositors whose savings fall well below 50,000 yuan - not enough to qualify them for high-yielding wealth management products offered by banks.

A prolonged credit squeeze endured by many Chinese banks, mainly the 13 joint stock commercial banks, has given Yu E Bao an opening to profit from the banking system's funding shortfalls. The pain of this credit crunch was felt most acutely in June and December, when Chinese companies had to balance their bi-annual budgets.

Banks are having trouble meeting their funding obligations for long-term projects, mainly those in real estate, mining, commodities and steel, because quietly and steadily the Chinese central bank has been tightening the screws on the national money supply.

Shui Pi, a popular financial commentator and editor-in-chief of the Beijing-based China Times newspaper, said: "The root cause is a quiet, invisible transition induced by the central bank to shift away from an ultra-loose monetary policy of the last few years. If we continue living on loose money, it'd turn into a disaster.

"It's a big dilemma. These mid-size banks are tapping short-term financing to pay for long-term funding obligations, all because they were expanding too fast.

"It has nothing to do with bad loans. It's because commercial banks have expanded their loan books too aggressively, too quickly. They made the wrong calls when the economy slowed down. They were too optimistic in their misguided expectations about the central bank's monetary policy."

Still, Mr Shui thinks the problem will be brought under control once banks resolve the mismatches in their loan books, a process he estimates could take about a year.

Most critics and supporters alike, meanwhile, focus on whether Yu E Bao and its many smaller copy cats would threaten the survival of traditional banking with their offer of attractive yields - more than 5 per cent annualised in recent weeks. Deposits in Chinese banks are yielding less than one per cent.

Critics have called Yu E Bao a "blood-sucking vampire", saying it would push up overall funding costs in the banking system while taking away deposits from smaller banks.

Its supporters have, however, praised it for its ability to redistribute the unreasonably fat profits previously earned by banks back to small investors. In the process, this has hastened the liberalisation of interest rates in the banking system.

China International Capital Corp, a domestic investment bank, estimates that the entire banking system's demand deposits are expanding at a pace of about two trillion yuan each year, and that some of this expansion in deposits would now be diverted into money market funds, which could push up banks' funding costs once it flows back in the form of lending to banks.

In a separate report, its researcher, Mao Junhua, calculated that Yu E Bao would triple its size to 1.5 trillion yuan in 2016.

Yu E Bao's Mr Wang said that he does not expect the fund's yields, now at above 5 per cent, to fall below an annual rate of 4.5 per cent anytime soon, because he expects banks to face another credit crunch in May and June.

Alibaba announced on Sunday that it is seeking an initial public offering in the US, but that Yu E Bao will be excluded from it. Separately, Alibaba recently received official approval to set up a commercial bank.

Two other China Internet giants, Tencent and Baidu, have also entered the online finance arena with online money market funds fashioned after Yu E Bao, though on a far smaller scale. Tencent has also received the green light to set up a commercial bank.

These forays may have achieved what many liberal economists have failed to accomplish for years - infuse competition into an otherwise unwieldy financial system dominated by state-owned players.

Moody's said on Monday that China's bank asset quality and profitability will worsen this year, given a moderating economy. However, it believes Chinese banks' credit metrics are "unlikely to deteriorate to a level that will negatively affect their current ratings".

site_title: Big Data is not just for 'high-end' data scientists
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Big Data is not just for 'high-end' data scientists

Published

Sun, Mar 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BUSINESS intelligence software provider Tableau may be riding the Big Data wave, but its start was initially an uphill journey. Chief scientist and co-founder Pat Hanrahan recounts that the desire to help non-technical users visualise and understand their data was considered a bad idea then.

"It was considered a bad idea as we would be competing with Microsoft. People were happy with Excel. Everyone was telling us we should go after the very sophisticated users," said Mr Hanrahan, who started his career in computer graphics and previously worked at Pixar.

He added: "We had read a report that more people use Excel to process data than for financial calculation. But Excel was never designed for that. Add to that the data was going to be more and more important to businesses and everyone would have to be manipulating it. It just seemed obvious that we could do something that would address that market."

Evolving from a research project that was started in the late-90s, Mr Hanrahan and two of his Stanford University students decided to take the leap and set up Tableau in 2003.

"If you think you have a better way of doing something, you're going to try to get it out to the world and get people to use it," he said of the entrepreneurial spirit that drove them to move ahead against conventional advice.

In order to ensure the rationality of their decision, the co-founders - Mr Hanrahan, chief executive officer Christian Chabot and chief development officer Chris Stolte - set realistic milestones. Their goal was to have a customer by the end of the first year. They clinched their first deal with grocery chain Safeway and then an OEM deal with Hyperion. By the end of the first year, they were profitable. That was when they decided to raise money. According to Mr Hanrahan, it took them one week to get funding for US$5 million, but as they were always profitable, they did not use that money.

Ten years on, the company achieved an 82 per cent year-on-year jump in revenue to reach US$232.4 million for its 2013 fiscal year. About 25 per cent of the revenue is ploughed back into R&D (research and development).

Tableau's customers include TravelSky Technology Ltd, which provides business intelligence and market information on the air travel industry in China. According to Joyce Yu, senior manager at TravelSky, the company has achieved an estimated 90 per cent improvement in time efficiency. "This translates to getting information out to clients faster, which can have significant impact on their businesses. They rely on the information to make decisions and every minute counts in the travel industry," she said.

A team of nine analysts sieve through 10 terabytes of data consisting of almost 100 million rows to pinpoint key performance indicators and unveil any developing trend in the industry. They compile all these into reports and present them to close to 100 client service representatives across China. Prior to adopting Tableau's software, it took two specialists two weeks every month to compile, sort and present their data to clients, which include commercial airlines, airport operators, travel agents and civil aviation institutions. Now, the team takes just one day to sort the data and drop it into the Tableau solution for analysis and for highlighting major developments and competitive trends in the industry. Information can also be presented in customised views according to different customer needs.

Melbourne-based start-up Brand Village uses Tableau's software to provide retail clients with insights on their customers' in-store shopping experience, so that they can finetune their strategies for improving brand loyalty and sales.

With the solution, Brand Village's own customers can also manipulate and interact with the data themselves using their iPads or PCs.

While more companies are jumping onto the Big Data analytics bandwagon, Tableau is sticking to its original intention of helping the average user work with data easily. "Many people think that Big Data is about all these 'high-end' data scientists. I don't think it is as I think that everyone in the world is going to be manipulating data in the future," said Mr Hanrahan.

In all, Mr Hanrahan and his students have started 15 companies, of which Tableau is the biggest. His advice to startups here: "I would encourage other entrepreneurs to come here. Entrepreneurs like to help more entrepreneurs. You can just get free advice. But you need support and encouragement.

"It takes a lot of commitment to think that you can build something that almost everybody can use, as everybody thinks that will never happen. That's when other entrepreneurs come and tell about their experience."

site_title: Symantec ready to ride cloud evolution wave
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Symantec ready to ride cloud evolution wave

It eyes piece of the action in software-defined technologies

Published

Sun, Mar 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

"SOFTWARE-DEFINED" seems to be the latest prefix fad in the computing industry, but companies need to understand the complexities that accompany this next evolution of the data centre architecture, said Eric Hoh, vice-president, Asia South region for Symantec.

Speaking to BizIT in an interview, he said that the initial teething phase that companies around the world went through at the dawn of virtualisation technology is happening again with software-defined data centres.

Virtualisation was a technology concept that allowed IT administrators to stretch the utilisation of their server hardware, by duplicating or shutting down "virtual" servers. This allowed a myriad of modern functions such as testing projects safely on a virtual server, or quickly moving a company's users over to a mirror server in the event of the main server going down. It's a fundamental building block of cloud-computing technology, because it is a necessary ability element for servers to accommodate peaks in user needs, for instance.

Now, software-defined data centres are the next evolution of that concept. It allows a data centre's physical elements such as storage and CPU (central processing unit) controls to be virtualised. And as more data centres become optimised for cloud-style performance, the industry is starting to take software-defined technologies seriously as a holistic architecture. But the complexity of managing software-defined assets has made it far more complex for smaller firms to handle.

Mr Hoh said: "In the past, if the light went out on a server, you'd know it wasn't working. But now there isn't a physical machine so you can't tell if it's switched on."

While small companies may be able to put off moving to a software-defined architecture for a little longer, they might still have to run up against it because of its prevalence in third party cloud providers, which smaller firms are more likely to rely on, as well.

Symantec is angling for a ride on the backs of large virtualisation vendors, as more firms take up their software-defined offerings. The security and back-up products vendor has been pushing back-up solutions for cloud servers, supporting specific vendors such as VMware and Microsoft, in the hopes of catching the new wave of spending on software-defined products.

Mr Hoh said: "The whole point of virtual resources is to make it easy to start up a server and shut it down, leaving no trace. But that means a user can accidentally take down a working server as well with a button. Where are the controls?"

According to a November 2013 study released by 451 Research, enterprise spending trends are moving towards software-defined technologies. Spending on hardware is predicted to slow over the next two years, as attention shifts to virtualisation and software automation that will allow IT administrators to create and run software-defined data centres, it said.

"Server professionals are switching their attention to the software required to run cloud-ready data centres, with spending increasing across the board in 2014 as compared with 2013, almost the exact opposite of the situation for infrastructure technologies," said the study.

The year 2013 saw most of the money going to software for virtualised data centres, and 2014 will usher in bigger cloud budgets for about 30 per cent of the pack. Not surprisingly, virtualised storage is the next technology leap for storage as well. The technology allows data to be moved and managed on commodity hardware. With software controls, a company's data can be replicated, with all of a document's different versions tracked.

Mr Hoh said adoption of the technology in the Asia-Pacific remains low, although most companies report that they are looking into switching to it.

site_title: Indonesia at risk of sliding into middle income trap
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Indonesia at risk of sliding into middle income trap

As commodity boom fades, it sees rapid growth waning

Published

Sun, Mar 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FOLLOWING nearly a decade of rapid economic growth fuelled by high commodity prices, Indonesia risks a slump into mediocrity, joining a class of resource-rich countries that fail to generate the jobs needed to lift millions out of poverty and propel them, one day, into the ranks of the rich world.

It's called the middle income trap: countries such as Brazil and South Africa, steeped in energy and minerals may ride a wave of rapid economic growth only to see boom go to bust, erasing gains because policymakers failed to invest sufficiently in education, infrastructure or governance necessary to attract investment and encourage new business. Indonesia is falling right into it, according to the World Bank's new Jakarta-based country director Rodrigo Chaves.

"Indonesia needs additional and more focused policy response to stop the economic slide," he said.

"It needs to address these structural changes because the winds are changing."

But as Indonesia begins its phased election season, voting for its House of Representatives on April 9 and then presidency in July, that more focused policy response may not be in the offing until at least October, when a new administration takes office. Until then, mining and trade policies with a nationalistic focus will likely take their toll.

Economic growth this year is forecast to slip to 5.3 per cent, Mr Chaves said, compared with 5.8 per cent last year. Foreign direct investment will "remain subdued" he adds, in part because the country's mineral ore export ban brought to a grinding halt much of the country's US$11.8 billion trade in nickel, copper as well as other mineral products.

"GDP growth of 5.3 per cent isn't enough to get out of the middle income trap."

To be sure, Indonesia's progress, until now, has been impressive. Since 1960, gross national income was - as measured in 2005 US dollars - US$300 a head. Now, it's closer to US$1,800. The ranks of the poor, those earning US$1.25 a day, have dwindled to about 16 per cent of the population.

But with most of Indonesia's macroeconomic risks coming from overseas, including the threat of war in Ukraine, moves by the US Federal Reserve to wind back its monetary stimulus, as well as shrinking demand for commodities from China, it makes Indonesia's recent bout of protectionist policies such as the ore export ban that came into effect in January, all the more risky.

A one per cent slowdown in China's rate of GDP growth, trims Indonesia's by 0.5 per cent as investment slows and demand for exports cool, Mr Chaves pointed out.

Futures contracts for palm oil, which accounts for 10 per cent of Indonesia's exports approached US$1,300 a tonne in 2011. Now, their value has fallen by a third. The metals index tabulated by the International Monetary Fund, including nickel, copper, iron ore and others has fallen by a similar amount.

"(The economy) could go a number of different ways in the event of any of those shocks," said Mr Chaves.

The 1997 Asian financial crisis that triggered the ouster of then-president Suharto plunged 51 million people who were reasonably well off into the ranks of the poor by 1998, noted Mr Chaves. It took eight years to return the country's per capita income to its pre-crisis level.

Even so, Indonesia's relatively consistent improvement in income may be the envy of the likes of Brazil where real GDP per capita growth has staggered between positive and negative rates since the 1970s.

Only two months into his new job, Mr Chaves sidestepped questions regarding whether Finance Minister Chatib Basri or other well-regarded members of President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono's outgoing cabinet can affect meaningful change in the months they have left in office.

Still, broadening the tax base and redirecting wasteful spending on fuel subsidies towards infrastructure and improving skills are a must he said. Indonesia needs US$60 billion a year in extra infrastructure investment amounting to 9 per cent of its GDP compared with the 3 per cent it spends now.

Indonesia spends US$21.5 billion subsidising the price of fuel and electricity. The top 10 per cent of the country's income earners enjoy 40 per cent of the subsidy because they drive cars and use more electricity at home than the poor.

For now, with its legions of young workers supporting a relatively small percentage of elderly, spending on roads and vocational schools will yield outsized dividends. But by 2025 when families have fewer babies and more of its people seek retirement, breaking free, like Singapore and South Korea managed, from the pack of middling performers, will get harder.

"Those countries got rich before they got older," Mr Chaves says.

"Indonesia may become old before it becomes rich."
