site_title: Designs on business
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Designs on business

An emerging design culture here makes the Singapore Design Week a timely initiative, writes TAY SUAN CHIANG

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FIRST, there was Singapore Fashion Week. Then Art Stage and its peripheral events raised the profile of art buying in Singapore. Now, Singapore design is in the limelight with a brand new festival that takes design out of the drawing studio and into real life.

Singapore Design Week (SDW) 2014 kicks off on Monday until Mar 16 with an activity-packed schedule that has no less than 50 local and international design events taking centre stage at the brand new National Design Centre in Middle Road and elsewhere around the city.

Whether you're a furniture or product designer, a house proud aesthete looking for the next conversation piece, or just anyone who likes pretty things, the SDW aims to please with its combination of both commercial and consumer interests. Scale-wise, it's the biggest such event so far, with the DesignSingapore Council joining forces with the Singapore Furniture Industries Council (SFIC) and DesignS - a collective of industry players - to play up the role of design in business and society, and bringing Singapore closer to its target of being Asia's design hub.

There's no better time than now to hold a festival like this, says Jeffrey Ho, executive director of DesignSingapore Council. "There's an emerging design culture in Singapore; people are much more design conscious; plus the prevailing global emphasis on design as a key economic factor."

Before SDW, the council's main interest was the Singapore Design Festival, which ran biennially from 2005 to 2009. It was a council-led event which provided a platform for Singaporean and international design communities to get together to network and share idesa.

While the festival was well received, Mr Ho says, "We wanted to rethink and be more targeted based on the Council's long-term plans to evolve the design landscape." Those plans include showing how design can play a part in growing businesses, as well as raising design awareness in Singaporeans.

SDW is therefore bigger and more ambitious in scope, thanks to the collaboration with SFIC and DesignS. Under the umbrella of SDW, Singaplural - a design event started three years ago to encourage brainstorming among design players in advertising, architecture, interiors and furniture design - will become the anchor event.

Design Council's Mr Ho adds that this symbiotic collaboration allows them to organise activities and events to benefit all parties across the board - from designers and businesses to students and the public.

For example, there is the first Singapore Design Business Summit, organised by the Design Business Chamber Singapore. Its president, Tai Lee Siang, says that top management folks, business owners, design practitioners, students of design and any organisation that uses design should attend the summit. "This is an opportunity to hear speakers share their success stories and challenges about how design can be used to enhance business," he says.

To further push the idea of collaborations between different associations, the Chamber is working with the Singapore Institute of Landscape Architects, Interior Design Confederation Singapore and SFIC for its summit lectures. "The variety of topics under the design umbrella becomes wider, covering landscape architecture, interior design and furniture design," says Mr Tai.

He adds that SDW presents the best opportunity for a multi-purpose platform to stage all the various programmes specifically made to highlight the value of design to businesses. He points out the close correlation between design and profit. Using Apple as an example, which has increased its revenue by 1200 per cent since 2000, Mr Tai says, "It's not just clever marketing or prudent financial moves; clearly the success is defined by excellent design solutions."

He adds, "holding the event annually will serve to anchor the value of design, and design industries firmly in the minds of businesses and the society at large."

Apart from targeting enterprises, key events during SDW also reach out to industry players. A new addition on this year's calendar is Maison&Objet Asia, an off-shoot of the highly successful Parisian home furnishings trade show.

Taking place from March 10 to 13, this first Asian edition will see 265 brand exhibitors from 24 countries, of which 30 per cent are from Asia Pacific.

Maison&Objet's managing director Philippe Brocart says that Maison&Objet Asia taking place during SDW will "help to attract more people to the show." He does not think the show will come in competition with the other stalwart - the 33-year-old International Furniture Fair Singapore which runs from March 13 to 16. "Maison&Objet and IFFS have different profiles but they will be complementary," says Mr Brocart.

Simon Ong, chairman of design development at SFIC and SingaPlural 2014, says that from the industry's standpoint, "it is good to have more design content and events. Maison&Objet Asia is a very different event from IFFS. There can be room to co-exist and develop synergy to propel the industry forward."

While pushing the idea of design and business, as well as reaching out to industry players are important, getting the man-in-the-street interested in design is also one of the goals of SDW.

Mr Ho says the line-up of events and activities have been planned to cater to even those who are not designed trained. He cites Design Trails: Creative Circuits as an example, where shuttle buses will ply two routes to bring visitors to design studios and stores.

Events under the SingaPlural umbrella are also meant for the public. One highlight is 30 LifeStories, held at Dhoby Ghaut Green and the National Design Centre. Here, old logs salvaged from parks around Singapore are given a new lease of life as park installations. Then there is also Design Larger Than Life, a series of outdoor installations where public interaction is encouraged.

The highly anticipated Furniture Design Award, which attracts regional and international design talents to work in Singapore and also acts as a launch pad for creative and innovative designs in Asia, will also be returning this year.

Department store Robinsons Orchard is also jumping on the design bandwagon this year for SDW. A team of designers will be transforming a glasshouse into one filled with Swarovski crystals in 48 hours as part of a window display competition. Local design firm Hjgher will create an interactive window display.

Inside the store, it is collaborating with Maison&Objet to show pieces that reflect the Singapore home.

Frank Kraatz, Robinsons' managing director says "design has always been a part of Robinsons' DNA. With the pivotal role that Maison&Objet plays every year in the global design scene, our collaboration epitomises our commitment to showcasing the best of design here in Singapore."

Even though there have been smaller design-related events held over the past year, design folks welcome the start of SDW.

Designer Edwin Low who runs Supermama says, "in a way SDW can be seen as an "official week" to house all design activities together. So yes, it is long overdue."

Joel Leong from Haystakt, an online retailer for design and craft says that, "with a small domestic market, it is great to have marketing-geared events like these to bridge the design community and the public. I think whether it will be successful or not depends on the level of public involvement and engagement, because an audience is required in order for designers to attempt to make design accessible."

For designer Pann Lim from Kinetic, an event such as SDW "will always be beneficial to the design scene no matter what, because more designers are involved. With more participation, the network in the industry becomes more intimate. Involvement from international designers also gives SDW more depth and breadth."

He adds that, "with time, the general masses will be more exposed to design culture. And, of course, the desired results will be like-minded people looking forward to SDW.

Design practitioner Lee Weiming, however, hopes that there will be more hands-on workshops in future editions. He finds that SDW is packed with talks and workshops that are too theoretical. "Hopefully there can be workshops, especially those by younger designers, that allow them to express themselves through their work."

He adds that workshops that are more hands-on and that allow the public to understand the design process, or even a visit to a factory to watch how furniture is conceptualised and built, and workshops that allow participants to use design tools, would help them better appreciate design."

Mr Ho says that he hopes SDW will be able to attract more than 15,000 participants and visitors. "Beyond the numbers, more importantly, we hope to deepen the level of engagement with our audiences."

content:

LTA: higher proportion of cheaper cars in Cat A now

Drop in median OMV of Cat A cars registered after re-categorisation

Published

Wed, Mar 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The small car Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium may not have softened substantially following last month's re-categorisation but Land Transport Authority (LTA) data shows a higher proportion of less expensive cars registered with a Category A COE since then.

A Cat A car used to be defined as one with an engine capacity of 1,600cc or smaller. From last month, the re-classified Cat A also limits engine output to 97 kW or 130 hp.

The move is to ensure that luxury models stay out of this traditional bread-and-butter segment and that soaring premiums are deflated.

As for Cat B, it is now for cars above 1,600cc or 130 hp.

Looking at car registration data in February - the first month since the re-categorisation of Cat A and B cars - the LTA says that there has been a significant decrease in the median open market value (OMV) of cars registered in Cat A, as well as a greater number of cars with a lower OMV registered in this category (see table).

"The objective of the re-categorisation was to ensure that Cat A better achieves its original social equity purpose of serving mass-market car buyers, in view of the rising proportion of higher-end cars appearing in Cat A in recent years," LTA said in a statement yesterday.

It pointed out that the median OMV of cars registered in February - using Cat A COEs obtained after re-categorisation - fell by 28 per cent to $18,845, compared with $26,147 for COEs obtained in the preceding six months (August 2013 to January 2014).

"Correspondingly, there were more cars with lower OMV registered in Cat A using COEs obtained after the re-categorisation, compared to those registered using COEs obtained in the six months prior to re-categorisation," said the LTA.

Two highlights from the data reveal that the proportion of cars with an OMV of $15,000 or below has tripled to 25 per cent after the re-categorisation, while those with an OMV of $20,000 or less has more than doubled to 56 per cent.

The LTA also noted that other social equity elements in its car ownership policies include the tiered Additional Registration Fee (ARF) structure introduced in March last year.

This means Cat A cars generally have "significantly lower statutory costs" than Cat B cars.

The total statutory cost payable for a Cat A car was $98,769 on average compared to $148,250 for a Cat B car, based on registration data from August 2013 to February 2014.

But one motor dealer said that the re-categorisation has not completely eliminated luxury cars from Cat A.

"Mercedes-Benz is still in this category with its CLA, A and B-Class cars, while Audi has the A3," he said. "That is one of the reasons why the gap between the Cat A and Cat B premiums is not wider."

site_title: 84, and on a second wind
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

84, and on a second wind

LA developer who thought of suicide during the '90s recession has US$600m of projects in hand, says NADJA BRANDT

Published

Wed, Mar 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LOS ANGELES] AT 84, Los Angeles developer Jerry Snyder has US$600 million of projects under construction or planned, including two apartment towers in the city's Koreatown area and three office buildings.

"My doctor asked me, 'When are you going to quit?'" Mr Snyder said in an interview at his 30th-floor corner office overlooking the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and La Brea Tar Pits. "So I said, 'Are you a better doctor now than you were 10 years ago?' He said yes. 'Well, I am a better builder than I was 10 years ago'."

Mr Snyder, who formed his first company when he was 19, is persevering after surviving some tough economic cycles. During the recession in the early 1990s, "suicide became an option", he said, as values plunged on properties with millions of dollars of his personal guaranties. Six decades after entering the business, he's about to sell his latest apartment project and intends to use the proceeds on new office buildings.

"I have been hearing more and more, 'I need more space'," Mr Snyder said. "When you get the 'I need more space' in more than one of your buildings, you know things are getting better. It's time to build."

Mr Snyder said he is planning a US$70 million office project on Vine Street in the Hollywood section of Los Angeles, which he will start building later this year even without tenant commitments. He also said that he expects to start a US$100 million building on Wilshire Boulevard, in addition to a US$138 million Hollywood office development that's already been announced.

Rising rents

Little office space has been added in the area in the past five years, putting Mr Snyder ahead of the curve, said Todd Doney, vice-chairman for brokerage office services at Los Angeles-based CBRE Group Inc.

"We are in the early stages of the office recovery," Mr Doney said. "As long as we keep the economy plugging along and can continue modest job growth, the office market here should continue to improve."

Average monthly asking rents at Los Angeles County office buildings climbed to US$2.63 per square foot last year, up 2.3 per cent from 2012, according to CBRE. Rising rents have spurred an increase in construction, with 1.3 million square feet of office space under development, the most since late 2008, according to the brokerage.

Higher rents are driven in part by demand from entertainment and technology companies in areas such as Los Angeles's Westside, where asking rents were US$3.62 on average, CBRE data show.

"We saw a rise in activity towards year-end for a number of reasons, including an increase in confidence by some Los Angeles area companies as the national economy continued its modest recovery," said Mark Sullivan, executive vice-president at New York-based commercial real estate services firm Studley Inc.

Mr Snyder last month broke ground on the US$138 million Hollywood office project without tenant commitments, aiming for entertainment and media-related clients. His other speculative office development in the area will be a 107,000-square-foot building on Vine across from the W Hollywood hotel, he said. He is awaiting final regulatory approval and expects to begin construction in September.

"The office market was hit hard during the recession," Mr Snyder said. "But it's pretty strong now in pockets. In Hollywood, for example, we're right in the middle of post-production and all the ancillary businesses. It's booming."

Some of the biggest issues facing Los Angeles office developers are the slow growth in rents and the uneven recovery, according to a fourth-quarter report by tenant representative Studley.

"Other than a couple of larger renewals and some significant healthcare leases, fourth-quarter leasing in most of the market was once again lacklustre," the firm said. The the majority of "employers plus particularly traditional-space users - remain cautious and focused on cost containment."

Shrinking space requirements by tenants are adding to high vacancies, according to Mr Doney of CBRE. Vacancies of 15.9 per cent remain close to their decade peak of 16.4 per cent, from 2010, CBRE data show.

"People are continuing to expand the 'free address' concept, meaning you're not building out space with the one-desk-per-employee concept," Mr Doney said. "So as tenants might sign leases, they may find they can make do with 60 per cent of the original space. The question for developers has to be, will this continue at the pace it's at, or is the pendulum swinging too far and will it mellow out again?"

Kilroy Realty Corp, a Los Angeles-based owner of commercial real estate along the West Coast, last month said it plans to develop a US$300 million office-and-apartment project in Hollywood after acquiring land from the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences, bringing the real estate investment trust's commitments in the area to about US$800 million.

Build-to-suit project

"When you go to invest in a speculative office development, you are still more out there on the risk curve," said Steve Reents, Seattle-based vice-president of acquisitions at Bentall Kennedy, a Canadian real estate investment adviser. Mr Snyder got a US$95 million construction loan for his Hollywood office project from a fund advised by the firm.

"It was particularly important to work with a partner with a deep connection and reputation in the market and one with a strong vision of the current and future market place," Mr Reents said. "Jerry has that."

On the Miracle Mile stretch of Wilshire Boulevard, Mr Snyder is planning a build-to-suit project - a model of which, complete with a replica of a mammoth drowning in the La Brea Tar Pits, sits on his conference table - for a client he wouldn't identify. The 13-storey building would sit next to his existing property at 5757 Wilshire Blvd, which is almost fully leased.

"I build everything, but I love office," Mr Snyder said. "I enjoy office because I'm dealing with business people - with professionals."

Proceeds from Mr Snyder's 464-unit apartment complex in Koreatown may total US$310 million, GlobeSt.com said on Jan 29, citing industry experts it didn't name.

Mr Snyder is planning to start marketing rental units at the project, called The Vermont, in early March, and put the entire development up for sale with the help of broker Jones Lang LaSalle Inc. Neither Mr Snyder nor Jones Lang would comment on the potential price.

The property, which Mr Snyder spent US$190 million to build using a US$65 million loan from Bentall Kennedy, has received "a lot of interest" from potential buyers, including US real estate investment trusts and investors from Asia and Europe, he said. Mr Snyder has shown the complex more than 20 times and expects a deal within 45 days.

"He's been a developer that has been able to see the future and execute on that," said Bruce Korter, director of real estate at Washington Capital Management. The Seattle-based firm manages investments for union pension funds in the state and was the lead equity investor in Mr Snyder's Vermont project. He wouldn't disclose the size of the company's investment.

"He's gone through hard times and good times, and has come up a survivor," Mr Korter said. "We have a lot of faith in Jerry and are looking to do more business with him."

Born in Brooklyn in 1930, Mr Snyder broke into real estate as a general contractor working with his father. They moved to the West Coast when Mr Snyder was a teenager and, at 19, he founded his own company, L. Snyder & Son, eventually buying an empty lot and building his first house.

"I loved it," Mr Snyder said. "I was the producer, the director and the screenplay writer. That's when I decided I wanted to be a developer."

He went from building one house after another to 500 at a time and, by the age of 22, was written up in The Wall Street Journal for being one of the youngest large-scale builders, developing 2,000 houses a year.

Single-family homes

Mr Snyder, who's lived in the Bel Air neighbourhood of Los Angeles with his wife, Joan, for 32 years and also owns houses in Montana and Rancho Mirage, California, focused on building single-family homes across the United States for three decades before entering the commercial real estate business in 1977 and ultimately focusing on Southern California.

After expanding his real estate projects - including his development of the Water Garden office complex in Santa Monica, and 10 high-rise condominium buildings next to the Hotel Coronado in San Diego County - he almost "lost his shirt" with US$144 million of personal guaranties given during the rapid appreciation of property values in the 1980s that then plunged during the US recession of the early 1990s, following the collapse of the savings-and-loan industry.

Mr Snyder, who continues to arrive at his office at 9am most days, said he has since improved his financing strategies, keeping the leverage on his buildings manageable and focusing on cash flow and costs. He won't give personal guaranties again, he said. By the time of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc's 2008 demise and subsequent market crash, he had refinanced most of his properties and reaped profits from selling some of his buildings.

"This last downturn we kind of skipped," Mr Snyder said of his company, where one of his three children also works. "But back in the '90s, I remember sitting on the weekends with my wife, and praying, 'Please get me out of this one'." Mr Snyder remains optimistic about development possibilities in the region today.

"There's an old joke about a golfer," he said. "He's had a terrible day. So he goes into the locker room and cuts his throat. When his friend comes in and says, 'You want to play tomorrow?' he holds his throat and says, 'What time, Charlie?' It's just like that for me. I see things coming my way, and I say, 'Sure, I'll look at it'." - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Rushed exit from bond funds ignites fear of market tantrum

Regulators are unprepared for such an outcome, warn economists in a paper

Published

Tue, Mar 4, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LOW interest rates have incited a craze for risky bonds in fast-growing economies, and few fund companies have been more adept in meeting this demand than Pimco, the world's largest bond manager. Over the past four years, Pimco's flagship emerging market (EM) local currency fund grew to more than US$12 billion from US$1.5 billion as investors, desperate for high-yielding exposure to Brazil, Mexico, Russia and Turkey, showered the fund with cash.

Now, investors are pulling their money out of this and other emerging market bond funds, as across-the-board selling by market heavyweights such as Pimco prompts others to follow suit. Economists and regulators fear that the result could be a system-rattling bond market tantrum.

In a paper presented on Friday at a conference in Manhattan, four influential economists with roots in Wall Street, academia and the Federal Reserve warned that regulators had done little to prepare for such an outcome. The paper was discussed by a panel that included Narayana Kocherlakota, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, and Jeremy C Stein, a governor at the Fed.

"It's the size of these inflows that is unprecedented," said Hyun Song Shin, a financial economist at Princeton and the incoming head of research at the Bank for International Settlements, the policy and banking outfit based in Basel, Switzerland, that caters to global central banks. "Because the Fed's policy has been maintained for so long, the pile of firewood has grown to a very large size."

The notion that a bond market tantrum, if it lasts long enough, can lead to a broader economic crisis that reaches beyond its original locus is not without precedent. The debt crisis in the eurozone got its start when bond investors began selling Greek government bonds. Whether an investor retreat from these markets starts a brush fire, as was the case last summer and earlier this year, or a wider conflagration remains to be seen. There are those who say that the fairly muted effect of the recent emerging market hiccups is proof that the investor exodus need not become a cataclysmic event.

This year, investors have pulled out close to US$40 billion from emerging market funds, according to the fund tracker EPFR Global - a figure that is fast approaching the US$51 billion that left these markets last year. Some of the most pronounced outflows have come from local-currency bond funds, which absorbed significant amounts of hot money during the liquidity boom. During a period when the Turkish lira, the Brazilian real and the Mexican peso were increasing in value - in line with surging economic growth - these local-currency funds invested in high-yielding government and corporate bonds and became the most popular funds for those seeking a maximum return.

As currencies such as the real and the lira have begun to wobble, the rush for the exit has become all the more hurried. In the last six months, for example, Pimco's local bond fund has lost about US$1.5 billion, reducing its size to US$10.7 billion. In the last two months alone, the fund has lost US$900 million. What worries Prof Shin and his co-authors is that this selling begets more of the same. Long-term investors, who in theory should act as a counterweight in such periods of panic by buying when others sell, are doing the opposite and heading for safer shores along with the rest of the market. This fear of "being the last one into a trade" could possibly "set off a race among investors to join a sell-off in a race to avoid being left behind", the authors of the paper conclude.

As Prof Shin and his co-authors point out, there is no regulatory mechanism in place that could, if needed, step in to address such a situation. No doubt, the International Monetary Fund would get involved, but addressing a market panic reaching from Rio de Janeiro to Beijing would be the most complex of tasks. The solution, they argue, is fairly straightforward: The Fed must remain vigilant in resisting pleas to halt its policy of tapering bond purchases.- NYT

SUBSCRIBERS

Luc Besson-style shoot-'em-up

Published

Thu, Mar 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN 3 Days to Kill, the CIA assassin played by Kevin Costner looks like he's suffering terribly while sleepwalking through Paris, coughing desperately and blowing his nose before blowing away his enemies.

That's because he's terminally ill, so ill in fact that on more than one occasion he collapses at the feet of a potential victim just as he's about to plug him between the eyes.

This is his fate - to kill or be killed. It's all Ethan Renner (Costner) has known for the past 32 years as a high-calibre hit man. "When you work for the agency it becomes your whole life," he sighs. Not any longer. Ethan wants out, now that his medical report has come back negative and he can't get rid of the crippling pain in his head.

What's more, he wants to use the few months he has left to reconnect with his rebellious teenage daughter Zooey (Hailee Steinfeld) and reconcile with his wife Christine (Connie Nielsen). When Christine goes away on a business trip, Ethan seizes the opportunity to quit the killing and ease back into life as a proper dad.

Then his CIA contact Vivi (Amber Heard) reels him in with an experimental drug that may or may not save his life. The snag: he has to locate an evil enforcer known as the Albino (Tomas Lemarquis) and kill his boss the Wolf (Richard Sammel). Worse, he can't even control Zooey. Oh, and there's a family of African squatters in his apartment.

Costner isn't the first gun-toting avenger to roam the streets in the City of Light. 3 Days to Kill is simply the latest in a long line of action-movie specimens to use Paris as a beautiful co-star.

Hardly surprising, of course, given that the film, directed by McG, is based on a story by Luc Besson and written by Besson with Adi Hasak. The same Monsieur Besson has his hand in the Taken and Transporter series, so any similarities are purely intentional.

site_title: Shipping-linked stocks drive BT Random Fund
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Shipping-linked stocks drive BT Random Fund

Environmental firm ecoWise Holdings replaces delisting Malacca Trust

Published

Tue, Mar 4, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE BT Random Fund, an experimental collection of 10 randomly picked stocks on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), recovered somewhat from a January dip to be down just 0.9 per cent for the year at end-February, continuing to beat the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) which is down 1.8 per cent.

The stable performance was in spite of illiquid, loss-making printing firm Craft Print International. The counter's only trade made in February was executed with a single lot changing hands at 2.1 cents, sending the counter down a whopping 22.2 per cent from its last traded price of 2.7 cents in December. Now, it is puzzling why someone would want to spend $21 of capital on a trade when minimum broking costs are $25, but the counter has to be kept alive somehow.

Luckily, our other illiquid, loss-making micro-cap, health supplement distributor Jacks International, saw five lots traded at 6.5 cents in a single day in February. This was the stock's only movement for the month with a value of just $325, but it was enough to send the counter up 6.6 per cent for the year.

Diversification is good. We countered one penny stock's plunge with another penny's rise. (Maybe this is what a certain minister means by "upturn the downturn". Just kidding.)

Meanwhile, all three shipping-related stocks in our portfolio posted stellar stock performances. Offshore support vessel maker Nam Cheong, a hot favourite among brokers, is up 7.9 per cent for the year. Last week, the company reported good full-year results and doubled its dividends. Shipbuilding margins were 21 per cent in the fourth quarter in 2013, ahead of consensus, noted broker DMG & Partners.

"We continue to like Nam Cheong for its strong growth, low valuations, high return on equity, strong order win momentum and orderbook, and asset-light strategy and business model," it said, as it raised its target price to 48 cents based on 10 times forecast 2014 earnings.

Singapore Shipping Corporation broke out of its half-year trading range towards the end of February to close at a seven-month high of 23.5 cents at end-February. Earlier in the month, the company reported that net profit was up 28 per cent at US$2 million and revenue was up 70 per cent at US$8.6 million for its third quarter ended Dec 31, 2013. This was due to the company having acquired terminal operations and logistics businesses last April. "The group is optimistic to expand and build up an even younger fleet with quality long-term charters," it said.

Meanwhile, container ship operator Rickmers Maritime made fourth-quarter losses due to impairment charges, but maintained its distributions and said the trust was "operationally robust". It continues to trade at a dividend yield of about 10 per cent.

Electronics manufacturer PCI Limited reported an 83 per cent improvement in second-quarter net profit for the period ended Dec 31, 2013, to US$2.6 million. It was helped by higher-margin products shipped and lower operating costs, but cautioned that it was entering a seasonally low-demand period in the next six months, with no clear sign of sustainable global growth.

Fellow electronics play AEI Corp, which makes precision aluminium extrusion products, reported a 59 per cent decline in net profit for 2013 to $2 million, and halved its dividends. It was hit by weak global personal computer demand.

China-based plastic package maker Southern Packaging Group also reduced its dividend payout, having reported weaker sales and profit for its 2013 financial year.

Meanwhile, OCBC Bank overcame lower life insurance and trading income to report stronger 2013 results, and said net interest margins should remain stable. The deadline for it to negotiate an exclusive deal to acquire Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank has been extended to the end of this month.

Finally, the privatisation of Indonesia-based financial firm Malacca Trust Limited was approved by Singapore Exchange (SGX) on Feb 19. The company has been replaced by another randomly picked counter, with buy-in prices pegged at end-2013 to facilitate easier reporting. The new counter is environmental firm ecoWise Holdings. More on that next time.

Overall, the fund remains stable, though it, like the STI, is underperforming world stocks. Both the S&P 500 and the MSCI World indices hit all-time highs at end-February, as developed markets shrugged off emerging market worries and a depreciating Chinese yuan. Where stocks are concerned, nobody likes Singapore that much, still.

site_title: Rising to the offshore challenge
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Rising to the offshore challenge

Shipowners are opting more for quality and durability in the building of their vessels than cost, reports MALMINDERJIT SINGH

Published

Tue, Mar 4, 2014 · 10:00 PM

CHINA is slowly losing its competitiveness as a low-cost shipbuilding destination for the offshore and marine industry.

Moreover, with serious shipowners opting for quality over price, Chinese shipyards are likely to up their game as they can no longer compete on price alone.

"The Chinese yuan continues to strengthen against the US dollar and Chinese labour costs continue to rise faster than in many South-east Asian countries. The Chinese yards are thus trying to move up the value chain as the Korean and the Japanese yards did a generation ago," George Horsington, president of business development at Jaya Holdings, told The Business Times.

Despite credit tightening in China, yards there are still able to offer attractive financing terms to shipowners for new builds.

"Chinese yards do have access to state bank financing unlike yards in Singapore and the Batam cluster. We have seen payment terms offered between the conventional 20:80 payment schedule as low as 5:95, which is unsustainable and exposes owners to issues with delays and corner-cutting," Mr Horsington adds.

Such compromises on quality and delivery schedules force many shipowners to look away. Mr Horsington explains that "state bank financing is likely to be more attractive to smaller, less established players, and is only part of the reason owners choose a yard".

Larger offshore and marine companies take a different view on contracting Chinese yards to build their vessels.

Mr Horsington observed: "A lot of the top-tier owners in the offshore sector have very strong balance sheets and are more concerned about timeliness of delivery and quality of build rather than cheap credit. Some players have large contingent liabilities from the payment terms offered in China by yards which ought to be factored into their balance sheets when assessing credit quality." In Singapore, the decision among shipowners to continue building with Chinese yards seems to be split along the lines of quality versus price.

Technical support

"Each owner (in Singapore) has their own strategy. I think some owners have been burnt in China and would be reluctant to return. Others place cheap build cost above all else, especially if they are not long-term owners and operators of the vessels," said Mr Horsington.

Regardless, industry players here still play an important role in the life cycle of a vessel built in China. According to Mr Horsington, most new builds from China come to Singapore for post-delivery work because the technical support available for offshore vessels in Singapore is much better than in China. This is because Singapore is positioned as the predominant Asia-Pacific hub for equipment manufacturers across the board.

The decline in appeal of Chinese yards is also due to another factor which affects demand for cheaper vessels. Since about 2009, a glut in the traditional shipping industry has seen more shipowners and shipbuilders make a transition to the more profitable and dynamic offshore and marine vessels segment. Even so, this trend has declined as a result of several push and pull factors.

"I think the recent recovery in bulk and tanker rates is reducing this trend as traditional blue water cargo vessel orders have recovered," suggested Mr Horsington.

Furthermore, challenges existed for those shipbuilders who made the switch, and this eventually turned them away.

"A lot of yards in China have tried moving into offshore and suddenly realised that it was much harder than they expected. Offshore vessels are small, complicated and very, very, specialised compared to tankers, bulkers and container vessels. The skills required to build the two categories of vessels are very different - cargo ships are about fabricating steel at the lowest cost per tonne; offshore vessels are about the value-add from special equipment such as cranes, dive systems, anchor handling winches and multiple cargo capacities. There is much more emphasis on electrical systems and automation in offshore vessels than in conventional, and more stringent requirements for fit out," he explained.

Even though some of the Chinese yards may have made incremental improvements in quality, they still lag behind their competition in the region in this aspect. "I think Singapore and Batam cluster yards still offer excellent quality, after-sales service and on-time delivery, which can offset improvements in China," Mr Horsington noted.

Indonesian yards, in particular, have risen in quality, said Mr Horsington, whose company Jaya Holdings itself has built its vessels in its Batam yard.

The Batam cluster has demonstrated its excellent commitment to quality, but most Batam-built offshore support vessels (OSVs) work outside Indonesia. We have vessels we have built in our Batam yard on hire to major international oil companies such as Statoil and Anadarko, which demonstrate that Batam yards can produce to the highest standards."

Indonesian industry players, though, admit that the shipbuilders in their country cannot compete with China on pricing.

"Indonesian shipyards for new building have never been price-competitive compared to China because of the taxes that apply to the shipbuilding industry (in Indonesia), even though we still have an advantage of a relatively low-cost labour. The only shipyards in (Indonesia that) have tax-free advantage is Batam as they are part of the free trade zone in Indonesia," Nova Mugijanto, CEO of the Pan Maritime Group, told BT.

This was reiterated by Djoni Sutji, president of PT Indonesia Bulk Carrier. "Indonesian shipyards are not as competitive to build a new ship compared to China or other countries that have incentives from the government. With the (raw) material almost all imported, and with no tax incentives, it is not really competitive yet to build a ship in Indonesia."

Even then, Mr Mugijanto, who is also the offshore marine division head at the Indonesian National Shipowners Association, added that shipowners looking to build small to medium-sized vessels with relatively not so high technology, may yet achieve cost advantages building in Indonesia.

Mr Sutji agreed that the Indonesian yards were more cost-effective for Singapore shipowners in building smaller and simpler vessels.

"It is dependent on the shipowner's requirement, but some still prefer to build in Indonesia for not too high-tech ships or smaller ships," he said.

He explained that this was because it was more convenient and cheaper for Singapore-based shipowners to monitor the progress of their vessel in construction and for smaller vessels, this factor weighed in favourably in its cost-benefit analysis. For bigger or high-tech vessels, such as large bulk carriers and LNG ships, Mr Sutji admitted that shipbuilders, including from Singapore, prefer building in more experienced and sophisticated yards in Japan, China, Korea and Singapore.

Cabotage law

However, industry players in Indonesia are optimistic that more shipowners from Singapore will increase their shipbuilding in Indonesia due to a new local content rule that the Indonesian government is implementing, in addition to a cabotage law that has already somewhat benefited the industry.

For starters, the cabotage law allowing only Indonesian-flagged vessels in the country, has helped improve the quality of shipbuilding in the yards there, revealed Mr Mugijanto.

"Because of the Indonesian cabotage policy since 2005, there are an additional 7,200 Indonesian-flagged vessels. Currently the total number of Indonesian-flagged vessels has already reached 13,224 units. Even though the majority are second-hand vessels, with the repair activities being done in Indonesia. So the ship repair business is booming. Because of that, the shipyard has the ability to improve their quality both for repair and new building."

He believes these standards in Indonesia will increase as more ship orders come in from Singapore due to the new local content rule. "Currently, the Indonesian government is trying to increase and boost 'Local Content'. Upcoming new build vessels, which are purchased using government funds, must be built in Indonesian shipyards. These include tankers for PT Pertamina, RORO Vessels for the Sea and Communication Department, Patrol Boats for the Customs, small and medium-sized OSVs for Indonesian oil and gas companies."

These rapid developments, including the trends of shipowners picking quality over price and traditional shipbuilders leaving the offshore and marine sector, will cause structural changes in the segment going forward, Mr Horsington pointed out.

"The offshore segment has always been very competitive and both in terms of shipowners and shipyards building in the sector, the market is very fragmented. We would expect to see more consolidation on both the yard front and the owner/operator front."

Another trend the industry veteran, who had spent 15 years with Swire Offshore Pacific before joining Jaya Holdings in 2012, pointed out was a potential change in the type of fuel and vessels the sector is likely to see going forward.

"The most likely trend in the OSV sector is going to be a move towards dual-fuel, LNG-powered hybrid vessels. LNG is going to take off as a source of fuel (in the sector). As a result, vessels will get larger to accommodate the extra tanks required. Diesel will not disappear but charterers will want to have the LNG option."

Lou Jiwei told a briefing at the National People's Congress (NPC), China's annual parliament meeting, that the government has three broad economic policy goals each year: create jobs, control inflation and boost the economy. He said jobs are the most important of the three.

site_title: Asia's ultra-wealthy to invest more in property: survey
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asia's ultra-wealthy to invest more in property: survey

S'pore remains a favoured location for a second home

Published

Wed, Mar 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Real estate remains a favoured asset class among ultra-high net worth individuals, and Singapore remains in their sights as a favoured location for a second home.

Knight Frank's The Wealth Report 2014 has found that 45 per cent of Asia's ultra-wealthy plan to invest more in property this year, compared to a global average of 47 per cent.

The wealthy in the Russia/Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) market are even more bullish at 71 per cent, followed by the Middle East market at 59 per cent.

Singapore's ultra- wealthy continue to favour the island republic as their most popular investment destination, despite the measures to cool the property market.

Alice Tan, Knight Frank's head of consultancy and research, said: "Despite the many rounds of cooling measures put in place by the government, interest in prime residential and commercial properties is still evident, as shown in the wealth attitude survey. The conducive business environment and tax regime, political stability and Singapore's growing status as a key regional financial hub are strong attributes embraced by the ultra-wealthy in Singapore and in Asia."

Overall, however, the UK is the top location for a second home, followed by Singapore, the US and Australia.

Individuals considered to be of ultra-high net worth are those with net assets of at least US$30 million excluding their home.

The survey, launched jointly with the Bank of Singapore, involved 600 private bankers and wealth advisers.

The results represent the views of more than 23,000 ultra-high net worth individuals worth US$68 million on average. In aggregate, the clients held some US$1.5 trillion in assets.

Knight Frank Asia-Pacific head of research Nicholas Holt said that there are some risks to residential property. One is the potential for higher interest rates. "If inflation starts to pick up . . . if (the US) unemployment drops further, we could see sooner-than-expected rise in interest rates."

For now, while the Federal Reserve has embarked on a tapering of quantitative easing measures, interest rates are not expected to rise until around 2015.

A second risk is political, and this includes further measures to dampen house prices. Dubai, for instance, has imposed mortgage restrictions.

In the report's global cities survey, which tracks the cities of most importance to the world's wealthiest, London retains the top spot this year, followed by New York and then Singapore. In 2024, however, New York is expected to take top spot, followed by London.

Singapore is expected to drop to fourth place, and Hong Kong, to rise to third. Shanghai is also expected to rise by a notch to fifth. By 2024, six out of the 10 top cities will be in the Asia-Pacific region, compared to five now.

Booming Asian markets dominate this year's Prime International Residential Index. Jakarta heads the index with annual growth of 38 per cent, similar to the rate it recorded in 2012. Bali took third place with a gain of 22 per cent.

Chinese markets also staged a recovery last year. Beijing prices rose 17 per cent, up from 2.3 per cent in 2012; Guangzhou rose 14 per cent.

Mr Holt said: "China, as always, has been difficult to predict, with the market continuing to defy expectations and several rounds of cooling measures. The reality is that in such an equity-driven market, the Tier 1 cities are likely to see both demand and pricing continue to head higher."

site_title: US Navy to buy 3 littoral ships next year instead of 4
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

US Navy to buy 3 littoral ships next year instead of 4

Published

Tue, Mar 4, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] The US Navy will request US$2.1 billion to continue developing the Littoral Combat Ship and buy three of the vessels in fiscal 2015, one fewer than previously planned, according to defence officials.

No decision has been made on which of the two companies building different versions - Lockheed Martin and Austal - will see one of its ships delayed by a year, according to one of the officials, who asked not to be identified before the Pentagon budget, for the year beginning on Oct 1, was sent to Congress yesterday.

The reduced pace of ship purchases underscores the budget constraints facing the Defense Department and may reflect what Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel last week called his "considerable reservations" about the Littoral Combat Ship, a lightly armed vessel designed for missions in shallow coastal waters.

The ship is intended to operate in a "relatively permissive environment", and the Pentagon must "closely examine" whether the vessel "has the protection and firepower to survive against a more advanced military adversary and emerging new technologies, especially in the Asia-Pacific", Mr Hagel said.

The US$2.1 billion for the Littoral Combat Ship is part of the Defense Department's weapons-buying request for fiscal 2015 of about US$91 billion, or US$15.2 billion less than previously projected. The request also includes US$64 billion for research and development, or US$8.8 billion less than forecast, according to internal budget figures.

The Navy's request also will include US$2.1 billion for a new class of aircraft carriers, funding research and procurement for the Gerald R Ford and John F Kennedy vessels, an increase from US$1.6 billion this year and US$781.7 million in fiscal 2013, according to Navy budget figures. Carriers are built and refurbished by Huntington Ingalls Industries.

In presenting his budget outline last week, Mr Hagel said that current plans foresee the Navy keeping 11 aircraft carrier groups. That may decline to 10 groups because plans to refuel and overhaul the ageing George Washington will have to be cancelled unless automatic budget cuts, known as sequestration, are eased for future years, he said.

On the Littoral Combat Ship from Bethesda, Maryland-based Lockheed and Henderson, Australia-based Austal, Mr Hagel barred planning for any more than 32 of the vessels, 20 fewer than the Navy's US$34 billion programme goal. He instructed Navy Secretary Ray Mabus to review the ship's performance and to prepare alternative proposals for a small combatant vessel "generally consistent with the capabilities of a frigate". Mr Hagel set out options including a completely new ship design, existing vessels including the Littoral Combat Ship or a modified version of it.- Bloomberg

SUBSCRIBERS

Emerging market slump a chance to invest: Maersk

Published

Mon, Mar 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[COPENHAGEN] AP Moeller-Maersk A/S, Denmark's biggest company, is using a slump in emerging markets (EM) as an opportunity to invest, chief executive officer Nils Smedegaard Andersen said.

"When we invest in ports and other infrastructure projects, we're often competing with financial investors," the 55-year-old CEO said in a phone interview. "With fewer financial investors interested in growth markets, that can open up investment opportunities for us."

Maersk, which owns a container line, a port operator and an oil division, invested about US$7 billion globally last year, focusing on emerging markets. This year's rout from Argentina to India won't prompt the company to scale back its commitment to the group of countries, Mr Andersen said.

"I will travel a lot to emerging markets this year, which is where the biggest opportunities for infrastructure investment are," he said. His company employs 89,000 people in 135 countries. "I was in Africa for a few weeks earlier this year and have scheduled travels to China and South America. Our investment strategy will focus on these growth markets. We have to think counter-cyclical."

Investors have fled emerging markets this year as the US Federal Reserve pares its record stimulus measures. A slowdown in manufacturing in China and political unrest in Ukraine have added to the uncertainty. Global investors pulled US$3 billion from emerging-market funds in the week ended Feb 26, the 18th week of outflows, according to Citigroup, which cited data from EPFR Global.

An exit by short-term investors from emerging markets will help buyers such as Maersk generate bigger returns, Mr Andersen said. "In general, these financial investors tend to settle for lower returns than we do; we want double-digit returns."

Maersk's investments last year included container terminals in Brazil, Mexico and Russia and building up its oil exploration business in offshore Angola.

"When we invest in a port in a growth market, we spend a mix of the local currency and US dollars, so in the short term, our investment costs may be a bit lower," he said. "And when the port is up and running, we tend to get payments in dollars in the transport industry, so in that way, we're pretty well covered."

Maersk is planning to shift some investments to its oil, ports and drilling businesses and away from its container line division, which has been hurt by overcapacity in the industry.

Maersk's earnings before interest and taxes fell to 9.46 billion kroner (S$2.2 billion) for the fourth quarter, the company said last week. - Bloomberg

content:

China buyers to prop up Aussie home prices

Investment over next seven years can push home prices even higher: study

Published

Wed, Mar 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] Wealthy Chinese will pour A$44 billion (S$50 billion) into Australian real estate over the next seven years, potentially pushing prices in one of the world's most expensive housing markets even higher, a study said yesterday.

Investment bank Credit Suisse used data from the Foreign Investment Review Board and other government agencies to estimate the amount of Chinese investment in Australian residential property at more than A$5 billion a year.

"They purchased $24 billion of Australian housing over the past seven years; we forecast they will purchase $44 billion over the next seven, to 2020," it said.

As the Asian powerhouse becomes richer, the ranks of those who could easily afford Australian real estate will swell beyond the current 1.1 million people, with implications for Australian home-buyers, it said.

"While Australia has some of the most unaffordable housing in the world, further strong Chinese demand can push prices even higher," it said. "A generation of Australians are being priced out of the property market. Many face a lifetime of renting."

Australia has one of the most expensive real estate markets in the world on a house price to income ratio, while median house prices in Sydney and Melbourne have risen by more than 30 per cent since the global financial crisis.

Chinese investment is welcomed by the Australian government, although it has become a sensitive issue after rural politicians warned against selling valuable farm and mineral land to foreigners.

The Credit Suisse report found that Chinese buyers - some of whom are restricted to buying only new homes - bought 12 per cent of new housing nationally per annum, an amount considered insufficient to drive prices up across Australia.

But because they are concentrating their buying in the east coast cities of Sydney and Melbourne - where they are acquiring 18 per cent and 14 per cent of new supply - they were a much more powerful force in these markets, it said.

The report said that the emergence of the global property investor meant traditional valuation methods - such as the ratio of house price to local income - were becoming obsolete.

"Residents of central London have known this for some time. Many of which are well-paid investment bankers but are still struggling to buy in the capital where many of the owners are wealthy individuals from the Middle East, North Africa and other parts of Europe," it said. - AFP

site_title: Economists divided over Reit impact on business
content:
Economists divided over Reit impact on business

Published

Wed, Mar 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Calls in Parliament for the government to rein in industrial and commercial rents or reverse JTC's land divestment programme to "buy back some of the Reits" have sparked mixed responses from market watchers, with some in agreement and others cautioning against tinkering with free market principles.

A decade ago, JTC divested most of its industrial property, saying at the time that the move would create a more open and vibrant market by giving the private sector more freedom to operate flexibly to accommodate industry needs.

On Tuesday, however, Member of Parliament Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio) called the divestment "a mistaken policy" during the Budget debate. "The government lost the ability to influence rental prices resulting in developers and investors (including Reits) making the money - this is passive income and not productive income benefiting the investors," he said.

It's a debate that has been cropping up in recent years as businesses reel from rising costs. Some economists agree that Singapore has over-embraced its free market approach and needs to recalibrate, especially with the proliferation of real estate investment trusts (Reits).

Irvin Seah of DBS, for instance, feels that Singapore has overdone what it set out to achieve and should backpedal. He believes that a sizeable amount of commercial and industrial property should come under government control to serve as a benchmark for the market.

"Right now, what we have is an oligolopolistic structure, with a small group of players in this market, which makes it prone to price rigging," he said.

"It is not so much about bringing prices down, but about ensuring that we have a lever on certain scarce resources (such as land). The Reit model may work in big countries with ample land but less so for land-scarce Singapore."

Yet, others found Mr Singh's suggestion too "drastic" and "excessive". They warned against being too quick to point fingers at Reits as the culprit for rising business rents. Rather, they suggested that it could be a case of supply lagging demand.

CIMB economist Song Seng Wun said: "Everyone forgot while squabbling on the ground level who's to blame, but if you take a few steps back, it is because there is plenty of demand for space out there. Economics 101: this allows landlords to yank up rentals."

In this case, solving the supply problem may prove more effective. Patience is also needed because physical completion of properties takes time, he said. It may even be a good problem to have if landlords have no difficulty finding tenants for commercial and industrial spaces as this may mean Singapore has been successful in attracting businesses that want to expand here, he added.

Several commercial and industrial Reits that BT contacted did not want to comment, but an industry player who declined to be named said that Reits themselves also face the same problems of rising costs that tenants face, including labour (for security guards and cleaners, for instance), land rents and property taxes, which help to justify rent adjustments.

That is not to say that profit is not on Reit managers' minds when they revise rents. It is the landlords' playground now, and they are motivated to maximise their return on investment, given that they are listed vehicles and answerable to unitholders, said the industry player.

This leads them to raise rents when they think the market can take it, while taking care not to tip the balance, lest their tenants pull down their shutters and leave, which is not in their interests either.

For Reits, the question is "how much can you push prices before businesses need a breather?", noted CIMB's Mr Song.

On Monday, Nominated MP R Dhinakaran also warned of the danger of the speculative element in commercial and industrial property. "An asset value being pushed higher by several times makes little sense with no significant underlying change to the value offered to (the) tenant . . . If the asset value is fuelled by trading on a speculative basis without any underlying benefit changing (such as higher traffic for the tenant), it is bound to disrupt economics for the operating business," he said.

But the industry player pointed out that JTC has tightened conditions on lease assignments to discourage "flipping" - such as implementing longer prohibition periods before sellers can sell the property, as well as a longer minimum occupation period for anchor tenants in sale and leaseback programmes.

SUBSCRIBERS

Amtek to lift itself out of HDD slump with US$210m deal

Purchase of Interplex will boost its global sales to about US$1b

Published

Tue, Mar 4, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN A deal aimed at lifting it beyond the declining hard disk drive (HDD) market, local precision engineer Amtek Engineering yesterday announced its purchase of US firm Interplex Industries for up to US$210 million.

The acquisition comprises US$165 million of enterprise value, a US$11 million deferred payment and up to US$34 million of incentive payments, depending on subsequent performance.

In contrast to Amtek, which makes larger components, Interplex makes miniature components for blue-chip customers in a variety of industries, including the auto, industrial and electrical, mobile devices and medical markets. Interplex customers include names like tech giant Apple, auto suppliers Bosch, Denso and TRW, and car manufacturer Continental.

It is in supplying to the auto industry that the greatest benefits of the deal can be found, Amtek chief executive and chairman Daniel Yeong told The Business Times yesterday.

"Customers who asked us to build car steering columns for them also want us to build modules, connectors that we don't know how to do. Now, customers will be very happy because we are truly end-to-end," he said.

He added that the precision-engineering sector in Singapore had been too dependent on the HDD market. This market has been on the wane along with the personal computer market, with mobile devices gaining prominence. Asian precision-engineering firms have also centred around HDD manufacturing, he said.

"One of the things we had to do was to take this company out of hard drives and out of the Asia market. China is also not going to be the world factory for everything because costs are rising," he said.

With Interplex's factories being in places like the US, Mexico, India and Hungary, Amtek will become a truly global firm, Mr Yeong said. Amtek's network now spans China, Vietnam, the Czech Republic, Malaysia and Singapore.

"Customers want us to be where they produce and where they sell. So we need to add the US, we need to add Mexico to address the Latin American and South American market; India is important as an alternative to China, and we also need a good presence in Europe," he added.

Amtek's acquisition will also mean it will now have global sales of about US$1 billion. "If you're smaller, the customer is also afraid to put too many eggs into a small company. We've crossed the psychological barrier of US$1 billion in revenue to do business with larger customers."

Interplex Industries was founded some 56 years ago by chairman and chief executive Jack Seidler, now 88.

In the six months to last Nov 30, Interplex generated revenues of US$182.4 million and pro forma Ebitda (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation) of US$16.5 million. Amtek is thus acquiring Interplex at around five times Ebitda - a multiple that Mr Yeong said was hard to go lower. "Some transactions are happening around us at seven to eight times, so five is a good price," he said.

The acquisition will be funded mostly by debt. Net debt is expected to rise from US$41.6 million to US$233.9 million. Gearing thus jumps from 24 per cent to 134.6 per cent. "This gearing level is still considered quite good. Most companies who are very aggressive will gear up to 300 to 400 per cent. For us, keeping it below 200 per cent is important," Mr Yeong said.

As an illustration of the financial effects, earnings per share for Amtek are expected to grow from 4.93 US cents to 5.18 US cents after the deal. Upon approval of Amtek shareholders and regulators, the deal is expected to be completed in the second half of the year.

Amtek shares closed at 54 cents, up 1.5 cents or 2.9 per cent, before the deal was announced.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

IAG group back in the black

Published

Sun, Mar 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] International Airlines Group soared back into net profit last year on a strong performance from its British Airways unit and from recently-acquired Spanish budget carrier Vueling, the company said.

Profits after tax stood at 122 million euros (S$214 million) last year, IAG said. IAG had suffered a net loss of 716 million euros in 2012. Revenues grew 3.1 per cent to 18.7 billion euros and fuel costs slid 2.5 per cent to 5.95 billion euros.

"In 2013, we strengthened the group by acquiring Vueling, embarking on Iberia's transformation and enhancing British Airways' revenue performance," said chief executive Willie Walsh.

Group operating profit, stripping out taxes and one-off costs, stood at 770 million euros compared with a loss of 23 million euros in 2012. BA benefited also from additional slots at London's Heathrow airport following integration of bmi, the no-frills carrier that IAG purchased in 2012 from German rival Lufthansa.

At the same time, Spanish carrier Iberia slashed its operating loss to 166 million euros compared with 351 million euros last time around. "Iberia has made huge progress on cost control as its restructuring takes shape and great credit should be given to all those involved," Mr Walsh said. He added that recent pay agreements between Iberia and its pilot and cabin crew unions were key to reducing the airline's costs further and "providing the foundation for profitable growth".

Looking ahead, IAG forecast that it would make "steady progress" this year towards its 2015 group operating profit target of 1.8 billion euros.- AFP

site_title: Something for everyone
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Something for everyone

What stood out in the 2014 Budget for your company or industry? What more can or should be done to meet specific business or socio-economic needs at this juncture?

Published

Sun, Mar 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Tham Sai Choy

Managing Partner

KPMG in Singapore

BUDGET 2014 is very much a people's Budget, with the government demonstrating its commitment towards addressing concerns from all segments of society.

From a business perspective, the extension of the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme and R&D tax incentive will definitely offer much-needed support to businesses in their productivity and innovation drive. We have been advocating adjustments to the PIC scheme so that it is more accessible to local SMEs. Therefore, we are very pleased with the introduction of PIC+ as there is now finally a tax incentive targeted specifically at SMEs.

However, even more can be done to simplify our tax regime. We ought to adopt a principle-based approach and move away from prescriptive rules so that businesses can access available benefits more easily. We were also hoping to see a tax allowance for self-generated brands to address the tax disparity between brand purchases and developers.

As an individual taxpayer, I am very impressed with the generous Pioneer Generation Package. This initiative sends out a very important message: We are a nation that remembers the hard work of its pioneers. In all, Budget 2014 is an uplifting one with something for everyone, ranging from enhanced subsidies for students to increased CPF contributions for all workers.

Max Loh

Country Managing Partner

Ernst & Young LLP

THE Pioneer Generation Package is a defining feature of Budget 2014. This is an excellent initiative that upholds the values of Singapore as an integrated and equitable society. The best part of this is the promise of support being funded regardless of future economic conditions. It is such forward thinking, fiscal discipline and willingness to shoulder responsibility that has distinguished Singapore for half a century.

As for tax measures, the improvements to the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) and financial services sector are important. Productivity and innovation remain at centrestage, with the PIC seeking to entice businesses to improve. Some may be disappointed that there were not more tax measures to boost business. This is not surprising - Singapore's tax system is already competitive. The main reason that businesses want to be here is favourable infrastructure in the broadest sense - stability and the rule of law, education and skills, transport and communications.

What is needed are further adjustments towards greater simplicity, transparency and certainty on the tax front. These need not be part of the annual Budget process but instead a continual process of incremental improvement.

Dora Hoan

Co-Chairman/Group CEO

Best World International Ltd

OUR collective wish for the extension of the PIC was heard and granted in the Budget. In addition, we will get to enjoy higher tax deductions with the expenditure limit being raised from $400,000 to $600,000. This is greatly beneficial to raising productivity.

Besides the PIC, the Infocomm Technology (ICT) for Productivity and Growth Programme (IPG) will be helpful for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to improve their technology.

However, companies are unique and hence, the "proven solutions" may not be suitable for some. While they can try to pilot new solutions, the risks and resources involved may be too high. Perhaps the government may wish to review this policy more.

There is another measure that stood out - the increase in employers' contribution to CPF. This is good for employees but costly to employers. Nevertheless, we are glad that this will only be implemented from next year, giving us enough time to plan our budgets.

Rod Rodericks

Vice-President and Managing Director, APAC

Zebra Technologies

THE government's continued investment in its productivity-driven restructuring of the economy is a positive sign for Singapore. In Budget 2014, the government has identified ICT as being critical in enabling businesses, particularly SMEs, transition from labour-driven to innovation-driven growth.

Facing challenges such as the manpower crunch, rising cost and growing competition, businesses need to leverage on technologies such as the Internet of Things to gain greater visibility and better business agility with a smaller but smarter workforce.

For example, by equipping their workforce with mobile point of sale (POS) systems and integrating smart tags to their stocks, retailers can significantly streamline and increase the accuracy of inventory and payment processes. On this front, initiatives which encourage the adoption of proven solutions and the development of emerging technology within the IPG and PIC schemes will play a significant role in helping Singapore SMEs make the productivity leap.

Yeoh Oon Jin

Executive Chairman

PwC Singapore

MOST of the measures proposed in the 2014 Budget focus on assisting SMEs to increase productivity and innovation. Singapore-based companies are also encouraged to expand overseas. These are necessary moves and should be applauded.

However, I feel that more could be done to anchor greater investments by foreign multinational corporations (MNCs) into Singapore. While there has been much global rhetoric about low tax jurisdictions, Singapore remains an exception because of our location as a strategic hub in this region and globally, and has also grown to be an attractive and very liveable city. This has encouraged many MNCs to locate their C-suite and key assets in Singapore. We must continue to enhance this unique position with pride.

Singapore should continue to encourage foreign MNCs to increase their footprint in Singapore. The Budget should have included further measures to incentivise MNCs to bring greater and real economic activities, assets, etc into Singapore that can withstand scrutiny from any domestic or foreign interest groups.

In parallel, the Budget could also have been more innovative by introducing other self-compliance measures even though Singapore has already committed to meet international standards through greater transparency and exchange of information.

My hope is that we can take some off-Budget measures to do so.

Tim Moylan

President, Asia Pacific

Infor

THIS year's Budget includes strong incentives for SMEs to raise productivity, innovation and competitiveness - thereby the extension of the PIC scheme to 2018. By leveraging initiatives that encourage investment in technology, SMEs will be in a better position to seek new business growth opportunities and creatively solve common challenges faced in today's resource-constrained world.

Investing in enterprise resource planning solutions will help SMEs improve efficiency and cost effectiveness as it allows them to have better insight into internal operations and costs as well as the foresight to enable better planning. In short, the opportunity to work smarter by harnessing technology enables SMEs to level up the playing field and be better poised to compete with the larger players. SMEs who understand that technology is not just a tool for large corporations can better streamline business processes to achieve that competitive advantage, and become stronger in the long run.

Hugues Delcourt

Country Executive Singapore & CEO Private Banking Asia & Middle East

ABN AMRO Bank NV

WHAT stood out most about the 2014 Budget was its focus on quality sustainable growth while building a fair and equitable society. From the pioneer generation that shaped what Singapore has become to supporting aspiring companies set to shape Singapore's future, there was something for everyone.

For our business, this year's Budget aimed to continue strengthening the competitiveness of the financial sector and create a stable business environment in Singapore. While we welcome the extension of productivity and tax incentive schemes, it would have been good to see even greater enhancements or new initiatives to address the main concerns for businesses in Singapore - rising operating costs and a tightening labour market. We need to continually improve Singapore's attractiveness as a global financial hub and key destination for foreign investments. In today's ever-changing global environment, there a greater need now than ever before to set Singapore apart from our peers.

While the focus continues on building Singapore's enduring competitive advantage, I would also welcome continued support from the government for arts and culture funding, which is an important soft aspect for the well-known Singapore brand. We are pleased to see that Singapore's arts and cultural landscape has flourished and grown significantly over the years, and our bank welcomes this encouraging trend. At ABN AMRO, we will continue to play our part to support relevant arts and culture initiatives to engage different stakeholders in our local community.

Philip Yuen

Chief Executive Officer

Deloitte Singapore

THE 2014 Budget is a balancing act as the government strives to achieve sustainable wage increases and increased standards of living. While the employer CPF rate hike for 55-year-olds and above was largely anticipated, the increase across the board was a surprise and will increase employment costs. While the government will subsidise half the increase in 2016, employers nonetheless will bear the full cost thereafter.

The big Budget winners are SMEs, as targeted measures like PIC+ and various financial supports are structured to help them grow, expand overseas and invest in productivity. Enterprises will need to be proactive in investing and taking advantage of available schemes. For SMEs still struggling to get by, more assistance to facilitate business consolidation to cope with transformation would help.

For the Budget to achieve its intended effects, there must be change in social norms and attitudes. This mindset change will not be easy, but is necessary.

Stevan Hoyle

President of Asia and Africa

Vodafone Global Enterprise

ACCORDING to the 2014 Budget, healthcare costs will be one of the main drivers of higher social spending in the next 10-15 years as Singaporeans age and the need for quality care increases.

To address the challenge of providing quality affordable care, the healthcare sector can leverage new Machine to Machine (M2M) and SMS technologies that enable healthcare practitioners to use mobile services that are prevalent in today's society.

M2M can free up valuable resources for the healthcare sector by extending the reach of care beyond the hospital as patients will be able to receive care in their homes. For patients, M2M allows them to be connected to their healthcare provider in ways that weren't previously possible and provides the peace of mind of constant monitoring and support via wireless mobile devices.

The government's focus on improving the affordability of health care, coupled with the healthcare sector's adoption of the latest in ICT technologies, can provide Singaporeans the quality care they need and deserve.

Craig Tegel

Regional President

Adobe Japan and Asia Pacific

A COUPLE of initiatives stood out for us in the 2014 Budget - mainly the focus on the education system, ICT as well as innovation - and at Adobe, we are firm supporters of all the three focus areas.

Education plays a critical role in moulding our young and preparing them for the future. As the Budget highlights the government's support for early adopters of ICT, the implementation of such solutions will need to be a focus in the education sector. There is a need for today's educators to develop more engaging curriculum for digital-native students as the ways of teaching and learning have evolved drastically over the years, thanks to the explosion of mobile devices. With the introduction of ICT solutions in the classroom, we believe that this will have a positive impact in not only fostering collaboration and innovation among students but also enabling them to discover new ways of learning. Students can in turn take these skills with them as they enter the workforce and contribute to Singapore's economy.

Michael Cornwell

Vice-President, Asia Pacific & Japan

Pure Storage

SINGAPORE'S goal of becoming Asia's innovation hub requires moving beyond just a hub for large multinational industries to focusing on developing local SMEs. The Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) of Singapore has set its sights on solving this by building talent and adopting technologies that can help SMEs become more productive to stay competitive in our current economic climate.

The IDA investment in subsidised Fibre Broadband connectivity is an important first step but only removes one bottleneck impacting these SMEs today. The key investment that companies need to be looking at is storage - all flash storage in particular, to enable true growth and innovation.

For years, storage functionality has been a limiter on what companies can do with the data they have at hand. Back then, we simply could not cope with the complexity and amount of information needed to make business decisions. Today, the demand for instant access to data for making business decisions has been solved elsewhere by not just high-speed connectivity but advancements in storage technologies such as all flash storage that remove the storage complexity and bottlenecks for these SMEs.

The PIC scheme and IDA's IPG programme in particular will push the envelope on investing in emerging solutions that enable data analytics. Through this, it will enable companies in Singapore to increase their productivity and efficiency.

I strongly believe that the day will come where companies realise the endless possibilities that data analytics can provide them, with storage not as a limiter but an enabler of value to their business and their customers.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

Plan-B ICAG Pte Ltd

THE Pioneer Generation Package in the 2014 Budget is extraordinary and revolutionary. It marks a significant shift in the government's efforts to tackle social problems. It will be remembered for a long time to come, by the pioneers, as they will benefit from it throughout their lifetime, as well as the younger generation, as the burden to support the pioneers has been eased.
