However, health care should not just be the responsibility of government. Industry can also participate and contribute to health care, especially in the current situation where demand is outstripping supply of services.

This undesirable situation is due in large part to the ageing population and entrenched consumer behaviour - for example, the tendency to go to A&E without ascertaining the need. There is also increased urgency to achieve better healthcare delivery in the new continuum from primary care in acute hospitals, to step-down care in community hospitals, and to home care.

It would therefore have been more complete if the 2014 Budget had introduced incentives to harness more private sector participation. Businesses and entreprenuers can complement the government in tackling the many challenges facing health care in Singapore. Many single, poor and old Singaporeans who had worked hard in their young days to help build the Singapore that we now take for granted will benefit from this scheme. Some do not have proper medical care, and the package of healthcare perks will help them greatly.

Singapore succeeded in the last 50 years largely due to the hard work of every individual, and many have moved out of poverty. Many have made good in their career and business. We must ensure that this social mobility continues in our society, especially when income divide is becoming a major global social issue.

Many initiatives to encourage innovation and productivity are good. However, the government needs to take appropriate measures to assist SMEs to tap the schemes by helping them to overcome cashflow issues. Many improvement possibilities require upfront cash investments before the company can receive financial support. Those that are cash-strapped will not be able to take advantage of the schemes offered.

Richard Hong

CEO

TÜV SÜD Asean

OUR business is about testing, certification, auditing and inspection, so what we do is tightly correlated to technology. In fact, we must be on a par with or even ahead of technological advancements so that we fulfil our commitment of protecting mankind and the natural environment against risks from new technologies. We are very encouraged by the Singapore government's decision to continue extensive R&D expenditure tax deductions as we procure costly testing and inspection equipment to pursue new discoveries that will benefit Singapore at large.

We are also happy about the government's decision to offer more support for companies expanding overseas. With the vision of an upcoming single Asean economic market, this is very timely as we are now actively seeking new opportunities in emerging economies such as Myanmar and Cambodia, and investing aggressively elsewhere in the region. Singapore is TÜV SÜD's first stop in Asia and we chose Singapore as our Asian HQ mostly due to the positive business environment built by the Singapore government. The pro-growth incentives announced at Budget 2014 reinforce our determination to remain in Singapore and play our part in building this economy.

Rangu Salgame

Chief Executive Officer

Growth Ventures for Tata Communications

WITH globalisation and continuous development in technology, this year's Budget include incentives and support for local companies to internationalise their operations. As a business, our global reach and market-leading connectivity give our customers the speed to market that is required to keep them ahead of the game in terms of local operations and international expansion.

We have chosen Singapore as our international headquarters - and over the past few years, have invested considerably in the country; by not only supporting local job creation but also by bringing in new skillsets and technologies into the region. Looking ahead, Tata Communications continues to focus on Singapore with significant investments into infrastructure and technologies around cloud enablement and unified communications, all of which are aimed at equipping businesses of the future. Our global customers find our commitment to Singapore important as part of their globalisation strategies - particularly those with a focus on Asia.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Purchases down, sales and buybacks go up

Published

Sun, Mar 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THERE was less buying and more selling among directors in the last week of February. Singapore Exchange filings in that week showed nine companies recording 17 purchases with a value of $2.29 million and four firms with 11 disposals worth $240,000. The buy figures were sharply lower than the previous week's 15 companies, 26 purchases and $8.76 million. Saleswere up from the previous week's three firms, three disposals and $220,000.

While the buying by directors fell, buyback activity rose for the second straight week with 10 companies that posted 41 repurchases worth $11.3 million. The figures were up from the previous week's nine firms, 30 trades and $5.3 million. Among the companies that bought back last week were Chip Eng Seng Corporation, Keong Hong Holdings and XinRen Aluminum Holdings. Aside from the buybacks, there were insider purchases in Heeton Holdings, Matex International and Serial System. On the funds' front, Schroders boosted its stake in Mapletree Commercial Trust after the counter fell by 23 per cent while The Capital Group Companies acquired shares of KrisEnergy Ltd at sharply lower than its initial filing price in November last year.

Chip Eng Seng Corporation

Construction firm Chip Eng Seng Corporation bought back for the first time since December 2013 with 4.78 million shares purchased from Feb 25 to 26 at an average of 74.2 cents each. The trades were made after the stock rebounded by 9 per cent from 68 cents on Feb 5. The buybacks were also made after the company announced on Feb 20 a 11.7 per cent drop in fourth-quarter profit to $34.634 million while earnings for the full year fell by 9.7 per cent to $73.374 million. The group previously acquired 1.5 million shares from Dec 26 to 30, 2013, at an average of 71.8 cents each, 13.81 million shares from Dec 3 to 31, 2012, at 49.2 cents to 60.2 cents each or an average of 55.6 cents each and 3.86 million shares from November to December 2007 at an average of 60.4 cents each. The counter closed at 74.5 cents on Friday.

Keong Hong Holdings

Building construction services provider Keong Hong Holdings bought back for the first time since February 2013 with 72,000 shares purchased on Feb 28 at 57 cents each. The trade was made on the back of the 12 per cent drop in the share price since December 2013 from 65 cents. Despite the fall in the share price, the counter is still up since March 2013 from 50.5 cents. The group previously acquired four million shares in February 2013 at 54 cents each. The repurchases since February 2013 are the company's first buybacks since the stock was listed in December 2011. The group's purchase prices were sharply higher than the IPO price of 24 cents. The counter closed at 57 cents on Friday.

XinRen Aluminum Holdings

Aluminium manufacturer and distributor XinRen Aluminum Holdings bought back for the first time since May 2012 with three million shares purchased from Feb 26 to 28 at an average of 38.2 cents each. The trades, which accounted for 29 per cent of the stock's trading volume, were made on the back of the 70 per cent rebound in the share price since November 2013 from 22.5 cents. The acquisitions were also made after the company announced on Feb 25 a year-end profit of RMB 61.598 million versus a loss of RMB 65.832 million in the previous year. The group previously acquired one million shares in May 2012 at 30 cents each, 1.18 million shares in February 2012 at 38 cents each and 1.8 million shares from June to August 2011 at an average of 33.2 cents each. The counter closed at 40 cents on Friday.

Heeton Holdings

CEO and managing director Toh Giap Eng picked up where he left off in property play Heeton Holdings in August 2013 with 60,000 shares purchased from Feb 25 to 26 at an average of 62.7 cents each. The trades increased his direct holdings to 25.858 million shares or 9.63 per cent of the issued capital. The purchases were made after Heeton announced an 85.4 per cent drop in fourth-quarter profit after tax to $6.069 million while earnings for the full year fell 65.2 per cent to $18.349 million. He previously acquired 100,000 shares in August 2013 at 66 cents each. Prior to his purchases since August 2013, Mr Toh acquired 2.388 million shares from August to November 2008 at 29 cents to 17 cents each or an average of 21.7 cents each and 350,000 shares in November 2007 at 58 cents each. The counter closed at 62 cents on Friday.

Matex International

Executive director Tan Guan Liang recorded his first on-market trade in specialty chemicals manufacturer Matex International since his appointment in 2010. He bought 510,000 shares (direct interest) on Feb 24 at 6.2 cents each. The shares bought represented 0.22 per cent of the issued capital. The acquisition was made on the back of the 42 per cent drop in the share price since September 2013 from 10.6 cents. The counter is also sharply down since April 2013 from 24.5 cents. The purchase was also made after the company announced on Feb 22 a year-end profit after tax of $0.492 million, reversing the loss of $5.526 million in the previous year. The counter closed at six cents on Friday.

Serial System

Chairman and CEO Goh Bak Heng picked up where he left off in semiconductors/components distributor and consumer appliances firm Serial System in January with 2.5 million shares purchased from Feb 20 to 27 at an average of 13.3 cents each. The trades, which accounted for 11 per cent of the stock's trading volume, increased his direct holdings to 338.093 million shares or 37.74 per cent. The purchases were made after Serial System announced on Feb 19 a 52 per cent gain in fourth quarter profit after tax to US$3.029 million while earnings for the full year rose by 43 per cent to US$11.395 million.

Mr Goh previously acquired 5.037 million shares from Dec 20, 2013, to Jan 2 and 8.57 million shares from February to August 2013 at an average of 12.8 cents each. Prior to those purchases, he acquired 8.5 million shares from August to November 2012 at an average of 10.9 cents each and 7.45 million shares from February to March 2012 at an average of 12.7 cents each. The counter closed at 13.5 cents on Friday.

Mapletree Commercial Trust

Schroders plc became a substantial shareholder of real estate investment trust Mapletree Commercial Trust on Feb 24 following the purchase of 74,000 units at $1.18 each. The trade increased its deemed holdings to 103.926 million units or 5.0 per cent.

The initial filing was made on the back of the 23 per cent drop in the unit price since May 2013 from $1.53.

Despite the fall in the unit price, the counter is still up since October 2011 from 80 cents. Also positive this month is non-executive director Hiew Yoon Khong with 210,000 units purchased on Feb 17 at $1.19 each, which boosted his deemed stake by 11 per cent to 2.210 million units or 0.1 per cent. He also has direct interest of 489,000 units (0.02 per cent). He previously acquired 200,000 units in October 2013 at $1.27 each and 600,000 units in June 2013 at $1.22 each. The unit trust closed at $1.21 on Friday.

KrisEnergy Ltd

The Capital Group Companies acquired 1.28 million shares of oil and gas explorer and producer KrisEnergy Ltd on Feb 21 at 77 cents each. The trade increased its deemed holdings to 62.998 million shares or 6.02 per cent of the issued capital. The filing was made on the back of the 41 per cent drop in the share price since the last week of November 2013 from $1.315. The group previously reported an initial filing on Nov 18, 2013, of 758,000 shares at $1.21 each, which raised its interest to 5.01 per cent.

Overall, The Capital Group's stake is up by 20 per cent since that initial filing in November 2013. The purchases since then are the first corporate shareholder trades in KrisEnergy since the stock was listed in July 2013. The shareholder's last purchase price was lower than the IPO price of $1.10. KrisEnergy announced on Feb 28 a year-end loss after tax of US$12.645 million, which was lower than the loss of US$17.737 million in the previous year. The counter closed at 75.5 cents on Friday.

The writer is managing director, Asia Insider Ltd

site_title: US stock market shrugs off weak economic data
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

US stock market shrugs off weak economic data

Status quo likely to continue, barring an international war

Published

Sun, Mar 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THIS week, the US stock market will most likely continue to bounce around near record highs as traders try to ascertain if the recent wave of weak data is bad enough to prompt a pause in "tapering".

All bets will be off, however, if internal upheaval in the Ukraine metastasises into an international conflict. Viktor Yanukovych, the pro-Russian president of the former Soviet state, was ousted last week. But his supporters in the ethnically Russian Crimean peninsula are militating against the new government in Kiev with the apparent support of Russian troops.

On Friday, President Barack Obama said he was deeply concerned by reports that Russia is intervening in the Crimea, warning "there will be costs" if it continues. The last time a major conventional army marched into a neighbouring nation was Saddam Hussein's incursion in Kuwait, which sparked decades of conflict.

"You do want to pay attention to things in the Ukraine," said Quincy Krosby, investment strategist at Prudential Financial. "If things heat up with the Russian factor, that's something that can affect the market. Anything that looks like military intervention could have a dampening effect on the European market, and that could seep into the US market."

Europe's eastern fringes - from the Middle East to the Balkans to the Ukraine itself - are notoriously unstable.

When shots are fired in this part of the world, "it's like lighting a match" near a tinder box, said Ms Krosby, a former State Department official.

Last week, the broad Standard & Poor's 500 finished at its highest level ever after Federal Reserve chairman Janet Yellen said the central bank stood ready to increase its levels of bond buying if the economy took a turn for the worse. Even Friday's drastic downward revision to the rate of fourth-quarter gross-domestic product growth caused stocks to rise as traders bet it would encourage Ms Yellen to pause in the "tapering" of purchases. This week, there will be a cornucopia of data to digest, including key manufacturing and services surveys midweek and Friday's February jobs report from the Labor Department.

The February jobs report may be the "anti-Goldilocks" - just cold enough to raise growth concerns, but not cold enough to prompt the Fed to change its policy. Most economists expect the number of jobs added to be well shy of the 200,000 level associated with optimum growth and the unemployment rate to tick down by no more than one tenth of one percentage point.

"The Fed is clear that they don't want to pause on the taper," said Ms Krosby. "It's clear that the threshold is quite high - what you're left with is how 'bad does bad need to be?' If things deteriorated and there's a major U-turn in the economy, she will pause, but nobody knows how bad bad has to be."

Even if the jobs report is worse than expected, both investors and central bankers will take the negative surprise with a pinch of salt said Oliver Pursche, president of money manager Gary Goldberg Financial Services.

"There will be weather distortions in the jobs report," Mr Pursche said. "If you look at the way markets reacted on economic data that kind of brushed off bad news, saying 'Well, you don't know how much the weather's playing into that.' "

Similarly, investors may turn a blind eye to the Institute for Supply Management's factor-activity index, likely to teeter near the flat line for the second straight month.

Most investors are working under the assumption, "that 'when the weather gets better, the data will get better as well,' " as portfolio strategists at brokerage Barclays Capital put it.

One reason the rally may continue in the weeks and months to come - barring an "exogenous shock" like an international war - is the fact that most stocks are relatively cheap compared with historical averages.

JD Joyce, a financial adviser and president of JD Joyce Investment Management Group in Houston, said the market is overdue for a significant correction. Still, he is encouraging clients to buy stocks because the average price-to-earnings multiple remains low, suggesting any correction would be short-lived.

"In an environment where interest rates are at record lows and the market's at a record high, it's almost like having to hold your nose to invest in the equity market," Mr Joyce said. "I'm comfortable doing so."

With the S&P 500 trading at roughly 16 times estimated aggregate 2014 earnings, it's much closer to the historical average "trough" of market corrections around 14 times "forward" earnings than the average "peak" of bull markets around 26 times earnings, Mr Joyce said.

The standoff in the Crimea is likely to make the market jumpy this week. Still, if there are no further shocks from the Ukraine or from the economic data, expect the US stock market to stay close to its record highs.

site_title: Qantas must re-examine its business model
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Qantas must re-examine its business model

Published

Mon, Mar 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SLASHING 5,000 jobs, reducing fleet size, freezing plane orders, pulling out of some routes, unloading assets and downsizing other operations, including terminating its Brisbane Airport lease. These are some of the drastic steps Australian carrier Qantas is taking after posting a pre-tax loss of A$252 million (S$285 million) for the first half of its financial year.

All these are part of a broader A$2 billion cost-cutting plan drawn up by the carrier which is struggling with its international operations and seeing its domestic market coming under pressure from arch-rival Virgin Australia.

Qantas' decision to tie up with Emirates, and reposition its international hub at Dubai has not really helped, it seems. Some observers in Australia, including former Qantas senior officials, have wondered aloud whether this arrangement benefits Qantas or its erstwhile rival.

Meanwhile, the loss of its investment grade following its ratings downgrade to junk status has made fund raising difficult. The question now is, what next?

The airline business is fraught with more challenges than elsewhere. Anything from terrorism, natural calamities, to union issues, economic conditions and fuel prices can impact business.

In Qantas' case, there is also the disadvantage of being an end-of-line carrier. Australia makes a good destination, but a bad hub to anywhere other than the icy Antarctic. To some extent, Qantas is a victim of geography.

But the airline has been pointing fingers at rivals such as Virgin Australia for its woes. CEO Alan Joyce's well-rehearsed line goes like this: Virgin Australia competes on an uneven field, backed by government-owned and cash rich carriers of Singapore, Abu Dhabi and New Zealand. As a result, Virgin Australia has been able to up its game, offering better products and services, and thus drawing business away.

There is some truth in this. But this is the reality of business today, especially in the world of aviation.

There are no easy solutions. Hoping for government support may just be that - hope. Despite the utterances of treasurer Joe Hockey, Prime Minister Tony Abbot has shut the door on any bail-out. Blocking competitors (as it did to Singapore Airlines on the trans-Pacific route), doesn't pay off either.

Qantas has to re-examine its business model and even is ownership rules. It still controls 65 per cent of its profitable domestic and trans-Tasman market. It has good assets and mostly competent people running them.

It needs to revamp its international business. Instead of being eurocentric, it should perhaps gravitate more towards Asia, Africa and the Latin Americas - the world's fastest growing aviation markets. Abandoning Changi (an Asian hub where it had strong presence and long history) for Dubai (where its submits to Emirates) has not worked - at least not so far.

Qantas is a valuable brand. It has a special place in the hearts of Australians and is a key player in the aviation industry. With the right moves it can regain its former glory.

site_title: S'pore not necessarily the 'costliest city'
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S'pore not necessarily the 'costliest city'

Appreciation in exchange rate big factor in rise in living costs for expats: ACI

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE steady appreciation of the Singapore dollar was a significant contributing factor to Singapore being ranked first in living costs for expatriates, according to a study by the Asia Competitiveness Institute (ACI).

The study covered 109 cities, providing cost of living, wage, and purchasing power indices for both expatriates and the average resident from 2005 to 2012. This study is the first of its kind to cover average residents.

In the study, Singapore was ranked most expensive in living costs for expatriates. However, this was partially due to a 25 per cent appreciation of the Singapore dollar against the US dollar.

When comparing the cost of living index for expatriates in Singapore against the index for Hong Kong, where the currency is tied to the US dollar, ACI found that while Singapore's index value kept rising, Hong Kong's remained relatively dormant.

"I was curious . . . how could Hong Kong be so flat in the expats' cost of living index, and Singapore's . . . be steadily (increasing)?" said Tan Khee Giap, co-director of ACI. "When it comes to average residents, they're about the same. So that puzzled me . . . and we decided, let's investigate."

The "investigation" came in the form of a simulation, where ACI used the Singapore dollar exchange rate from 2005 (US$1 = S$1.66) instead of 2012 (US$1 = S$1.25) to calculate the indices.

Without the 25 per cent exchange rate appreciation effect, Singapore's ranking fell from first to 16th, not far from its 2005 ranking, where it ranked in the 17th place.

Hong Kong's simulated result, however, remained in 20th place, as its currency did not appreciate within the same time period.

The rise in cost of living for expatriates, however, is not solely due to the exchange rate appreciation effect, said ACI. There were some other significant contributing factors, including housing costs (118 per cent increase) and transport (49 per cent increase). In the worldwide rankings for 2012, housing and transport costs for expatriates in Singapore were ranked highest in the world.

Even with the rise in exchange rate, housing costs still ranked second highest in the world, and transport costs remained in first place.

This does not mean that Singapore is the world's most expensive city, as it is still relatively affordable for locals to live in Singapore.

The study placed Singapore's cost of living index for average residents at 60th in the 2012 world rankings - a position unaffected by the appreciation in exchange rate, and a far cry from its ranking in the expatriates' cost of living index.

However, cautioned Dr Tan Khee Giap, the difference in the indices for expatriates and local residents was not indicative of income disparity or wealth disparity, as the indices were based purely on prices.

The cost of living being much higher for expatriates than average residents was a trend observed in cities of other Asian countries like Seoul and Beijing.

"This is a duality effect . . . the filet mignon versus pork chop effect," said Tan Kong Yam, co-director of ACI, explaining that the highly different consumption patterns of expatriates and average residents gave rise to the disparity in rankings.

He also noted that in cities such as Paris and New York this difference was not as apparent, as it was "roughly equally expensive for expats and domestic residents" to live there.

Indeed, in comparison to New York - which was used as the base for the study - the average Singaporean's cost of living was 35 per cent lower. Dr Tan Kong Yam pointed out three key areas that were much cheaper for Singaporeans than New Yorkers: healthcare (75 per cent cheaper), education (73 per cent cheaper), and housing (27 per cent cheaper).

This, he said, was due to government subsidies for Singapore residents in these areas. As expatriates are not covered by these subsidies, they find it more expensive than the local residents.

Looking towards the future, Dr Tan Khee Giap raised the importance of monitoring the affordability of education, housing, healthcare and transport costs for locals over the next decade, mentioning the possibility of ACI doing affordability indices to monitor those four areas.

site_title: EMA reviews disclosure of data for better trading
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

EMA reviews disclosure of data for better trading

Published

Mon, Mar 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] With a six-month trial starting this month for electricity futures trading - followed by expected trading proper in October - the Energy Market Authority (EMA) is reviewing the disclosure of market information and how to enhance this to better facilitate trading and risk management for participants in both the spot and futures power markets.

The regulator launched an industry consultation yesterday regarding market disclosure in both the Singapore wholesale electricity market (ie the spot market) and the electricity futures market, and has offered two proposals to enhance data transparency.

The EMA paper also confirmed the expected launch date for electricity futures trading when it said that this is "anticipated to commence operation . . . on Oct 1". BT had earlier cited an official from the Singapore Exchange - which will administer electricity futures trading and be the clearing house - disclosing the April launch of trials, followed by trading proper in October, with dates subject to MAS approval.

EMA said that there are two broad information categories. One is market information available to spot market and non-market participants who subscribe to data services provided by the Energy Market Company which operates the spot market. The second is information available only to spot market participants or a subset of this. And the regulator is proposing that data subscribers should also be given the same market information currently provided to spot market participants or generating companies (gencos).

It said that it "has assessed that there would be no commercial sensitivity or adverse impact on market competition or national security" if such information is extended to others. The latter includes the Adequacy and Security Assessment reports which provide data about forecasts of power system demand, available generation and reserve capacity, and the Annual Outage Plan of participants' planned downtime for overhauls and maintenance of generating units and non-generating equipment. Also included is the Projected Gas Curtailment Schedule on when gencos expect gas supplies to be affected, including by upstream events such as maintenance in the Indonesian and Malaysian gas fields.

"Disclosure would help to eliminate the significant information asymmetry that currently exists and may provide pro-competitive benefits to futures market participants."

The regulator said that currently, physical offer information including the price-quantity offers of gencos in the spot market for physical delivery to end-consumers is not disclosed. While recognising that this information will help facilitate electricity trading, the EMA added it could also increase the likelihood of independent exercise of market power or concerted activities among spot market participants to push up spot prices, hence EMA's second proposal for the Energy Market Company to publish aggregate energy offer information with a four-week time lag on a trial basis for six months.

"We assess the four-week delay to be adequate for short-term tight market conditions to normalise and mitigate informational feedback for strategic bidding in the spot market." EMA added it will also "continue to monitor all gencos' bidding behaviour closely and take firm regulatory actions against any genco exhibiting anti-competitive behaviour".

SUBSCRIBERS

Gold price expected to see bigger swings in Q2

Published

Mon, Mar 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

GOLD price volatility is likely to be higher in the second quarter, given the mixed outlook, said broker Phillip Futures in a report yesterday.

Among the bearish factors weighing on gold prices are speculative safe haven hedges which have arisen after several defaults in China instilled fear among investors.

This may wear off as the government shows that it is ultimately still in control, Phillip Futures said.

"We believe speculative fear may add further upward momentum to gold if the future turn of events in China confirms investors' fears. That said, we believe the government is capable of and will continue to maintain firm control of the credit and financial sector."

The uncertain outlook in China has added about US$60 to the gold price, according to Phillip Futures' estimate, showing an uninformed understanding of China's trust market, it said.

In its view, such products form "a very small proportion" of the 11 trillion yuan trust sector, and are only sold to high network individuals who have the ability to absorb such shocks.

The gold price has risen 7 per cent or some US$91 so far this year, to US$1,294 a troy ounce.

The slow recovery in the US, coupled with a more hawkish monetary stance that the Federal Reserve took in its last meeting in March, would provide further pressure on gold, said Phillip Futures.

But unforeseen geopolitical tensions could provide a support to gold price.

Also, institutional investors - who caused the gold price to plunge 28 per cent last year when they sold off gold-related holdings - have become more positive, which would help boost gold prices.

"There has been an absence of outflow since mid-February and in fact, there are hints of increase in fund holdings since then," said the brokerage house.

But a combination of rising open interest and long positions - indicating a bet on rising gold prices - is worrying, as a drop in gold prices would lead to a covering of such positions, compounding the slide in gold prices, it added.

"Looking ahead, fundamental factors offer mixed outlook, sentiments seem to have turned more bullish but technical indicators turned more bearish. As such, the quarter ahead is expected to be a very dynamic and exciting one," it said.

CapitaLand secures 60% stake in Chengdu sites

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

IN A move to deepen its presence in China, CapitaLand has secured a 60 per cent stake in two adjacent prime residential sites in the New Southern Area of Chengdu in Sichuan province.

This interest is acquired through a proposed subscription of shares in two Chinese companies which own the sites for a total of 752 million yuan (S$155.6 million) in cash.

CapitaLand said that it planned to build 4,600 residential units for first-time homebuyers and upgraders on the sites, which cover about 133,333 square metres.

"CapitaLand continues to be confident of the potential of the Chinese market and this acquisition is in line with its strategy of strengthening and deepening its presence in China through the five city clusters, including Chengdu," said CapitaLand China chief executive Jason Leow.

He noted that Chengdu is attracting domestic and foreign investments and displays tremendous growth potential arising from rapid urbanisation and China's "Go West" strategy.

Under the share subscription agreement, CapitaLand's wholly owned unit, Shanghai Zhong Da Industry Development, will enter into a 60-40 joint venture with the existing sole shareholder of the two Chinese companies Chengdu Kai Guang Property and Chengdu Hong Hu Zhan Property.

The total net asset value of these two Chinese companies is 1.25 billion yuan. This transaction is scheduled to be completed in the second quarter, subject to approval by the Chinese authorities. It is not expected to have any material financial impact on the group this fiscal year. Construction will likely begin in the second quarter with the first phase targeted for launch by the end of this year, CapitaLand said.

This project is nestled in a mature residential area surrounded by mid- to high-end projects and located inside the Da Yuan cluster within the central core of Chengdu's Tian Fu New Area, a modern metropolis that focuses on advanced manufacturing and high-end service industries.

The sites are served by main roads and Metro Line 5 and enjoy strong connectivity to nearby commercial developments, such as the New Century Global Centre, the world's largest commercial building, as well as other retail, F&B and leisure facilities.

Mr Leow said that Raffles City Chengdu, a mixed development consisting of retail, Grade A offices, Ascott-branded serviced residences and premium condominiums that opened in September 2012, and the group's other residential projects in the city such as luxury project, The Loft, have been very well received by the local community.

CapitaLand China had said in its fiscal 2013 report that it expected to hand over more than 3,000 units this year, mainly from The Loft, La Cite in Foshan and International Trade Centre in Tianjin, The Metropolis in Kunshan and Dolce Vita in Guangzhou.

SIA increases stake in Virgin Australia to 22.17% for A$30.4m

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

SINGAPORE Airlines has raised its stake in Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd (VAH) to 22.17 per cent - from 19.83 per cent - for a total consideration of A$30.4 million (S$35.5 million).

The acquisition makes SIA VAH's second largest shareholder after Air New Zealand, and ahead of Etihad Airways.

Virgin Australia (previously Virgin Blue) is Australia's second largest airline, after Qantas Airways, with a fleet of 133 aircraft with an average fleet age of 4.2 years.

SIA increased its holdings after the purchase of 35,045,334 additional shares on the Australian Securities Exchange over some two months from Feb 6 to March 26. The total consideration paid for the shares was A$12.5 million.

In addition, SIA's settlement of an equity share swap relating to VAH's entitlement offer in November and December last year allowed the airline to take up another 42,048,785 ordinary shares for A$17.9 million.

VAH's other major shareholders are Air New Zealand with 24.46 per cent, Etihad Airways at 19.9 per cent and Virgin Group with 7.37 per cent. While both Air NZ and SIA have been adding to their stakes over the past six months, the Virgin Group cut its stake by 63 million shares or 2 per cent last October.

With the acquisition, the free float of Virgin Australia will fall to just 28 per cent, making it one of the most tightly held publicly listed airlines, despite its still unprofitable operations. Virgin Australia reported a net loss of A$98 million for the year ended June 30, 2013.

Besides SIA's portfolio of four key airline brands - Singapore Airlines, SilkAir, Scoot and Tiger Air - its holding in Virgin Australia is becoming increasingly important as seen by the increased stake.

SUBSCRIBERS

UK home prices continue rising for the 14th month in March

Published

Mon, Mar 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] UK house prices increased for a 14th consecutive month in March, the longest run of gains in almost seven years, as momentum spread across the country.

Values in England and Wales rose 0.6 per cent from February, with the south-west and East Anglia registering the largest increases, property researcher Hometrack Ltd said in a report published yesterday. Prices in London climbed 0.7 per cent, while 50 per cent of postcode districts reported gains.

Record-low borrowing costs and a government-incentive plan have spurred concern that the UK housing market risks overheating.

Bank of England financial stability officials said last week there's increasing momentum in the market and pledged to take more action if needed.

"Half of the country registered a price increase in March for a second month in a row," said Richard Donnell, director of research at Hometrack.

"The real driver of higher house prices is record-low mortgage rates and strong demand from first-time buyers and investors who have no property to sell."

Yorkshire and Humberside and the north-west region registered the smallest gains, with values increasing 0.2 per cent in March. Prices in the south-west and East Anglia increased 0.8 per cent.

Nationally, prices rose 5.7 per cent in March from a year earlier and the annual rate of growth was positive across all regions for the first time since September 2007, Hometrack said. The proportion of sellers achieving their asking price was 96.2 per cent in March, the highest since 2004. In London, the proportion was 99.3 per cent.

BOE officials adopted measures to restrain housing by ending mortgage incentives under its Funding for Lending Scheme in November.

While the Financial Policy Committee said this month it will "remain vigilant", it also noted that a number of indicators remained below their long-run average levels. - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Suntory's spirited strategy

Canny planning has helped change the image of staid old whisky for a new generation. By Jaime Ee

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THEY'RE smoky. Stuffy. Chaotic. Elbow room is a luxury, social niceties an afterthought and the food deliberately oversalted. But when spirits are high - in more ways than one - such things don't matter to a Japanese salary man whose sole intention is to pack his daytime persona as straight-laced, subservient model employee back into his manbag so that his real self can come out to play.

Behold the izakaya - a pub with food to you but a way of life to the Japanese, a culture deeply ingrained since the Edo period that's in no danger of dying out any time soon. Certainly not at Tachinomi Marugin - or simply Marugin - a grungy hard-core izakaya that sits on the fringe of Tokyo's shiny Ginza district. Locals and clued-in tourists pack shoulder-to-shoulder in this tight space shrouded in silvery grey smoke as flexible servers coolly slither around, delivering freshly grilled yakitori and boiled edamame. Groups of dark-suited men (and some women) sit with their ties askew, laughing uproariously as they nibble and knock back gulps of Kaku highball served in giant beer mugs - the alcoholic refresher of choice which has become synonymous with Japan's izakaya culture.

The thirst-quenching, lightly boozy combination of one shot of Suntory whisky and four shots of soda water - the ratio is imperative - is a prime example of how clever marketing and carefully calculated strategy can reverse the image of a once boring liqueur and influence social trends at the same time.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Jardine group, banks put STI back in the black

Published

Fri, Mar 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT TOOK almost three months, but better late than never - the Straits Times Index yesterday rose 9.71 points to 3,172.17, pushing it about five points or 0.2 per cent into the black for the year-to-date. It was the first time since Jan 2 that the STI closed in positive territory for 2014.

For the week, the index gained 100 points or 3.2 per cent. The STI started the year at 3,167, but since closing at 3,174 on the first day of the year, it has traded below. The first quarter low was 2,960 on Feb 5, which means that since then, the index has bounced 212 points or 7.2 per cent.

The bulk of the gains over the past fortnight have come courtesy of the banks and Jardine stocks, which has prompted observers to speak of quarter-ending window dressing. That is plausible given that there were no

really notable market-moving developments on the external front this week other than Russia being axed from the G8 group of nations amid tensions in Crimea, and China releasing weak PMI numbers.

Both these events were brushed off by markets preoccupied with bond yields, rising interest rates and possibly the health of the US economy.

Somewhat perversely, China's slowdown actually supported stocks because of hopes that the government would have to step in with stimulus measures, while over in the US, strong economic releases were not really welcomed by the market, possibly because they hint at interest rate hikes sooner rather later.

On Thursday, China's premier Li Keqiang said he recognised downward pressures and downside risks to growth and is well prepared to stabilise growth with a pipeline of policies.

Here, Jardine Matheson proved the top performer with a huge US$7.58 or 14 per cent jump over the five days to US$63.10. Jardine Strategic, Cycle & Carriage and Hongkong Land also weighed in with strong contributions. Among the rest of the index components, a rebound in the banks should also be noted.

Also helping was Noble Group, whose shares rose 13.6 per cent this week to $1.21. The commodities firm has announced that it has signed a 10-year supply agreement with Sundance Resources, which is planning to mine iron ore in central-west Africa. According to one report, the Noble-Sundance deal may be worth as much as US$3.5 billion a year, based on a sales price of US$100 a tonne after costs.

Among the banks, OCBC yesterday fell 11 cents to $9.51 on volume of 3.8 million following reports that it has won preliminary approval from Hong Kong regulators to take over Wing Hang Bank. The market perceives OCBC as having overpaid for the acquisition.

In the second line, satellite and wireless digital technology firm AddValue Technology's shares were by far the best performer with a 7.8-cent or 124 per cent surge during the week to 14.1 cents, the bulk of which came on Wednesday after the company announced that it plans to sell its wholly owned subsidiary AddValue Communications to a China buyer for $330 million in cash.

In response to a media article that asked for more information, the company responded on Thursday that its technology is attractive to players interested in expanding into the field of high-end broadband satellite communications, and provided examples of other similar sales in the region. AddValue's shares dropped sharply since the mid-week burst which took place on volume of 198 million. In yesterday's session the stock slipped 0.8 cent and just 13.2 million shares were traded.

Among the other penny stocks in play were China water treatment plays like HanKore and Memstar, while Johor property play Albedo was also in focus despite some confusion over whether its deal in the Iskandar region of Johor is still on.

KSH-Lian Beng unit in Cambodia property deal

ISEA in joint venture to buy US$64m land and redevelop hotel on it

Published

Wed, Mar 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IMPERIAL South East Asia Investment (ISEA), 34.7 per cent owned by KSH Holdings and 32.65 per cent owned by Lian Beng Group, is forming a joint venture (JV) to acquire a piece of land in Cambodia for US$64 million, with plans to redevelop the existing hotel on it.

ISEA has signed a JV agreement with Lok Oknha Sear Rithy, a Cambodian national unrelated to both the listed property development groups, to set up a real estate development firm in Cambodia called New Global Imperial Investment.

The principal activity of New Global will be real estate development and investment holding in Cambodia.

New Global is expected, on incorporation, to have a registered capital of 20,000,000 KHR (approximately US$5,000), 49 per cent to be held by ISEA and 51 per cent by Sear Rithy.

This JV will become owner of a 15,882 square metre plot of land at Village 2, Sangkat Chaktomuk, Khan Daun Penh, Phnom Penh, which currently houses the Imperial Garden Villa & Hotel.

New Global plans to redevelop the property, subject to obtaining necessary approvals from the authorities.

"The redevelopment plans are at a very preliminary discussion stage and further details will be provided in due course," it said.

ISEA will fund its 49 per cent of the consideration, or US$31.4 million, with the help of a bond issue to its shareholders.

They are KSH Asia Investment, a unit of KSH Holdings; Wealth Land, a unit of Lian Beng, and Heeton Invesco.

Under the exchangeable bond agreement, the ISEA shareholders have agreed to provide the funding in their respective shareholding proportion in the company.

The ISEA shareholders also have the option to exchange these bonds for new bonds to be issued by New Global to ISEA on a dollar-for-dollar basis.

Both KSH Holdings and Lian Beng are tapping internal resources to fund their bond subscriptions.

KSH Holdings ended half a cent lower at 45 cents, while Lian Beng closed half a cent higher at 57.5 cents yesterday.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Singapore Maritime Week the biggest yet

This year's edition aims to reach out to the public, especially the young

Published

Wed, Mar 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Singapore Maritime Week (SMW) is back with a record number of events for a wide audience ranging from industry players to the general public.

Driven by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA), the ninth edition of the SMW, from April 6 to 11, centres around the theme of "People, Ideas and Opportunities". It will be the biggest show since its inception in 2006 featuring 29 events.

"We have put in more efforts to reach out to the public, especially the young, through fun and exciting outreach activities," said Andrew Tan, chief executive of the MPA.

"Last year's SMW saw some 100,000 participants. We are confident that this year's event will be as successful as previous runs. The continuing growth of SMW shows strong interest in our maritime sector."

Singapore's maritime industry contributes 7 per cent to the country's gross domestic product (GDP) and hires about 170,000 people. The industry is made up of some 5,000 companies from 130 shipping groups, offering a range of products and services.

"We hope to put Singapore on the thought leadership map, by bringing the best experts and practitioners to share their expertise and insights, and promoting the exchange of best practices in the industry. With Singapore's strategic location, SMW also provides a one of its kind business platform for companies to access new market in the region and beyond," Mr Tan said.

Thought leadership events include the Moore Stephens Shipping Forum, which will discuss the economic trends that affect the shipping industry, the Dry Cargo Chartering Seminar and the Asian Maritime Law Conference, which will showcase the professionals and knowledge leaders.

In addition, the Automation and Autonomy Seminar will address the challenges of the shortage of skilled labour and productivity, while the Sustainable Marine Transportation Conference, jointly organised by the Royal Norwegian Embassy and MPA, offers insights into global operational and environmental issues, strategies and technological advancements.

The ReCAAP ISC Piracy and Sea Robbery Conference will give an update on piracy and sea robbery in Asia, and discuss the challenges in providing a safer operating environment for all forms of shipping.

Jacques de Chateauvieux, chairman of the board of Bourbon, and chairman and CEO of Jaccar Holdings, will deliver the Singapore Maritime Lecture on April 9.

The SMW events will also create opportunities to forge business relationships. IBC Asia will organise three offshore conferences for the offshore maritime community. The conferences include the Floating Production Storage and Offloading Conference, Offshore Drilling Conference and Offshore Support Vessels Conference.

The TOC Contain Supply Chain Asia Conference, which has a 16-year history, will provide a comprehensive event for the container transport community. The Singapore Maritime Lecture cocktail, Seatrade Asia Awards and the Sea Asia launch reception will provide networking opportunities for the local and international participants.

The Singapore Yacht Show offers an opportunity to discover some of the world's finest superyacht and international yacht brands while the Asia Pacific Superyacht and Boating Conference will be a platform to discuss ideas and promote the industry.

Singaporeans can visit the SMW exhibition at shopping centres - VivoCity, Jurong Point and Parkway Parade - from March 31 to April 6. More than 400 students, maritime employees and the public will go on Maritime Learning Journeys that include a port and sea tour to the Raffles Lighthouse.

More youths and students will be involved in SMW by co-organising career talks and as guides for selected public outreach activities.

Houston channel remains shut

Published

Tue, Mar 25, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TEXAS CITY] The closure of the vital Houston Ship Channel looked set to extend to a fourth day after the Coast Guard struggled to finish cleaning up after an oil barge spill on Monday, threatening to force deeper production cuts at local refiners.

Earlier on Monday, the Coast Guard had told ship operators that it should be able to reopen the waterway later in the day, resuming at least some supply of crude oil to more than one-tenth of the nation's refining capacity.

"We will begin the process of a tapered ... not a floodgate resumption of marine traffic," Captain Brian Penoyer, commander of US Coast Guard sector Houston-Galveston and captain of the Port of Houston, told reporters on Monday. "We anticipate re-opening the Houston Ship Channel as soon as we can," he said.

However, the Port of Houston was still shut by evening, officials said, with the queue of waiting vessels growing to more than 90.

Capt Penoyer explained that traffic can't move again until there's no more oil in the water to cling to ships and be carried further. Also, any ships that were touched must be cleaned before moving through water deemed sufficiently clean.

The closure of the channel on Saturday has led to a queue of more than 90 vessels trying to move into or out of the Gulf of Mexico. Shipping delays forced Exxon Mobil Corp to cut production at the nation's second-largest refinery.

Exxon said production at its 560,500 barrel per day Baytown, Texas, refinery had been cut on Monday due to the closure of the Houston Ship Channel. The company expects further production cuts by mid-week if the channel remains shut. - Reuters

site_title: Basel III won't shift S'pore banks' focus on SMEs
content:
Basel III won't shift S'pore banks' focus on SMEs

Some fear costs linked to higher risk under new rule may be passed to SMEs

Published

Sun, Mar 23, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Banks in Singapore are maintaining their support for small and medium enterprises (SMEs), despite the higher funding requirements for the higher risk that banks have to bear. But there are concerns that the higher cost of SME funding would be passed on to the small businesses.

One way that higher funding cost is captured in the Basel III regulatory framework is through the net stable funding ratio (NSFR), through which banks show that they are not overly reliant on short-term or unstable funding over a one-year period.

With an increasing minimum capital requirement under Basel III, banks have to set aside more capital per dollar of risk-weighted assets, and this impacts SME exposures more relatively, said chief financial officer at DBS, Chng Sok Hui.

"Basel III rules have never specifically targeted SME exposures: it is not a problematic asset class that triggered the global financial crisis. However, SME exposures are typically higher risk and thus invite higher risk weights," she said.

Still, SME lending remains one of the bank's priorities, with income from SMEs growing 11 per cent last year to $1.4 billion.

"We are able to grow the franchise, and stand by our SME customers because of our strong capital ratios," said Ms Chng.

United Overseas Bank (UOB) and OCBC Bank echoed similar views, noting that the segment is strategically important to the banks.

"In the small business segment, the risk weighting for assets is low because the loan portfolio is made up of smaller-sized loans spread across a big group of customers. In other words, it is a business with diversified risks," said Victor Lee, group head of business banking at UOB.

But SMEs, having low bargaining power with banks, may bear a disproportionate amount of this increased cost if costs are passed on by banks, said Gary Chia, head of financial services regulatory compliance at KPMG in Singapore.

"Banks which typically finance SMEs need to improve their capital quality, mostly by resorting to retained earnings. This implies an indirect pressure on margins for these banks, which needs to be passed on to their customers - the SMEs."

Still, while Basel III imposes higher capital requirements on banks for lending to smaller SMEs, key SME banks here have already been operating on risk-based models before the introduction of Basel III, noted Linus Goh, chairman of the Singapore Business Federation's (SBF) SME sub-committee on financing.

"We believe the enhancement to the government risk-sharing from 50 per cent to 70 per cent for the microloan programme in Budget 2014 will also help improve the financing to small businesses," said Mr Goh, who is also OCBC's head of global commercial banking.

There are signs that lending to SMEs have not eased. Based on the SBF-DP SME Index for the first quarter of this year, bank lending has increased and there appears to be a smaller number of SMEs facing financing challenges. Still, last year's SME development survey showed that there are SMEs that continue to have difficulty accessing funding from banks, either because of the lack of a track record or sufficient assets for collateral.

Broadly, Basel III should prompt banks to evolve from universal banks to specialist lenders to improve their margins, said Lim Eng Hock, partner and practise leader at Ernst and Young.

site_title: 2014: A transformative year for cloud computing
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

2014: A transformative year for cloud computing

Many trends will come to the fore

Published

Sun, Mar 23, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE cloud matured faster last year than in any previous year, with pace-setting organisations using it to accelerate the adoption of mobile, social, analytics and Big Data technologies. But last year was just the tip of the iceberg, compared to what this year has in store for the cloud community.

To say this year will be a transformative year for the cloud would be an understatement. The push for interoperable clouds, built on open standards, the evolution of delivery models, and the convergence of cloud ecosystems, are just a few examples of trends that will shape cloud computing in the year ahead.

Based on the insights gained from US$6 billion invested in research and development (R&D), 1,400 cloud patents and more than 37,000 cloud specialists, an IBM team looked ahead to see what the cloud would bring to organisations this year. They found some broad trends.

Firstly, the continued adoption of the cloud across different business lines and the spread of shadow IT will lead to a fundamental shift in the role of the CIO (chief information officer).

The role of the CIO is changing from a manager of traditional IT systems to a broker of cloud infrastructure, applications and information services. As the cloud becomes more pervasive in various lines of business, IT will start to assume ownership of integration, service levels and governance around cloud services.

CIOs today must also strengthen their established relationships with existing IT partners, who will become increasingly important in helping the transition into this new role. By partnering specialists to help guide them on their cloud journey, IT leaders will be able to create business value by reducing risk and accelerating the implementation of cloud services.

Secondly, Cloud Foundry will emerge as the de-facto standard for platform-as-a-service (PaaS). The OpenStack foundation was launched in September 2012; by the end of 2013, OpenStack had emerged as the de-facto industry standard for infrastructure-as-a-service with over 12,000 people involved in the project. As platform-as-a-service offerings mature, the push for a similarly ubiquitous platform built on open standards will intensify as organisations look to avoid vendor lock-in while meeting the demand to build cloud-based mobile, social and analytic applications.

Thirdly, industry-specific clouds will become the norm, driving cloud adoption in finance, healthcare, telecommunications, retail, energy and utilities and more.

Until recently, most clouds fell into the "one-size-fits-all category", with basic cloud features and benefits applied to every organisation, regardless of industry. But organisations aren't basic; rather, they belong to an industry with unique needs, challenges and advantages.

To help facilitate and expedite the move to the cloud, industry-specific clouds are being developed to help organisations - with a common shared service outcome, social need or business requirement - make use of cloud services faster and more efficiently. As a result, the rate of adoption for private clouds will continue to increase. Over the last several years, private cloud deployments have driven a large percentage of the overall cloud spending.

Another key trend is that mobile-first, cloud-delivered enterprise applications embedded with analytics will create new possibilities for real-time data analysis anywhere on any device. Intelligence is rapidly moving away from individual devices and into the cloud, while an increasingly diverse array of devices are being used to complete essential job functions. As cloud, mobile and Big Data continue to converge, large data sets stored in the cloud are leading to new opportunities for data analysis that were never before possible.

Cloud ecosystems are networks where partners and third parties converge to build and deliver an enhanced range of services on top of cloud platforms. As uniformed open standards are increasingly embraced up the stack, ecosystems will expand and will begin to work together to develop top-to-bottom solutions that can be leveraged across any open cloud platform.

Users who are running on top of an open cloud will benefit tremendously from this convergence, while those running on proprietary models will see their IT deployments become increasingly isolated.

Recently, analyst firm Gartner alluded to this escalating growth in the cloud and predicted that the bulk of new IT spending by 2016 will be for cloud computing platforms and applications, with nearly half of large enterprises having cloud deployments by the end of 2017.

Cloud technologies built on open standards have the opportunity to become the norm. Not just in business, but in every way we touch technology. As organisations begin to realise that the cloud can do so much more than simply speed up or reduce the cost of their IT, the cloud will have a significant impact on the way we work and play.

The author is cloud computing leader at IBM Singapore

site_title: Sub-800 sq ft units' share of new sales hits record
content:
Sub-800 sq ft units' share of new sales hits record

Spike is due to 500-800 sq ft units, not shoebox units

Published

Mon, Mar 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Small units of up to 800 square feet made up a record proportion, 47.6 per cent, of non-landed private homes sold by developers last year. This was up from 43.4 per cent a year earlier.

A caveats analysis by CBRE found that the over 40 per cent share started in 2011.

"This is a function of supply," said CBRE Research associate director Desmond Sim, "as developers have been reducing unit sizes to keep the absolute price quantum affordable to buyers especially investors, who have been slapped with successively tighter loan limits in recent years."

The spike in small units' share, however, is not due to the so-called shoebox apartments (below 500 sq ft) but to 500-800 sq ft units.

The property consulting group's analysis - which excluded executive condos, a public-private housing hybrid - found that 500-800 sq ft units' proportion has increased steadily to 34.4 per cent last year, from 29.7 per cent in 2012, 25.9 per cent in 2011 and 18.9 per cent in 2010.

This reflects the trend of developers minting more compact two- and three-bedders in a bid to keep absolute price quantums within buyers' reach - despite higher per square foot prices.

Meanwhile, the share of shoebox units dropped to 13.2 per cent last year, from 13.8 per cent in 2012 and the high of 15.1 per cent in 2011.

Analysts attribute this partly to an Urban Redevelopment Authority cap, effective Nov 4, 2012, on the number of homes in new non-landed residential projects Outside the Central Area, based on an average unit size of 70 square metres (753.47 sq ft) gross floor area.

The growing share of small homes in the past few years is also reflected in a contraction in median unit sizes - the figure has shrunk 30.6 per cent to 829 sq ft last year from 1,195 sq ft in 2009. Over the same period, the median per square foot price increased 47.2 per cent to $1,354 from $920, while the median lumpsum unit price rose 12 per cent to $1.08 million from $965,000.

Market watchers note that the end of the global financial crisis was marked by an era of unprecedented money-printing by governments in many parts of the world, creating a surge of global liquidity and low interest rates.

This has resulted in investors snapping up properties in many markets - including Singapore, driving up suburban condo prices.

To counter this, some developers began building a higher ratio of small units to keep lumpsum prices affordable and widen the pool of potential buyers.

Developers have also found that small units help investors overcome the lower loan-to-value limits introduced for those with at least one existing home mortgage and seeking to buy more residential properties.

And with the Total Debt Servicing Ratio framework rolled out last June, financial institutions are required, when granting property loans to individuals, to cap a borrower's total monthly debt obligations to no more than 60 per cent of gross monthly income.

"Thus, it has become increasingly difficult for potential homebuyers to obtain a loan, if they do not have enough cash," noted Mr Sim.

Developers told BT that in 2009, after the global crisis, they were building two-bedroom apartments of typically around 900-950 sq ft. This has shrunk to 700-750 sq ft compact two-bedders today. Over the same period, three-bedroom units have been compressed from 1,100-1,150 sq ft to around 950 sq ft.

Frasers Centrepoint Homes CEO Cheang Kok Kheong said that demand for compact units comes from young couples to baby boomers/retirees. "Most buyers still want the master bedroom and kitchen to be sufficiently sized. We're also seeing creative storage solutions - for instance, above wardrobes, near the ceiling (by moving air-con pipes to the side) and insertion of linen storage areas along the corridor between the living room and bedrooms."

Looking ahead, Mr Sim said that in light of reduced spending power of buyers post-TDSR, developers are likely to stick to the strategy of carving out a high ratio of affordable homes. "Hence, we will continue to see small-format homes making up a high proportion of new home sales."

Mr Cheang reckoned that if more study/library space is provided as part of a development's common facilities, compact apartment sizes could potentially be trimmed a further 5-10 per cent. "But we've not done that because our customers are not ready."

Agreeing, another developer said that unit sizes are unlikely to shrink further for the time being. "However, the proportion of developer sales in the sub-800 sq ft category may still go up because TDSR has reduced loan availability and the still-high property prices force buyers to look at compact units to keep within their budget."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Unionmet sheds light on rights puzzle

Substantial owner's entitlement scaled back to avoid triggering takeover

Published

Mon, Mar 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

INDIUM manufacturer and trader Unionmet (Singapore) yesterday clarified that its substantial shareholder, Precious Stream Holdings (PSH), has had its rights entitlement scaled down from 87.9 million shares to 23.9 million, so as not to trigger a mandatory takeover of the company.

The move kept PSH's shareholding below 30 per cent at 29.8 per cent of the company's enlarged share capital, up from 28.65 per cent previously.

Unionmet had on Feb 19 said that PSH's owner, Weng Huixin, had given Unionmet an irrevocable undertaking that she would ensure PSH takes up its rights allotment to the company's renounceable, non-underwritten rights exercise first announced in January.

Since she was deemed to have interest in about 175.8 million Unionmet shares through PSH and since the rights was a one-for-two offer, her undertaking was originally to subscribe for 87.9 million new shares. These were priced at 6.5 cents apiece.

However, the company last Thursday released the results of the issue, in which it said that only 56.6 million rights shares would be issued. This represented only 18.4 per cent of the original 306.8 million. Nothing was said of PSH.

The Business Times on Saturday reported puzzlement among many observers over why there was no mention of PSH's entitlement. It was this low subscription rate that had prompted the scaling back of PSH's portion.

According to the company's Feb 19 Offer Information Statement posted separately, "the company may scale down any shareholder's application to subscribe for any rights shares to avoid placing that shareholder in the position of incurring an obligation to make a mandatory general offer" if other shareholders do not take up their entitlements.

Based on the actual take-up, if PSH was allotted its full entitlement, it would have ended up holding more than 30 per cent of the enlarged capital, triggering a mandatory takeover offer.

Yesterday, Unionmet also clarified that another substantial shareholder, Bestway Premium Investments, which on Feb 19 was said to have expressed interest in taking up its rights entitlements, did not do so.

Unionmet is headquartered in Singapore and its production facilities and R&D divisions are located in Liuzhou, Guangxi, China. It makes and trades non-ferrous metals comprising indium ingots and their related by-products. It was listed on Singapore Exchange's mainboard in January 2007. The 56.6 million new rights shares listed yesterday.

The counter ended 0.1 cent lower at 5.9 cents yesterday.

Flash China PMI shows factory output weakened again in March

[BEIJING] China's manufacturing industry weakened for a fifth straight month, according to a preliminary measure for March released yesterday, deepening concern the nation will miss its 7.5 per cent growth target this year.

The Purchasing Managers' Index from HSBC Holdings and Markit Economics dropped to 48.1, compared with the 48.7 median estimate of 22 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News and last month's final 48.5 figure. Numbers above 50 signal expansion.

Chinese stocks rebounded from initial losses on speculation that weakening growth will prompt policy makers to reconsider their aversion to broad stimulus measures. Leaders face a balancing act of reining in credit expansion that's fuelled the risk of loans going bad, while averting an economic slump that raises the odds of higher unemployment.

SGX site is now counter-intuitive

Published Tue, Mar 25, 2014 · 10:00 PM

USUALLY, an upgrade or revamp is good news because it makes everybody's lives easier. We get upgraded smartphones with bigger screens and faster processing power, for example, so we waste less time accessing applications, squint less at words and images, and are better distracted by smoothly streaming Korean dramas on the train ride to the office.

This ideal of the pursuit of the better life seems to have fallen flat after the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) latest revamp of the all-important "company announcements" section of its website, which went live over the weekend. The page, which retail investors use to get their corporate news and updates, is somehow less accessible and harder to understand after the change.

The most baffling, unannounced change concerns real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts. Previously, someone who wanted to search for the announcements made by, say, Cache Logistics Trust, could go directly to the "company disclosure" section and search immediately for the name of the company. Now, one can only access the information after identifying and searching for the name of the company managing the Reit or trust, which can sometimes be very different.
